History[edit]
The earliest origin  of "grass roots" as a political metaphor are obscure. In the United States, an early use of the phrase "grassroots and boots" was thought to have been coined by Senator Albert Jeremiah Beveridge of Indiana, who said of the Progressive Party in 1912, "This party has come from the grass roots. It has grown from the soil of people's hard necessities". [8]
In a 1907 newspaper article about Ed Perry, vice-chairman of the Oklahoma state committee, the phrase was used as follows: "In regard to his political views Mr. Perry has issued the following terse platform: 'I am for a square deal, grass root representation, for keeping close to the people, against ring rule and for fair treatment.'" [9] A 1904 news article on a campaign for possible Theodore Roosevelt running mate Eli Torrance quotes a Kansas political organizer as saying: "Roosevelt and Torrance clubs will be organized in every locality. We will begin at the grass roots". [10]
Since the early 1900s, grassroots movements have been widespread both in the United States and in other countries. Major examples include parts of the American Civil Rights Movement of the 1950s and 1960s, Brazil's land equity movement of the 1970s and beyond, the Chinese rural democracy movement of the 1980s and the German peace movement of the 1980s.
A particular instantiation of grassroots politics in the American Civil Rights Movement was the 1951 case of William Van Til working on the integration of the Nashville Public Schools. Van Til worked to create a grassroots movement focused on discussing race relations at the local level. To that end, he founded the Nashville Community Relations Conference, which brought together leaders from various communities in Nashville to discuss the possibility of integration. In response to his attempts to network with leadership in the black community, residents of Nashville responded with violence and scare tactics. However, Van Til was still able to bring blacks and whites together to discuss the potential for changing race relations, and he was ultimately instrumental in integrating the Peabody College of Education in Nashville. Furthermore, the desegregation plan proposed by Van Til's Conference was implemented by Nashville schools in 1957. This movement is characterized as grassroots because it focused on changing a norm at the local level using local power. Van Til worked with local organizations to foster political dialogue and was ultimately successful.
The Brazilian Landless Workers Movement (MST) was founded in the 1970s and has grown into an international organization. The MST focused on organizing young farmers and their children in fighting for a variety of rights, most notably the right to access land. The movement sought organic leaders and used strategies of direct action such as land occupations. It largely maintained autonomy from the Brazilian government. The MST traces its roots to discontent arising from large land inequalities in Brazil in the 1960s. Such discontent gained traction, particularly after Brazil became a democracy in 1985. The movement focused especially on occupying land that was considered unproductive, thus showing that it was seeking overall social benefit. In the 1990s the influence of the MST grew tremendously following two mass killings of protestors. Successful protests were those in which the families of those occupying properties receiving plots of land. It is worth noting that although the grassroots efforts of the MST were successful in Brazil when they were tried by the South African Landless People's Movement (LPM) in 2001 they were not nearly as successful. Land occupations in South Africa were politically contentious and did not achieve the positive results seen by the MST. [11]
The National People's Congress was a grassroots democratic reform movement that came out of the existing Chinese government in 1987. It encouraged grassroots elections in villages all around China with the express purpose of bringing democracy to the local level of government. Reforms took the form of self-governing village committees that were elected in a competitive, democratic process. Xu Wang from Princeton University called the Congress mutually empowering for the state and the peasantry in that the state was given a renewed level of legitimacy by the democratic reforms and the peasantry was given far more political power. This manifested itself in increased voting rate, particularly for the poor, and increased levels of political awareness according to Wang's research. One example of the increased accountability from the new institutions was a province in which villagers gave 99,000 suggestions to the local government. Ultimately, 78,000 of these were adopted indicating a high rate of governmental responsiveness. This movement is considered grassroots because it focuses on systematically empowering the people. This focus manifested itself in the democratic institutions that focused on engaging the poor and in reform efforts that sought to make the government more responsive to the will of the people. [12]
Another instance of a historical grassroots movement was the 1980s German peace movement. The movement traces its roots to the 1950s movement opposing nuclear armament or the "Ban the Bomb" Movement. In the 1980s, the movement became far bigger. In 1981, 800 organizations pushed the government to reduce the military size. The push culminated in a protest by 300,000 people in the German capital Bonn. The movement was successful in producing a grassroots organization, the Coordination Committee, which directed the efforts of the peace movements in the following years. The committee ultimately failed to decrease the size of the German military, but it laid the groundwork for protests of the Iraq war in the 2000s. Further, the movement started public dialogue about policy directed at peace and security. Like the Civil Rights Movement, the German Peace movement is considered grassroots because it focused on political change starting at the local level. [13]
A further example of grassroots in the 1980s was the Citizens Clearinghouse for Natural Waste, an organization that united communities and various grassroots groups in America in support of more environmentally friendly methods of dealing with natural waste. The movement focused especially on African American communities and other minorities. It sought to bring awareness to those communities and alter the focus from moving problematic waste to changing the system that produced such waste. The movement is considered grassroots because it utilized strategies that derived their power from the affected communities. For example, in North Carolina, African American communities lay down in front of dump trucks to protest their environmental impact. The success of these movements largely remains to be seen. [14]
Strategies of grassroots movements[edit]
Grassroots movements use tactics that build power from local and community movements. Grassroots Campaigns, a non-profit organization dedicated to creating and supporting grassroots movements in America says that grassroots movements aim to raise money, build organizations, raise awareness, build name recognition, to win campaigns and to deepen political participation. Grassroots movements work toward these and other goals via strategies focusing on local participation in either local or national politics. [15]
Grassroots organizations derive their power from the people, thus their strategies seek to engage ordinary people in political discourse to the greatest extent possible. Below is a list of strategies considered to be grassroots because of their focus on engaging the populace. [4]
Hosting house meetings or parties
Having larger meetings— AGMs
Putting up posters
Talking with pedestrians on the street or walking door-to-door (often involving informational clipboards)
Gathering signatures for petitions
Mobilizing letter-writing, phone-calling and emailing campaigns
Setting up information tables
Raising money from many small donors for political advertising or campaigns
Organizing large demonstrations
Asking individuals to submit opinions to media outlets and government officials
Holding get out the vote activities, which include the practices of reminding people to vote and transporting them to polling places.
Use of online social networks[edit]
Social media's prominence in political and social activism has skyrocketed in the last decade. Influencers on apps like Instagram and Twitter have all become hot spots for growing grassroots movements as platforms to inform, excite and organize.
Hashtags[edit]
Another influential way media is used to organize is through the use of hashtags to group together postings from across the network under a unifying message. Some hashtags that stirred up larger media coverage include the #MeToo movement, started in 2017 in response to sexual assault allegations against prominent figures in the American entertainment industry. Grassroots movements also use hashtags to organize on a large scale on social media. Some examples include:
BlackLivesMatter, this hashtag demonstrates how what starts as a media campaign can take footing to be a form of embodying an entire movement. [16]
LoveWins. After the Supreme Court of the United States ruled in favor of legalizing same-sex marriage, supporters used the hashtag #LoveWins.
Resist: This hashtag, used in cities throughout America, is another example of the power of organization through media platforms. It was used by event planning sites like Meetup.com to bring together members of a community who wanted to get involved politically. It was used in the case of #Resist:Dallas for such purposes.
Grassroots activism partnered with social media may be shaping the way in which citizens organize, engage and protest in an intensely digital age.
EnoughIsEnough: originating from survivors of the Parkland school shooting in Florida, U.S., this hashtag calls for political action to prevent shootings.
Examples[edit]
Barry Goldwater 1964 presidential campaign[edit]
Main article: Barry Goldwater 1964 presidential campaign
The junior senator from Arizona and standard-bearer of conservative Republicans, Barry Goldwater announced his candidacy on January 3, 1964. Goldwater focused on goals such as reducing the size of the federal government, lowering taxes, promoting free enterprise and a strong commitment to U.S. global leadership and fighting communism; which appealed strongly to conservatives in the Republican Party.
Despite vehement opposition from the leaders of his party's dominant moderate-liberal wing, such as New York governor Nelson Rockefeller and Michigan governor George Romney; Goldwater secured the Republican nomination. He sparked a grassroots movement among young conservatives by presenting himself as honest, committed and a genuine politician. The majority of his campaign donations were made by individual supporters; and only one-third of donations were greater than $500.
Bernie Sanders 2016 presidential campaign[edit]
Main article: Bernie Sanders 2016 presidential campaign
The junior United States senator and former Representative from Vermont, Bernie Sanders, formally announced his 2016 presidential campaign on May 26, 2015 on the foundation of reversing "obscene levels" of income and wealth inequality. [17] [18] Sanders stated that he would run an issue-oriented and positive campaign, focusing his efforts on getting corporate money out of politics, raising taxes on the wealthy, guaranteeing tuition-free higher education, incorporating a single-payer healthcare system, fighting against climate change and other key issues. [19] [20]
Sanders didn't have the resources to run a massive presidential campaign across the United States, so he utilized passionate[peacock prose] volunteer organizers across the nation to build the movement.[citation needed] Millions inspired by Sanders were able to elevate the campaign to challenge the Democratic front-runner, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, before ultimately losing. [21] Sanders used his grassroots campaign to receive more than 7 million individual contributions averaging $27, effectively breaking Barack Obama's previous individual contribution record in 2008. [22]
UK grassroots aid movement[edit]
In 2015 the refugee crisis became front-page news across the world. [23] Affected by images of the plight of refugees arriving and travelling across Europe, the grassroots aid movement (otherwise known as the people-to-people or people solidarity movement), consisting of thousands of private individuals with no prior NGO experience, began in earnest to self-organise and form groups taking aid to areas of displaced persons. [24] The first wave of early responders reached camps in Calais and Dunkirk in August 2015 [25] and joined forces with existing local charities supporting the inhabitants there. [24] Other volunteers journeyed to support refugees across the Balkans, Macedonia and the Greek islands. [26] Grassroots aid filled voids and saved lives by plugging gaps in the system between governments and existing charities. [27]
The Axis of Justice[edit]
The Axis of Justice (AofJ) is a not-for-profit group co-founded by Tom Morello and Serj Tankian. [28] Its intended purpose is to promote social justice by connecting musicians and music enthusiasts to progressive grassroots ideals. The group appears at music festivals; the most prominent being Lollapalooza in 2003. The Axis of Justice most regularly appears whenever the bands System of a Down or Audioslave are performing. The group also has a podcast on XM Satellite radio and KPFK (90.7 FM), a Pacifica Radio station in Los Angeles, California. The AofJ's mission is to connect local music fans to organizations, local and global, aimed at effectively working on issues like peace, human rights and economic justice within communities.
Criticism[edit]
Issues with horizontal movements[edit]
Grassroots movements are usually criticized because the recent rise in social media has resulted in leaderless and horizontal movements. Some argue that social movements without a clear hierarchy are far less effective and are more likely to die off. [29]
Astroturfing[edit]
Main article: Astroturfing
Astroturfing refers to political action that is meant to appear to be grassroots, that is spontaneous and local, but in fact comes from an outside organization, such as a corporation or think tank. [30] [31] It is named after AstroTurf, a brand of artificial grass .
An example of astroturfing was the ExxonMobil Corporation's push to disseminate false information about climate change. ExxonMobil was largely successful both in disseminating the information through think tanks and in disguising the true nature of the think tanks. [32]
More controversial examples of astroturfing often exhibit some characteristics of a real grassroots organization, but also characteristics of astroturf. Many of President Obama's efforts, for example, have been deemed grassroots because of their focus on involving the electorate at large. Critics of Obama have argued that some of these methods are in fact astroturfing because they believe that Obama faked the grassroots support. For example, the Reason Foundation has accused Obama of planting astroturf supporters in town hall meetings. Many movements and organizations must be placed on a continuum between grassroots and astroturf instead of labeled entirely as one or the other. For example, Australia's Convoy of No Confidence, a movement seeking to force an early election in 2011, incorporated elements of grassroots infrastructure in its reliance on the anger and discontentment of the participants. It also had elements of astroturf, namely the large extent to which it relied on support from political elites in the opposition party. [33]
The Tea Party, a conservative force in American politics that began in 2009, is also a controversial example of astroturfing. Critics, notably including Former President Barack Obama and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, dismissed the Tea Party as Astroturf. They say that the movement purports to represent large swaths of America when in reality it comes from a select few billionaires seeking policies favorable to themselves. The Tea Party has defended itself, arguing that it comes out of broad popular support and widespread anger at the Democratic Party and disenchantment with the GOP. Defenders of the Tea Party cite polls that find substantial support, indicating that the movement has some basis in grassroots politics. Critics point to the corporate influence on the Tea Party, which they believe indicates that the movement is more top-down than the grassroots rhetoric would suggest. The Tea Party can be considered grassroots to the extent that it comes from the people, but it is considered astroturfing to the extent that it is shaped by corporations and particularly wealthy individuals. [34]
Current examples[edit]
Earth Hour International - Created by WWF Australia and advertising agency Leo Burnett Sydney and Fairfax Media, has described itself as "the world's largest grass roots movement" [35]
Bernie Sanders presidential campaign, 2016: this has been deemed by some as a grassroots campaign because of its focus on small donations, massive rallies and other grassroots style politicking methods. [36]
Momentum in the United Kingdom: it has been described as a grassroots movement supportive of Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party.[37]
Use in sport - The term "grassroots" is used by a number of sporting organizational bodies to reference the lowest, most elementary form of the game that anyone can play. Focusing on the grassroots of a sporting code can lead to greater participation numbers, greater support of professional teams/athletes and ultimately provide performance and financial benefits to the organization to invest into the growth and development of the sport. [38] [39] Some examples of this are FIFA 's Grassroots Programme and the Football Federation Australia 's "Goals for Grassroots" initiative. [40] [41]

Communities: Definition, Motivations & Characteristics
Instructor: Amy C. Evans
Amy has a BA/MA Criminal Justice. Worked with youth for over 20 years in academic settings. Avid reader, history and mystery lover.
Communities are the subject of this lesson. We will go over the definition of what a community is and explore the motivations and characteristics of communities. Updated: 10/04/2020
What is a Community?
What is a community to you? Is it a group of living organisms that share an ecosystem? Is it the people you join in fellowship when you gather to share your faith tradition? Is it the neighborhood you live in? What about universities where people go to learn and teach and some live? Are they communities? If you answered yes, to all the above, you would be correct. Communities can be found in all kinds of incarnations around the world and you can have a role in more than one community.
A community is a place where people live, play, work, interact with one another in a number of ways. Communities are a source of identity and security where people interact with each other within a set of norms and rules that they create. These communities exist within a larger society and may also have smaller communities within them. In other words, communities can be layered one within the other.
For example, American society has urban communities (cities) that in turn have neighborhoods, that in turn have churches, social organizations, sports teams, etc... all of which are examples of communities. Let us explore what motivates humans to build communities and the characteristics that many have in common.

Motivation to Build Communities
What motivates humans to build communities? Well, there are a lot of reasons that gathering to live in a group makes sense. These reasons include, but are not exclusive too, the following:
Pooling of resources
Safety and security
Shared interests
Shared goals
Shared culture
Shared ethnicity
Freedom to practice or not practice a religion
Freedom to express one's personal thoughts and opinions
Characteristics of Communities
First of all, members of communities identify with one another in some way, they have enough things in common that make living together advantageous and while not all communities are the same, they do share some characteristics that can be generally applied.
Communities often occupy a specific space or locale, although some communities may have a more universal or worldwide reach.
Rules and laws are a characteristic of communities; they set boundaries and communicate what is and what is not acceptable behavior
Communities have active members who are invested in the success of their community and who can effectively communicate with one another.
Communities have some sort of administrative structure made up of members of the community who have the authority to tax, and fine members, as well as, offer up initiatives to be voted on that provide for community needs, such as mass transit, libraries, infrastructure, schools and hospitals.
Communities have shared values and understandings between their members on how to do things, such as socializing.
Members of communities share their resources amongst one another.
Communities have goals and societal roles meant to benefit the community, as well as individual members of the community.
Communities have institutions for enforcing rules, laws, norms and for the distribution of resources. For example, they have some sort of system for accountability, such as law enforcement and courts.
Examples of Historical Figures in Community Building
Communities do not just spring up unannounced. They oftentimes have people of vision, people who motivate the creation of a community. For example, John Winthrop dreamed of creating a community for Puritans fleeing religious persecution in England. He made this dream a reality called Boston, Massachusetts, in 1630, when he set sail with eleven ships for the shores of the New World.
James Madison, also referred to as the Father of the American Constitution, wrote the first ten amendments to the Constitution of the United States. The Constitution, was crucial in structuring the type of government the United States would have, including the institutions and their specific roles in the community and the rules and rights of citizens that belonged to the new nation.
In South Africa, former Black African Nelson Mandela helped transform his community and free it of apartheid where whites and blacks shared power and representation in the government and small communities, such as Cape Town and Johannesburg took down barriers that had long separated colored communities from white communities, creating a more equitable system and equal rights for all citizens, regardless of ethnicity.

What Are Characteristics of a Civilized Society?
By Staff Writer Last Updated April 07, 2020
Follow Us:
Modern civilized societies focus on education, safety and a high quality of life. Where these factors rank can change between societies. A strong middle class is another sign of a civilized society.
Agriculture is often credited with starting civilization. Agriculture allows one person to feed many, allowing other people to focus on other tasks. This job specialization has helped cultures develop writing, trade and other aspects of modern civilization, and it has allowed people to settle down in one location instead of having to live nomadic lifestyles.
Effective government is a cornerstone of civilized societies. Whether the government is a monarchy, democracy or dictatorship, a strong government is needed to enforce laws and keep people safe from foreign and domestic threats. Governments are also able to invest in infrastructure that citizens can use. Public-use roads, for example, typically require government approval and financing.
Education, science and art all play a role in civilized society, and these fields have been high priorities for thousands of years. An educated population tends to be less violent and happier, and art and entertainment help build cultural cohesion. Societies that invest in science are typically able to provide a better quality of life; modern medicine, for example, has led to longer lives.

Zachary P. Neal

Introduction
Community is a broad topic within sociology, the social sciences generally, and indeed even in the natural and physical sciences. This bibliography focuses primarily on human communities, and although many different definitions have been offered, most involve a few basic claims. First, a community is a group of people who interact with one another, for example, as friends or neighbors. Second, this interaction is typically viewed as occurring within a bounded geographic territory, such as a neighborhood or city. Third, the community’s members often share common values, beliefs, or behaviors. This bibliography includes sources for general overviews of community, journals publishing research on community, and entries organized under three major headings: Defining Community, Community Processes, and Finding Other Communities. Defining Community lists works that have attempted to define the concept of community, and to locate and characterize specific communities. Community Processes lists works that explore the wide range of social, political, and economic processes that take place within communities and that shape communities as they change over time. Finding Other Communities lists works that consider human communities that exist outside the mainstream, and that seek to explore community as a more abstract notion that goes beyond face-to-face human communities, including Internet-based virtual communities and communities of nonhuman entities, such as dolphins or protein molecules.
General Overviews
Because community is such a broad topic, no single work can provide a comprehensive overview of the concept. These works offer a general introduction and may serve as references sources that point to more specific aspects of community. Christensen and Levinson 2003 and Delanty 2010 provide broad and encyclopedic coverage of several aspects of community. Adopting a different approach, Neal 2013 introduces a social network approach to understanding community, and provides a general overview from this perspective.
Christensen, Karen, and David Levinson. 2003. Encyclopedia of community: From the village to the virtual world. Thousand Oaks, CA: SAGE.
This multivolume encyclopedia includes over five hundred entries on topics ranging from specific communities (e.g., Amana, Amish, Arcosanti) to the problems that contemporary communities face (e.g., vigilantism, xenophobia).

This textbook briefly summarizes several different conceptions of community, including urban communities, political communities, and virtual communities.

Neal adopts a network-based approach to thinking about urban communities, which are explored at multiple levels ranging from neighborhood communities of people to global communities of multinational corporations.

Abstract and Figures
Community participation should be an integral part of national development policy. This is more so following a major catastrophic event such as a natural disaster, or in the case of Iraq, a war. The conference held in July 2007 on rebuilding Iraqi communities identified community participation as a significant factor in national reconstruction: 

The central objective of the conference is to provide an intellectual forum for scholars and practitioners from Iraq and everywhere else in the world, to explore how the reconstruction of Iraq can be carried out in a way that promotes social justice, economic and political sustainability, and the full participation of all stakeholders (Awotona 2007).

The U.S. has a long history of community participation in national development, and some of the lessons learned from this experience could be applicable to Iraq as the country contemplates reconstruction efforts to amend a shattered nation after the war.
For development practitioners such as urban planners, community participation in development has long been recognized as essential for ensuring that development plans reflect the needs and wishes of a country’s residents. As Burby (2003) observed: 

Strong plans stem from planning processes that involve a broad array of stakeholders, and strong plans accompanied by broad stakeholder involvement are needed if plans are to have a significant effect on the actions of local governments.”(p. 33).

Mileti (1999) put it even more forcefully when he said: “The participatory process itself may be as important as the outcome” (p. 6). Finding ways to effectively involve the public in development planning has been a well beaten path of planners.1 Brody et al. (2003) lists the benefits of participation as generating “trust, credibility, and commitment regarding the implementation of policies….” (p. 246).

Abstract
An overview of participatory community-based decision systems in Japan is presented. In this disaster-prone country, effective community coping capacity has developed, largely to fill community-level needs for disaster preparation, mitigation, and response. Experience with three concepts of disaster planning and management, namely “Kyojo” (Neighborhood or Community Self-Reliance), “Jijo” (Individual or Household Self-Reliance), and “Kojo” (Government Assistance), is recounted and assessed. Then three structures for disaster management, Jiishu-bosai-soshiki (Self-support Disaster Reduction Association), “Machizukuri” (citizen-led town-creation), and “Toshikeikaku” (urban or city planning), are discussed. Finally, the contributions of the three papers in this special issue are related to Japanese community practices and to the broader perspective of group decision and negotiation.

Abstract
Yogyakarta Special Province’s vulnerability to natural disasters necessitates effective disaster risk reduction strategies, while climate change exacerbates exposure to weather-related disasters. This chapter focuses on improving disaster risk reduction efforts aimed at building community resilience through an investigation of the influencing factors in the Stop Disaster Game for disaster management and disaster preparedness. Based on previous research into the use of such a game by at-risk communities in Yogyakarta, the chapter further aims to develop an empirical model of the decision-making process and raise awareness of the community’s vulnerability to natural hazards, and to enhance effective collaboration amongst relevant stakeholders. For this research, a descriptive-qualitative method was used and an online survey was conducted with 202 respondents. The results from the survey were analysed using the Partial Least Square Structural Equation Model (PLS-SEM) to create an empirical model of decision-making processes based on the level of awareness of disaster risks and disaster management. The research found that the stronger the capacity of the at-risk community in understanding risk and to respond to disaster, the greater their willingness to contribute to and collaborate in the decision-making process for disaster risk reduction in Yogyakarta. This highlights the need to improve the community’s capacity and literacy regarding disaster risk, disaster preparedness, and disaster risk reduction. The gamification, in this context, is a potential strategy to facilitate the integration of community participation in disaster risk reduction and climate change adaptation planning.

(PDF) Decision-Making, Policy Choices and Community Rebuilding after the Tohoku Disaster
Decision-Making, Policy Choices and Community Rebuilding after the Tohoku Disaster
Authors:
Junko Mochizuki
International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis
Abstract and Figures
The long-term reconstruction following the 2011 tsunami disaster has required extensive deliberation at all levels of government that is now redefining and redrawing the future of the region. Based on semi-structured interviews conducted with municipal government officials and community leaders in the cities of Miyako and Kesennuma in January 2013, this study identifies the ways in which local communities have defined, prioritized and adopted a set of objectives and measures for long-term reconstruction, and how these will likely affect the disaster risk and community rebuilding in the coming years. Particular attention is paid to the debate surrounding tsunami defense measures, including the rebuilding of sea walls, the relocation of communities, and other land-use adjustments, and how multi-layered governance plays out in balancing the need for swift recovery, optimal resource allocation, and future disaster risk reduction. Since the 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake, the national recovery policy has stressed the need to build 'tsunami-resilient' communities, envisioning the construction of multi-buffer tsunami defense systems characterized by coastal land-use restrictions based on nationally determined guidelines of relatively frequent to extreme rare tsunamis. While this hands-on approach by the national government has contributed to streamlining the reconstruction processes, limited opportunities for citizen participation have contributed to tensions among stakeholders, calling into question the community ownership of decision-making following a disaster.

Based on the search results, I can provide a comprehensive overview of the environmental and health impacts of e-waste, recycling benefits, and practical solutions.

## Environmental and Health Risks of E-Waste

### Toxic Contamination
E-waste contains numerous hazardous substances that pose serious risks when improperly managed [1]. These include:

- **Heavy metals**: Lead, mercury, cadmium, chromium, and arsenic that can leach into soil and groundwater
- **Organic pollutants**: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and brominated flame retardants
- **Secondary toxicants**: Dioxins and furans produced during improper recycling processes

### Health Consequences
Research shows significant health impacts on workers and communities near informal e-waste recycling sites [1]:

- **Children are particularly vulnerable**, showing reduced lung function, lower birth weights, and cognitive impairments
- **Workers face increased risks** of respiratory problems, DNA damage, and exposure to carcinogens
- **Thyroid dysfunction** and immune system disruption from exposure to flame retardants

### Global Scale
The problem is massive and growing: global e-waste generation reached 53.6 million tons in 2019 and is projected to hit 74.7 million tons by 2030, with only 17.4% being formally recycled [1].

## Benefits of Proper Recycling

### Environmental Protection
Proper recycling provides multiple environmental benefits [2]:

- **Conserves natural resources** by recovering valuable materials like gold, silver, copper, and rare earth elements
- **Reduces greenhouse gas emissions** and energy consumption compared to virgin material extraction
- **Prevents toxic contamination** of soil, water, and air by keeping hazardous materials out of landfills

### Economic Advantages
The economic value is substantial [1][2]:

- E-waste contains approximately $57 billion worth of raw materials annually
- **Job creation**: Proper recycling creates employment opportunities in collection, processing, and refurbishment
- **Lower manufacturing costs**: Recycled materials are often cheaper than virgin resources, leading to lower consumer prices

## Recent Recycling Innovations

### Advanced Technologies
Several breakthrough technologies are transforming recycling [4][5]:

**Robotic Sorting**: AI-powered robotic arms can recognize and sort different materials automatically, improving efficiency and reducing contamination.

**Apple's Daisy System**: Processes over 200 iPhones per hour, recovering precious metals with high precision [4].

**Nuclear Waste Recycling**: University of Bristol researchers have developed methods to transform nuclear waste into long-lasting batteries [4].

### Plastic Recycling Breakthroughs
- **PureCycle Technology**: Removes contaminants from polypropylene to create virgin-quality recycled plastic [5]
- **Pyrowave Process**: Breaks down non-recyclable plastics into monomers for creating new resins [4]

### Smart Systems
**Internet of Things (IoT)**: Sensor-equipped bins optimize collection routes and track recycling performance [5].

**RFID Technology**: Embedded chips provide specific recycling instructions for individual products, potentially replacing ineffective recycling symbols [5].

## Practical Steps for Responsible Waste Management

### For Individuals
Based on best practices outlined in the search results [2][3]:

**Do's:**
- Use authorized e-waste recyclers only
- Keep non-functional electronics isolated to prevent damage
- Donate working electronics for reuse
- Learn local recycling guidelines through municipal programs

**Don'ts:**
- Never attempt to dismantle electronics yourself
- Avoid selling to unauthorized dealers or scrap collectors
- Don't mix e-waste with household garbage
- Don't store replaced parts in exposed areas

### For Businesses
Companies should implement comprehensive e-waste management strategies [3]:

**Extended Producer Responsibility**: Manufacturers should take responsibility for product lifecycle management, including end-of-life recycling.

**Sustainable Design**: Create products that are easier to disassemble and repair, using fewer hazardous materials.

**Employee Training**: Ensure all staff handling e-waste are properly qualified and trained on safety protocols.

### Policy and Infrastructure Solutions

**Formal-Informal Partnerships**: Successful models link informal waste collectors with formal processing facilities, providing safer working conditions while maintaining cost-effectiveness [1].

**Regulatory Frameworks**: Strong legislation like the Basel Convention helps control transboundary movement of hazardous waste and promotes environmentally sound management.

## The Path Forward

The transition to sustainable waste management requires coordinated action across multiple levels. While technological innovations offer promising solutions, success depends on:

1. **Consumer awareness** and participation in proper disposal programs
2. **Industry commitment** to sustainable design and take-back programs  
3. **Government policies** that support formal recycling infrastructure
4. **International cooperation** to prevent waste dumping in developing countries

The goal is creating a circular economy where materials remain in use as long as possible, minimizing waste generation while maximizing resource recovery [1]. With proper implementation of these strategies, we can significantly reduce the environmental and health impacts of our electronic consumption while building more sustainable and economically viable waste management systems.

E-waste management: A review of recycling process, environmental and occupational health hazards, and potential solutions - ScienceDirect

E-waste management: A review of recycling process, environmental and occupational health hazards, and potential solutions
Rajesh Ahirwar a Amit K. Tripathi b
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.enmm.2020.100409 Get rights and content
•
An overview of the global e-waste generation and management is presented.
•
Opportunities and constraints in e-waste management via recycling are discussed.
•
Environmental and public health concerns due to unsafe recycling practices are discussed.
•
Strategies to make e-waste recycling efficient and safer are suggested.
1. Introduction
Electrical and electronic equipment (EEE) such as cell phones, computers, video recorders, televisions, coffee machines, refrigerators and medical devices that add ease, comfort, and luxury to the modern life have become an indispensable part of modern societies. However, short lifespan, limited repair options and fast-changing technology is turning a high proportion of electronic gadgets into waste upon the end of its usable life due to damage, non-working, operational risks, or availability of better alternatives (Montalvo et al., 2016 ). Waste EEE (e-waste), mostly defined as “electrical or electronic equipment which is waste including all components, sub-assemblies and consumables, which are part of the product at the time of discarding” (Directive, 2008) have emerged both as a global concern due to its massively high volume and health hazards associated with its improper handling, disposal, or recycling (Forti et al., 2020; Grant et al., 2013; Widmer et al., 2005 ), as well as an opportunity due to high content of extractable valuable materials. Recent reports on global e-waste statistics have estimated global generation of 53.6 million ton (Mt) e-waste during 2019 that grew from 41.8 Mt in 2014 and 44.7 Mt in 2016 with further projection to grow to 74.7 Mt by 2030 at an annual growth rate of approx. 2 Mt (Balde et al., 2017, 2015; Forti et al., 2020 ).
E-waste generated at the household level in most of the countries is managed in three ways: (i) by dumping it to waste bins, (ii) through formal collection by government recognized bodies, and (iii) collection outside the formal system by individual waste dealers and companies (Chi et al., 2014 ). E-waste collected through authorized commercial and/or municipal collection points and pick-up services is usually recycled at facilities having advanced technology and machinery and infrastructure for safe and efficient removal of valuable materials (formal recycling). On the other hand, the e-waste collected outside the formal system by individual waste companies or dealers is mostly processed and recycled under sub-optimal conditions with primitive techniques and usually without any provisions to reduce the emission of hazardous chemicals into the environment (informal recycling) (Chi et al., 2011; Pradhan and Kumar, 2014 ). E-waste dumped into landfills or sold to peddlers often end up by polluting the environment through leaching into soil and groundwater, and via emission into the surrounding air, soil, and surface water (Cesaro et al., 2019; Man et al., 2013 ). A substantial amount of valuable resources are also lost through disposing or during recycling under inferior conditions. Thus, formal e-waste recycling is the safest way to manage e-waste. However, recent estimates suggest that only about 17.4 % (9.3 Mt) of the global e-waste generated in 2019 has been collected and recycled in the formal sector, leaving the flow of rest 44.3 Mt (82.6 %) e-waste undocumented (Forti et al., 2020 ). This suggests that most of the e-waste, particularly in Asian and African countries is managed by the informal sector. Presence of multiple precious metals (e.g. gold, platinum, palladium, ruthenium, rhodium, iridium, copper, and silver) along with other valuable materials such as iron, aluminium, cobalt, indium, germanium, bismuth, and antimony, make e-waste an attractive source of economy among local scrap dealers, dismantlers and recyclers (Deubzer et al., 2019 ). Toxic substances present in EEE (e.g. heavy metals, brominated flame retardants, and polychlorinated biphenyls), or those produced during recycling activities (e.g. polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and polychlorinated dibenzofurans), and used for extracting metals (e.g. acids like HCl, H 2 SO 4, HNO 3, HClO 4, NaClO) are often emitted in the local environment as primary, secondary and tertiary emissions, respectively from informal recycling, leading to an increase in the levels of toxic pollutants in the ecosystem (Kumar et al., 2019; Orlins and Guan, 2016; Quan et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2015 ). Long term recycling activities in the informal sector compounded with long term persistence of e-waste pollutant in the environment increases the exposure risk to the waste recycling workers and the population inhabiting nearby localities and thus is a health hazard (Grant et al., 2013 ).
To establish a balance between the negative impact of e-waste recycling on the environment and human health, and resource reimbursement (financial), a multi-directional approach is required to holistically solve the e-waste menace while also assisting the global economy and resource conservation. Numerous reviews on one or the other aspects of e-waste generation and its recycling: global e-waste generation and management (Awasthi and Li, 2017; Kumar et al., 2017 ), e-waste recycling process and methods (Islam et al., 2020 ), regulation and legislation (Kumar and Singh, 2013 ), role in the circular economy (Pini et al., 2019 ), impact on the environment and human health (Awasthi et al., 2016; Grant et al., 2013; Vaccari et al., 2019 ), and sustainable management (Ravindra and Mor, 2019) have been published. However, very few of them provide a holistic picture covering most of the aspects of e-waste generation and recycling including the environmental and occupational health concern, economic and legal issues and strategies to address such issues.
This review provides a comprehensive account of the current trend in global e-waste generation, the latest approaches in e-waste recycling, environmental and occupational health concerns, opportunities and constraints in effective e-waste management, and solutions for improved e-waste recycling. Besides, we have also discussed the mechanism of toxicity of a few of the prominent pollutants associated with e-waste generation and recycling. Further, key regulations and legislative framework on e-waste management among countries generating major amount of e-waste were provided. Moreover, we have also commented on the potential strategies for improved and effective e-waste management.
2. Current status on global e-waste generation
The rate of generation of e-waste at the global level has increased substantively in recent years. While previous estimates suggested an annual growth rate of 3–4 % (ASSOCHAM-NEC, 2018; Balde et al., 2017, 2015 ), by the year 2019, the growth rate of global e-waste generation has increased to around 6% (Forti et al., 2020 ). The global e-waste generated in 2019 is estimated comprising 17.4 Mt small equipment, 13.1 Mt large equipment, 10.8 Mt temperature exchange equipment, 6.7 Mt screens and monitors, 4.7 Mt small IT and telecommunication equipment, and 0.9 Mt lamps (Forti et al., 2020 ). Detailed quantities of e-waste generated by individual countries in the year 2019, as well as detailed classification of EEE under above mentioned six major subheads are provided in the ‘Global E-waste Monitor 2020’ report (Forti et al., 2020 ). The continent-wise figures of e-waste generated during 2014–2019, and countries which generated the highest e-waste within each continent in 2019 are shown in Fig. 1. It is worth noting here that in each successive year, both total e-waste as well as per capita generation of e-waste has increased among all the continents .

Asia with its 17 countries contributed the highest share of e-waste in 2019. China, India, Japan, and Indonesia generated most of the e-waste among Asian countries. Many nations in Asia are covered by nation-based e-waste legislation which prohibit trans-boundary movement of e-waste, and mandate formal collection of generated e-waste for recycling at government-recognized setups with appropriate technology (Table 1 ). For a comprehensive analysis of e-waste legislation worldwide, the recent article by Patil et al. and other may be referred (Patil and Ramakrishna, 2020; Kumar et al., 2017; Pathak et al., 2017; Patil and Ramakrishna, 2020; Wei and Liu, 2012; Zeng et al., 2013) Despite various policies on e-waste management in many Asian nations, only a marginal increase in e-waste recycling at formal setups has taken place and has not kept pace with the unmatched increase in total e-waste generation . Limited coverage of EEE under e-waste management rules, lack of effective enforcement of regional and international e-waste legislation and treaties, and unprofessional standards of e-waste disposal, collection, and recycling are believed to be contributing to persisting informal recycling under sub-optimal conditions in Asian countries (Balde et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2017; Wei and Liu, 2012 ).

Europe and Americas recorded the next highest global e-waste generation after Asian countries . North and South America have been estimated to have generated approximately 11−13 Mt e-waste annually in the past six years, with per capita contribution of approximately 12−13 kg/inhabitant per year. While European nations too maintained their total e-waste generation to around 12 Mt in the last six years; they recorded a substantial decrease in per capita generation of e-waste because of their stringent e-waste management practices. Also, the average e-waste collection and recycling through the formal system in Europe was comparatively higher (5.1 Mt) than the Americas (1.2 Mt). Most of the European nations (as part of the European Union) are covered by the EU directives to follow regulations on transparent and systematic management of generated e-waste, whereas only a few countries like the USA and Canada in the Americas have provincial laws to manage e-waste (Wang et al., 2016 ).
Africa and Oceania were reported to generate the least amount of e-waste in the past six years. The highest quantities of e-waste among 49 African nations analyzed for their share of e-waste was recorded from Egypt (585 kilo ton), South Africa (415 kt), Nigeria (461 kt) and Algeria (308 kt). E-waste management in Africa is still dominated by the informal sector due to the lack of either specific e-waste legislation or their implementation. In Oceania (among 12 countries analyzed for e-waste generation), Australia and New Zealand (650 kilo ton; 21.3 kg/capita) recorded generating the most of the e-waste. Most of the African and Oceanian countries either do not have e-waste management laws or schemes to solve the e-waste problem and deal with the informal recycling. However, Australia (Oceania) has enacted the National Television and Computer Recycling Scheme (2011) to increase the rate of recycling of televisions and computers to 80 % by 2026–2027 through industry-based collection and recycling initiatives (EPHC, 2010 ). Also, the dumping of e-waste in landfills is banned in Australia to encourage safe management of hazardous materials and increase recovery of the valuable materials.
3. Exposure to pollutants associated with e-waste: mechanism of toxicity and environmental and occupational health concerns
E-waste recycling without appropriate measures to limit environmental pollution can add a variety of organic and inorganic pollutants such as heavy metals, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), brominated flame retardants (BFRs), perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs), polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins (PCDDs) and polychlorinated dibenzofurans (PCDFs) into the ecosystem which can adversely affect human health. This section discusses exposure to e-waste toxicants and mechanisms of their toxicity. Epidemiological findings highlighting health consequences in e-waste workers and population inhabiting nearby localities to sites of e-waste recycling (mostly in the informal settings) are also provided.
3.1. Exposure to e-waste pollutants
The toxic components contained in e-waste depend on the type of EEE. Besides, the emission of toxic components and their derivatives into environment is dependent of the method used for processing and recycling. Various metals and organic compounds are added to the EEE in trace quantities for various purposes, such as to impart mechanical support and strength, enhance electrical and thermal conductance, resistance to flame and weathering conditions, and other added benefits (Table S3). Being embedded in EEE, these components impose minimal adverse effects on human health when the EEE is intact. However, upon emission into the environment through recycling activities, such as dismantling, size reduction, and burning or heating these get released into the environment.
Presence of various primary e-waste toxicants (hazardous substances present in e-waste, e.g. Pb, Cd, Hg and PCBs) and secondary e-waste toxicants (produced during processing and recycling of e-waste, e.g. PAHs, dioxins and difurans) in the environment of the Guiyu town of China, Agbogbloshie of Ghana, National Capital Territory (NCT) region in India, Shershah (Karachi) in Pakistan, Lagos in Nigeria, and Dhaka in Bangladesh (all well-known e-waste dump yards) has been widely reported (RajyaSabha, 2011; Sthiannopkao and Wong, 2013 ). For instance, Seelampur and Mandoli industrial area in Delhi, India have been reported for contamination of drains and surface soil from discarded acid wastes that carry unrecovered metals like Sb, Cu, Pb, Ni, Sn, Zn, As and Se (Brigden et al., 2005; Pradhan and Kumar, 2014 ). Similarly, high concentrations of polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) and tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) have been detected in the indoor dust from TV dismantling workshops in east China and Vietnam (Anh et al., 2017; Deng et al., 2014a; Wang et al., 2010b ). Presence of PBDE, particularly the BDE-47 and BDE-99, and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) has been found in soil sediments of Dayan River near an electronic waste site in Qingyuan (Zheng et al., 2015 ). Bioaccumulation of PBDEs, especially the BDE-209 has been found in fishes collected from ponds near to e-waste recycling localities in Vietnam (Anh et al., 2017 ). Various low and high molecular weight PAHs such as phenanthrene, anthracene, fluoranthene, pyrene, and benzo(a)anthracene, chrysene and dibenzo(a,h)anthracene have been reported in soil and vegetations near recycling or dumping sites in South China and Nigeria (Adeyi and Oyeleke, 2017; Wang et al., 2012 ). Multiple studies evidenced the presence of heavy metals and persistent organic pollutants at informal e-waste recycling sites coming mainly from crude processing, such as open burning and discharge of acid bath effluents into soil, water and other habitats (Awasthi et al., 2016; Vaccari et al., 2019 ).
Exposure to toxic e-waste components may result from inhalation, ingestion or upon dermal contact at workplace (occupational) or through contaminated air, water, soil and food items. Workers engaged in recycling activities, elderly people, children, and pregnant women residing near e-waste recycling units are highly susceptible to adverse health effects of e-waste toxicants (Chimere May et al., 2018; Ohajinwa et al., 2019 ). Particularly, children and infants, owing to the possibility of in utero exposure, intense hand-to-mouth activity, high rate of breathing, frequent breast-feeding and food intake, and low rate of toxicant removal are considered the most vulnerable group for e-waste exposure (Guo et al., 2010, 2012; Xu et al., 2018, 2012 ).
3.2. Mechanism of e-waste toxicity
While many of the environmental pollutants including those generated during e-waste recycling may have different mechanisms through which they can affect various body systems, their co-existence in the environment and simultaneous exposure to different magnitudes of dose, duration and routes make it extremely challenging to delineate their exact roles in various health conditions among exposed population. These challenges notwithstanding, significant progress has been made to uncover the possible mechanism of toxic effects of various e-waste toxicants.
3.2.1. Molecular mechanism of heavy metals toxicity
Cellular exposure to heavy metals is known to increase reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and deplete antioxidants. Multiple studies have indicated that redox active metal ions, such as Fe(II), Cu(II), Cr(VI), or As(III) upon getting oxidized by the by-products of aerobic respiration (e.g. hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2) and superoxide (O 2 − )) can initiate autoxidation driven by Fenton reaction, leading to production of highly reactive hydroxyl radical (OH) and hydroxide (OH −) (Flora et al., 2008; Thomas et al., 2009; Xu et al., 2017 ). These reactive oxygen species (ROS) can form additional free radicals such as thiyl radical (RS ), carbon-centred radical ((R) 3 C) and peroxyl radical ((R) 3 COO) upon reacting with other cellular biomolecules and may damage cellular proteins, lipids, DNA and polysaccharides among other cellular machineries (Fig. 2) (Godwill et al., 2019; Lemire et al., 2013; Li et al., 2013 ).

Exposure to heavy metals result in generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which may lead to depletion of antioxidants, alteration of enzyme and protein function, damage to the cell membrane, interference in the activity of transporters and genotoxicity.
Metal catalyzed oxidation of amino acid residues, such as histidine, arginine, lysine and proline adjacent to metal binding sites in proteins (form carbonyl derivatives) may result in loss of enzyme activity as well as protein dysfunction and degradation (Stadtman, 1993 ). Similarly, exchange of catalytic metals or structural metals, for example, displacement of metallic cofactor Zn(II) by Pb(II) from catalytic site of heme synthesizing enzyme δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (Jaffe et al., 2001 ), and substitutions of Ni(II) for cofactor Zn(II) at non-catalytic site of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (an enzyme involved in glycolysis) (Macomber et al., 2011 ), and destruction of catalytic Fe–S clusters (2Fe – 2S; 3Fe – 3S; 4Fe – 4S) in proteins involved in electron transfer, enzymatic reactions, and RNA and DNA metabolism, can potentially lead to site-specific enzyme inhibition (Vernis et al., 2017; Xu and Imlay, 2012 ). Moreover, these metals can form disulphide bonds with sulphur atom in amino-acid residues in glutathione, L-cysteine, NAD(P)H and FADH 2 due to their electron-sharing affinities, thus depleting the anti-oxidant reserves of the cell (Lemire et al., 2013 ). Oxidative breakdown of lipids, particularly at the methylene bridges (-CH 2 -) in polyunsaturated fatty acids or glycolipids by, for example Cu(II) and Cd(II) catalysed ROS can result in loss of membrane potential and integrity leading to impaired membrane function (Flora et al., 2008 ). Both oxidative stress mediated damage and inactivation of key proteins involved in DNA synthesis and repair are known as causative factors for metal-associated genotoxicity. Free radicals such as OH can react to nucleobases or 2-deoxyribose moiety resulting in DNA damage such as base lesions, 8-hydroxy-2-deoxyguanosine, and formation of inter-strand and intra-strand base cross-links, and DNA–protein cross-links (Cadet and Wagner, 2013 ). Inhibition of mismatch repair protein by metal ions or its effectors can result in propagation of unrepaired errors which may lead to mutations and cellular apoptosis (Jin et al., 2003 ). Also, some heavy metals such as Cr(VI) or Ga(III) are known to starve the cells of essential micronutrients, e.g. sulphate and Fe by interfering in their uptake through various mechanism (Lemire et al., 2013 ). Exposure to heavy metals has also been shown to result in neurological and behavioural disorders, diseases of nervous, respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, reproductive, and immune systems, and cancers of the bladder and lungs (Jarup, 2003; Rebelo and Caldas, 2016; Rehman et al., 2018; Song and Li, 2015 ).
3.2.2. Molecular mechanism of PAH and dioxins toxicity
PAHs and dioxins are produced as by-products during combustion of e-waste components. PAHs are lipophilic in nature, and enter pulmonary cells via passive diffusion upon inhalation or ingestion. They activate cytochrome P450 (CYP) monooxygenases, like CYP1A1/2 and CYP1B1, and cellular enzymes such as glutathione S-transferases, UDP glucuronyl transferases, NADPH quinone oxidoreductases (NQOs), aldo-keto reductases (AKRs), and epoxide hydrolases (EHs) through aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR)-dependent and AhR-independent pathways including mainly the CYP1A1/1B1 and epoxide hydrolase pathway (CYP/EH), CYP peroxidase pathway (CYPP), and aldo-keto reductases pathway (AKR) (Moorthy et al., 2015 ). During this process, the PAHs are transformed to its active carcinogenic metabolites like diol-epoxides, radical cations, and reactive and redox-active o-quinones which may react with DNA to produce DNA adducts that can lead to DNA mutation, abnormal gene expression, and tumorigenesis (Fig. 3) (Moorthy et al., 2015 ). The toxicity due to PAH exposure is further enhanced by the metabolic processes which generate reactive metabolites such as epoxides and dihydrodiols (Burchiel and Luster, 2001; Moorthy et al., 2015 ). Such metabolites cause DNA adduct formation and may lead to mutations apart from protein adduct formation (Burchiel and Luster, 2001 ). Besides, exposure to PAHs has been found to cause oxidative stress leading to oxidative damage to DNA, oxidation of proteins, lipid peroxidation and membrane damage (Deng et al., 2014b ). Chronic exposure to PAHs, in ecological settings, has been found to be associated with reduction in immune function, liver and kidney damage, retarded lung function and enhanced risk of cancers of various organs viz. lung, skin, bladder, and gastro-intestine (Armstrong et al., 2004; Bostrom et al., 2002; Burchiel and Luster, 2001; Kim et al., 2013 ).

Toxic effects of the dioxins appear to be mediated via genomic and non-genomic pathways by binding to the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR). Dioxins entering the cells via diffusion can bind the cytosolic AhR complexed to chaperone proteins Hsp90-p23-XAP2 (heat shock protein 90, prostaglandin E synthase 3, and the immunophilin-like protein – hepatitis B virus X-associated protein 2) leading to dissociation and translocation of AhR-dioxin complex into the nucleus where it recruits AhR nuclear translocator, transcriptional proteins, co-activators and co-repressors to bind the promoter regions (xenobiotics response elements) of target genes to exhibit altered expressions (Fig. 3) (Beischlag and Perdew, 2005; Beischlag et al., 2004; Petrulis and Perdew, 2002 ). The rapid effects of dioxins, such as TCDD-induced inflammation appear to stem from its non-genomic action involving ligand activated AhR causing rapid rise in intracellular Ca 2+ and activating protein kinases and phosphatases, for example epidermal growth factor receptor (Matsumura, 2009 ). Besides, hijacking of AhR by dioxins disrupts the endogenous functions such as regulation of cell-cycle, hematopoietic cell populations, tumour suppression, aging, hypoxia, and circadian rhythms (Carlson and Perdew, 2002; Marlowe and Puga, 2005; Singh et al., 2009 ). Chronic exposure to dioxins has also been shown to cause reproductive toxicity (interfere with hormonal signalling, anti-estrogenic effects, vitamin A inhibition, thyroxin mimicry), neurotoxicity (endocrine-disrupting actions, neural-disrupting action), immunotoxicity (immune-suppression, promotes inflammatory responses), tumorigenesis promotion etc. (Kogevinas, 2001; Marshall and Kerkvliet, 2010 ).
3.3. Health consequences of e-waste exposure
The health impact of e-waste exposure on humans has been mainly assessed through evaluating exposure and effect biomarkers, and analysis of morbidity pattern among exposed and control populations. A comprehensive account of the health implications of exposure to various toxicants associated with e-waste recycling has been provided by Grant et al. in a systematic review (Grant et al., 2013 ). Through assessing levels of e-waste pollutants and their derivatives in serum, blood, cord-blood, placenta, meconium etc., it has been suggested that exposure to e-waste toxicants may affect thyroid function (as evident by altered levels of serum thyroid stimulating hormone, tri-iodothyronine and tetra-iodothyronine in the exposed group), cause genotoxicity (higher DNA damage, increased micronuclei frequency and chromosomal aberrations), alter cellular expression and function (altered expression levels of metallothionein, S100 P and S110 P proteins), neonatal outcomes (low birth-weight, birth-length, gestational age, Apgar score and body-mass index), physical growth and cognitive functions (low weight, height, body-mass index and intelligence quotient), temperament and behaviour (behavioural neurological assessment score and temperament score), and lung function (low forced vital capacity) (Table 2 ).

4. E-waste recycling methods
In the modern era of rapid technological advances, a large amount of e-waste has been accumulated from the increased production of EEE that turn to e-waste upon the end of its useful life. Effective strategies are required both at production stage and after-use for environmentally sound management of the e-waste. Recycling is a valuable tool to control the rising heaps of e-waste; however, sub-optimal practices of recycling are contributing to increase in the levels of toxic pollutants in the ecosystem. The current global trend in e-waste management (informal processing of 82.6 % of global e-waste in 2019) has become unsustainable, and requires multifaceted approach for a holistic solution. Better understanding of e-waste collection and recycling process is an important link in this direction. This section discusses in brief the formal methods of e-waste collection and processes for recovery of valuable metals from e-waste.
E-waste recycling comprises (i) collection of e-waste, (ii) its processing, and (iii) recovery of valuable materials (Meskers et al., 2009 ). Collection and consolidation of the obsolete EEE is an important step that requires both public awareness as well as establishments in form of regulatory agreements, government policies and accessible collection facilities to facilitate efficient collection of household or institutional e-waste. Under formal collection, the e-waste is collected by government authorized organizations, and/or producers via municipal collection points, pick-up services, and retailers. Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) norm, a take-back initiative put in place by various nations places the responsibility on the original equipment manufacturers to collect certain fraction of their sales.
Enrichment of valuable metals through removal of non-essential and non-recyclable fractions is the next step in recycling e-waste. It involves dismantling of the EEE to collect individual components. An e-waste, depending upon the type, manufacturer and the age of the equipment carries varying quantity of ferrous components (e.g. iron, steel), non-ferrous metals (e.g. silver, gold, copper, aluminium, platinum), plastics, glass, wood, rubber and other materials. These components are sorted to different batches of metals, plastics, ceramics, paper, wood and categories like capacitors, batteries, LCDs, PCBs to shred them into further small pieces (e.g. 0.177 mm to 5 cm) using mechanical processes (Cui and Forssberg, 2003 ). Industrial scale granulation machines are used for these purposes (Fig. 4 ). The processed e-waste is enriched for recovery by finally separating them into metallic and non-metallic fractions using magnetic, current-based, or density separation techniques (Li et al., 2007; Zhang and Forssberg, 1997 ).The plastic part of e-waste is mostly recycled as energy source, and to convert into plastic bottles.

Metals from the processed e-waste are recovered using hydrometallurgical and pyrometallurgical methods. The hydrometallurgical methods of metal recovery from e-waste use solvent extraction, leaching, adsorption and ion exchange processes for selective dissolution of precious metals, and recovery through electro refining or chemical reduction process (Ritcey, 2006; Sadegh Safarzadeh et al., 2007 ). Various mineral acids and oxidants including aqua-regia (3HCl:HNO 3 ), HCl, H 2 SO 4, HNO 3 /H 2 O 2, HClO 4, NaClO and lixiviants including cyanide, thiosulfate, thiourea and halide have been used for the recovery of pure base and precious metals from e-waste (Ding et al., 2019; Islam et al., 2020 ). Hydrometallurgical processes use toxic, highly acidic/alkaline, or flammable reagents and also generate voluminous solid wastes and effluents. Hydrometallurgy require off-gas treatment as the halogenated flame retardants used in printed circuit boards forms toxic dioxin, furans and volatile metals (Hageluken, 2006 ). However, it is not possible to achieve simultaneously both the inexpensive extraction and minimal emission of toxic components into the environment along with high extraction efficiency, and recyclability using any single process. Methods such as landfilling and incineration are used for treatment of effluent and other dangerous waste to minimize environmental contamination from disposed waste.
Pyrometallurgical methods of metal reclamation from e-waste involves thermal treatment of e-waste through conflagration, smelting in furnaces or alkali chemicals, drossing, sintering, plasma melting and other solid-liquid-gas reactions at high temperature for recovery of valuable metals (Antrekowitsch et al., 2006; Cui and Zhang, 2008; Ding et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019 ). Majority of e-waste recycling especially for Pb, Cu, and precious metals at industrial scale is performed using pyrometallurgic methods in Cu and Pb smelters (Antrekowitsch et al., 2006 ). These methods rely on chemical and metallurgic proportion of metals to segregate them pinto solvent metal phase (molten bath) for partial or full recovery through subsequent hydrometallurgical, electrochemical techniques. Mostly, copper smelters are used for these purposes. Separated precious metals as anode slimes are recovered through electro- or hydro-metallurgical process. Non-recyclable materials like plastics are used as energy sources (Cui and Zhang, 2008; van Schaik and Reuter, 2014 ). Pyrometallurgy methods are often used for initial segregation and upgrading of precious metals into base metals followed by hydrometallurgical and electrometallurgical process for the recovery of pure base and precious metals. For example, recovery of platinum group metals [e.g., Ruthenium (Ru), Rhodium (Rh), Platinum (Pt), and Palladium (Pd)] from e-waste uses a combination of hydro-, pyro- and electro- metallurgical process. Leaching into acids and separation from model solution using liquid-liquid extraction through precipitation with phosphonium quaternary salts and pH change, and ionic liquids have been reported for Pd, Pt, Ru and Rh metals (Mohdee et al., 2018; Rzelewska-Piekut and Regel-Rosocka, 2019 ). Similarly, extraction of gold (Au) by leaching it into lixiviates like thiourea, cyanide, halide or thiosulfate and separation through resin-based adsorption (1-ehylenediamine and 1-(2-aminoethyl) piperazine resins), or with aqueous polyethylene glycol-(NH 4)2 SO 4 two-phase system have been reported (Bulgariu and Bulgariu, 2011; Cyganowski et al., 2017 ). Further details on sustainable approaches to recover precious metals from e-waste using various chemical and biological processes have been discussed elsewhere (Ding et al., 2019; Islam et al., 2020; Khaliq et al., 2014 ).
5. Challenges and opportunities associated with e-waste management
Metals, plastics, glass, and rare earth elements present in e-waste are valuable secondary resources. The richness of e-waste for valuable elements can be understood by estimates that suggest a typical cathode-ray tube TV carry approximately 450 g Cu, 227 g Al and 5.6 g Au (Zeng et al., 2018 ). Similarly, a metric ton of waste personal computers may generate more gold than that recovered from 17 metric ton of gold ore (Bleiwas and Kelly, 2001 ). The conventional e-waste recycling activities have, however, targeted mainly for recovering useful and easily extractable materials such as metals that are present in relatively high content and extractable forms (Baccini and Brunner, 2012 ). Notwithstanding the challenges in effective e-waste management, recycling e-waste have benefitted both the environment and human health (Table 3 ).

5.1. Major challenges in effective management of e-waste
Electronic components such as printed circuit boards, graphic and memory cards, hard drives, and cables and connector which are commonly used in gadgets like personal computers and smartphones have been the preferred sources for extraction of precious and rare earth metals (Bleiwas and Kelly, 2001 ). However, e-waste is not only a source of valuable materials, but also of a variety of toxic chemicals emitted during its processing and recycling. For instance, hazardous substances present in e-waste (Pb, Hg, As, Cd, PCBs; primary emission), or those produced as by-products during processing and recycling (dioxins and furans, PAHs; secondary emission) are of great concern for environment as well as human health (Orlins and Guan, 2016 ). A holistic approach that encompasses collection of all categories of e-waste upon end of useful life and recycle them entirely, so that no materials get wasted, is required for sustainable e-waste management (Reuter et al., 2013; Song et al., 2015 ).
The main challenge for managing e-waste is its massively high volume and complexity. As presented in Fig. 1, e-waste generation is increasing constantly with an estimated rate of 2 Mt annually, where China, USA, India, Japan, and Brazil together generated 50 % of the total e-waste in 2019 (Forti et al., 2020 ). Escalating e-waste amount is a serious concern in countries such as China and India which are leading e-waste generators as well as importers of e-waste from across the world (Wang et al., 2016 ). Compounded with the difficulty in separating e-waste components (i.e., some components may be bolted, others screwed, snapped, glued or soldered together), the household tendency to dispose all categories of e-waste together make it further difficult to segregate e-waste components into multiple categories such as metals, plastics, and glasses for their effective product-specific recycling (Chi et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2017 ).
Lack of environmental awareness and knowledge on e-waste disposal and collection options among households due to insufficient efforts taken by local governments to popularize e-waste recycling policies and collection strategies after implementation of relevant legislation constrain the households to either sell e-waste to peddlers or itinerant collectors, or dump as solid waste (Wang et al., 2017 ). Further, the lack of effective collection mechanisms and networks has promoted informal setups that could recycle only selective e-waste materials due to lack of infrastructure and technology-driven methods. As a result, high volume of valuable secondary resource is either lost, and/or multiple toxic materials from primary, secondary and tertiary emissions are released into the environment.
Lack of financial support to highly automated and technically sound formal sectors to meet high running costs for systematic e-waste collection and treatment, site rent and skilled manpower costs have restricted the role of formal systems vis-a-vis the informal sector in e-waste recycling (Lundgren, 2012 ). Hence, a major fraction of the e-waste is handled by informal sector at inappropriate setups which lack basic infrastructure and technology to recover all the valuable substances and are usually not able to put in place measures to prevent the escape of pollutants into the environment. The crude recycling methods adopted by informal sectors are expected to release toxic additives and hazardous substances contained or produced from e-waste treatment into the environment, posing significant threat to the environment and human health. Further, prevalence of extensive manual dismantling, for example, use of hammers, chisels and screw drivers operated with bare hands to dismantle and separate e-waste components (Puckett et al., 2002, Wen et al., 2006), and recovering metals from cables, printed circuit boards and other components via heating over coal-fired grills, burning in open air, or stripping in open-pit acid baths are key constraints to effective management of e-waste (Awasthi and Li, 2017; Chi et al., 2011; Wong et al., 2007 ).
5.2. Key opportunities in effective e-waste management
Despite many challenges, e-waste recycling offers multiple opportunities owing to its huge richness of resources and its role in limiting the pace of e-waste generation. The most remarkable benefit of a systematically managed e-waste recycling is that it provides a controlled processing system for the e-waste that would otherwise end up in landfills or incinerator contaminating the environment (Song et al., 2015; Widmer et al., 2005 ). This way, it loops the conventional linear approach of resource extraction and helps in retaining materials in use for a longer time (Fig. 5 ). This reduces waste generation and promotes use of secondary raw materials in production through material recycling (Cossu et al., 2012; Klinglmair and Fellner, 2010 ).
