Dr. Stefan Kasian
Title.
CROSS-CULTURAL PERSPECTIVES ON EUTHANASIA AND PHYSICIAN ASSISTED SUICIDE
Stanley Krippner, Ph.D.
Saybrook Graduate School and Research Center
San Francisco, California, U.S.A.
and
Stefan Kasian, Ph.D.,
Akamai University
Hilo, Hawaii, U.S.A.
The end of life may become the most meaningful period ever. But facing death results in more fear and anxiety than any other human Experience, and death is a topic we don’t enjoy talking or thinking about. (Rengetsu, a Buddhist nun)
Abstract: This chapter compares perspectives on euthanasia and physician assisted suicide within countries as well as between countries. Several indigenous perspectives on euthanasia are contrasted with those of mainstream Western religion and medicine, both of which consider euthanasia and assisted suicide to be in conflict with their ethnical principles. Religious differences have emerged in research studies; Jewish participants are more likely than those from other groups to support physician assisted suicide, and Muslims are less likely to trust the health care system than were members of other religious groups. In spite of secular and ecclesiastical rejection of euthanasia and assisted suicide, several jurisdictions, including the state of Oregon in the United States, have permitted either or both. The Netherlands has guidelines for euthanasia and physician assisted suicide, while these practices have a de facto status in Switzerland, Belgium, and Colombia. In the U.S., the Compassion and Choices group urges its members to complete a “living will” and “power of attorney” for health care, both of which give members, or those who they designate, to control the time and manner of their death. At the academic and medical level, these developments impact the field of bioethics; at the public level, they have become part of the discourse between fundamentalist members of Roman Catholic, Protestant, and Muslim congregations on the one hand, and Unitarian-Universalist, liberal Protestant, and secular humanist groups on the other hand. As a result this topic has become a player as well as a pawn in the so-called “culture wars” that characterize both peaceful and conflictual diversity in the 21st century. This chapter exemplifies how the anthropology of consciousness can offer cross-cultural perspectives on conventionally “taboo” topics, e.g. death and dying, to deepen and perhaps advance discourse and policy based on humanitarian concerns.
Introduction
As an emerging discipline, the anthropology of consciousness can not escape the investigation of cultural myths and practices concerning death and dying. One set of beliefs and procedures is especially pertinent in the contemporary world, namely euthanasia and physician assisted suicide (Gustafsson, 2007; Kleinman, 1988; Krippner, 1989). Western medicine has prolonged human life, but its practitioners typically ignore discussing the end of life with their patients. In the meantime, there is a small group of physicians who are attempting to respond to the desires of some terminally ill or severely disabled patients that their wish to terminate their lives be honored.
In preparing this article, we used the American Humanist Association’s 1974 definition of “euthanasia” as “a mode of act of ending or permitting death painlessly as a relief from suffering.” The English word “euthanasia” is derived from the Greek words “eu” and “thanatos,” literally, “dying well.” The Hippocratic Oath, required from Greek physicians and dating back to the 3rd century B.C.E., states “To please no one will I prescribe a deadly drug or give advice that may induce death.” Even so, physician assisted suicide was not uncommon in Greece and Rome, and was actively promoted by the Stoics and Epicureans whose philosophy condoned euthanasia for those whose terminal illness resulted in unbearable suffering.
Tracing the history of physician assisted suicide and other forms of euthanasia (i.e., death assisted by non-physicians or by gravely ill persons themselves) was conducted by archival research. Material from books and journals in our own libraries was supplemented by means of internet searches using such search engines as google.com, questia.com, and yahoo.com to obtain data in regards to the contemporary debate, with an emphasis on cross-cultural perspectives. We delimited our thesis for this chapter to identifying the diverse ways in which national, religious, and ethnic groups respond to the issue of euthanasia; such theses as ethical issues, historical development, and psychological motivations are worthwhile candidates for other essays. We have not focused on the issue of life after death, a topic that has been dealt with from various perspectives (e.g., Braude, 2005; O’Kelly, 2006).
Historical Perspectives
Several indigenous tribes practiced euthanasia before their lands were colonized. For example, the Caribs practiced euthanasia on the grounds that the terminally ill were possessed by evil spirits and the longer these people clung on to life, the more powerful the malevolent spirits would become, endangering the safety of the community. The Caribs were cannibals, but only ate healthy war captives, especially young boys who were fattened up for the feast. The sick and the infirm were not cannibalized for fear that wicked entities would enter their bodies.
Among a number of other indigenous people, euthanasia was practiced for a number of reasons as well, both as a type of population control during times of hunger and famine, and as an act of mercy. The Kalinago inhabitants of the island of Grenada transported the aged and the terminally ill into the afterlife with the aid of herbal poisons, convinced that they were sparing the infirm debilitating inconveniences and pain (Honychurch, 2002).
Currently (as of 2008), euthanasia and physician assisted suicide are opposed by mainstream Western medicine, as expressed by The World Medical Association, and by all large religious institutions, as articulated by the Lutheran Church’s Missouri Synod and by Pope John Paul II in 1995 on behalf of the Roman Catholic Church. Islam is slightly more moderate, holding that the life of gravely ill people should be ended “only when absolutely necessary” (Johnson & McGee, 1986/1991).
However, in The Netherlands, since the 1970s, these practices are not punishable, provided that they have been committed by a physician who met certain care requirements. Canada gives its terminally ill citizens the right to refuse medication, intravenous feeding, or so-called “heroic” interventions that would prolong their lives (but, presumably, at the cost of prolonged pain and suffering).. In 1995, Australia’s Northern Territory became the first jurisdiction worldwide to legalize suicide and euthanasia for the terminally ill, whereby patients could facilitate their own death through a computerized process. In 1996, Philip Nitschke became the first physician to provide legal voluntary euthanasia under the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. However, the Federal Parliament soon overturned this legislation even though three people had been voluntarily euthanasized by Nitschke, and four seriously ill people had voluntarily ended their lives before the Australian Parliament aborted the activity.
The Belgian Parliament legalized euthanasia in 2002, specifically for competent adults and emancipated minors. Furthermore, supported by the Association for the Right to Die with Dignity, a Belgian pharmaceutical company announced the development of “home euthanasia kits” in 2005. In Switzerland, euthanasia cannot be prosecuted, assuming no selfish motive is exhibited on the part of the physician. In Great Britain, the Dying with Dignity society argues for euthanasia as a relief of terminal illness, despite some government opposition.
In the United States, the philanthropist George Soros initiated the “Death in America” project to support the legalization of euthanasia and physician assisted suicide. Two highly publicized cases of physician assisted suicide in 2005 were those of Haileigh Young and Terry Schiavo. The Compassion and Choices organization in the United   States, formerly known as the Hemlock Society, supports giving its members the right to control the time and manner of their death. This society supported Oregon’s 1997 law, upheld by the Supreme Court, to allow physicians to prescribe lethal drugs to terminally ill patients who want to end their lives. They also have organized movements to oppose legislation in half the states in America that would prohibit physician assisted suicide.
As an aging population continues to grow worldwide, governments and public opinion leaders will need to address this issue in a responsible manner, facing ethical issues on which there is no clear-cut consensus (Rosenbaum & Baird, 1989). While most religious institutions oppose euthanasia, a number of spiritual and activist groups stress the importance of the quality of life, not its duration. Even here, there is no unanimity as evidenced by such groups as the Atheist and Agnostics Pro-Life League, Feminists for Life of America, the Pro-Life Alliance of Gays and Lesbians, Jews for Life, Libertarians for Life, Citizens United Opposing Euthanasia, and the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force. Some of these organizations also oppose abortion, while others do not take a position on the issue.
In addition, some advocates support passive euthanasia (in which a physician or other person withholds a surgical procedure or an antibiotic or other vital medication) but reject active euthanasia (the administration of a toxic substance or the initiation of suffocation or other fatal procedure). Finally, many advocates of animal euthanasia would not extend the practice to humans whose dire medical situation is similar. Anthropologists can advance discourse and policy regarding this issue by making cross-cultural comparisons and by identifying indigenous practices that may be relevant to the contemporary debate.
Bioethics
Euthanasia and physician assisted suicide are examples of topics discussed in the field of “bioethics,” a term introduced in the United States in the early 1970s, and one that spread rapidly to other countries. The field covers a wide range of topics, from organ transplants to cloning. Writers from non-EuroAmerican cultures comprehend that any approach to bioethics should be based on specific cultural traditions, which vary from culture to culture (Sakamoto, 1995). Even within any given country, there are divergences of opinion; in Japan, some individuals believe that brain-death defines the cessation of life, while others believe that the circulation of blood is the defining criteria (Morioka, 1995). Therefore, this chapter will compare perspectives on euthanasia and assisted suicide within countries as well as between countries. Given the controversial nature of these topics and the clashing views involved, a deeper exploration of the beliefs and practices among various cultures can help provide a greater understanding, and promote a dialogue between these differing viewpoints, even though reconciliation is hardly realistic.
Mainstream Western religion and medicine consider euthanasia and assisted suicide to be in conflict with their ethical principles. For example, the World Medical Association (whose membership includes the American Medical Association) has adopted resolutions condemning both practices. This group has urged all medical associations and their members to refrain from practicing euthanasia and assisted suicide even if national laws are not prohibitive.
In 2002 the World Medical Association adopted a resolution that stated, “Euthanasia, that is the act of deliberately ending the life of a patient, even at the patient’s own request or at the request of close relatives, is unethical….Physician assisted suicide, like euthanasia, is unethical and must be condemned by the medical profession.” But the same resolution makes an exception: “This does not prevent the physician from respecting the desire of a patient to allow the natural process of death to follow its course in the terminal phase of sickness.” In addition, “The right to decline medical treatment is a basic right of the patient and the physician does not act unethically even if respecting such a wish results in the death of a patient.”
In the United States, a 1976 study based on data from 36 different focus groups found that Americans in general shared similar values, opinions, and concerns about death and dying. Focus group members expressed their desire for a humane, compassionate process for dying that would allow them as much control as possible over what happens at the end of their lives. However, ethnicity appeared to shape the few differences that resulted from the survey. For example, African American and Native American focus group participants were somewhat more reluctant to support physician assisted suicide than other ethnic groups. Moreover, African Americans and Native Americans were less likely to believe that decisions should differ for elderly patients in comparison with young patients. Euro-American and Asian American participants were more likely to place trust in the health care system than were Native American, African American, or Latino and Latina participants. African American participants were the most likely to indicate that a lesser quality of life would be acceptable to them if their lives were saved (Kalish & Reynolds, 1976).
There were also some religious differences that emerged; Jewish participants were more likely than those from other groups to support physician assisted suicide, and Muslims were less likely to trust the health care system than were members of other religious groups. Age had even less of a bearing than ethnicity or religious background; however, participants between the ages of 18 and 24 were more likely to support physician assisted suicide and less likely to trust the health care system (Kalish & Reynolds, 1976). These ethnic differences are in accord with anthropological data on minority groups in the United States; as “outsiders,” Muslims (both African American Muslims and those with roots in the Middle  East) are less likely to trust any system that reflects the power structure that has marginalized them. The same can be said for African American, Native American, and Latino/Latina participants, all of whom lacked trust in a “system” run by Euro-Americans, and one to which Asian Americans have accommodated surprisingly well. Jewish participants in the study were more likely to support physician assisted suicide, reflecting the diversity of American Jews (many of whom are not members of either the Orthodox, Conservative, or Reform congregations). Younger U.S. participants tend to question authority, no matter what the topic; those African Americans who would settle for “a lesser quality of life” may have had dealt with survival issues themselves or recall their ancestors’ attempts to survive during the years of slavery, when their life or death was dependent on the whim of their slave masters. I other words, it is essential that ethnic differences be taken into consideration before any sweeping generalizations are made regarding a country’s attitudes on life and death issues (Parkes, 1997).
A Report of the Commission on Theology and Church Relations of the Lutheran  Church’s Missouri Synod (Advocates for Better Care, 1993) rejected, on “scriptural” grounds, claims that euthanasia and assisted suicide were “compassionate acts,” insisting that “Christians aim always to care, never to kill.” However, the Commission noted that the administration of pain-killing medications, “even at the risk of shortening life” was permissible “since this does not entail the choice of death as either a means or an end.” Moreover, physicians were allowed to request and receive a patient’s statement, or one signed by the nearest of kin, consenting to the uselessness of “heroic efforts” and consenting to the termination of treatments.
In 1987 a coalition of conservative Protestant groups, the Fundamental Bible Churches stated their objection to the direction taken by the World Council of Churches (WCC) at their Vancouver assembly, a trend the coalition claimed was “evident” since the WCC’s Uppsala, Sweden assembly in 1968. The coalition stated that the WCC’s strong warnings against the nuclear threat to human life “is inconsistent with the apparent negligence of the millions of human lives sacrificed yearly through the toleration of legal abortion, and of the many other lives which will be sacrificed as the consequence of the increasing demand to introduce euthanasia.” Many evangelical and fundamentalist Protestant churches are not members of the WCC, taking exception to its stand on such issues as family planning, abortion, and – in select cases – the consideration of euthanasia.
In 1995, Pope John Paul II, in the Encyclical Evangelium Vitae, pronounced, by the authority that Christ conferred upon Peter and his successors, and in communion with the bishops of the Catholic Church, I confirm that the direct and voluntary killing of an innocent human being is always gravelyimmoral…, whether a fetus or an embryo, an infant or an adult, an old person, or one suffering from an incurable disease, or a person who is dying. Furthermore, no one is permitted to ask for the act of killing, either for himself or herself or for another person entrusted to his or her care, nor can he or she consent to it, either explicitly or implicitly, nor can any authority legitimately recommend or permit such an action.
This encyclical left no doubt that papal doctrine is completely opposed to both euthanasia and assisted suicide (Kurtz, 2006).
This perspective resembles the position of Kardec Spiritism, as practiced throughout Latin  America. Allan Kardec, a French educator, wrote several books about
“spirits” and “mediums” in the 19th century; these books have become the basis for an international movement, most notably in Brazil. The Spiritist medium Divaldo Franco (2006) wrote that euthanasia “constitutes a heinous crime.” But Spiritist doctrine differs from Catholic doctrine in that it attributes long-term agony to “past-life actions” (p. 10). Euthanasia interrupts the “process of adjustment” and “atonement” that is needed for the individual’s next “incarnation” (p. 11).
In 2000, after a three-year discussion that covered such areas as ethics, theology, and pastoral care, the Board of Directors of the Massachusetts Council of Churches voted to oppose legalized physician assisted suicide. The 40-member board consisted of clergy and lay representatives of 15 of the state’s Protestant denominations as well as representatives from Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox traditions.
In 1976, the Greek Orthodox Church issued an encyclical calling euthanasia “a moral abomination,” but also distinguished “between euthanasia and the withholding of extraordinary means to prolong life” (Harakas, 2005). However, in spite of this secular and ecclesiastical rejection of euthanasia and assisted suicide, several jurisdictions, including the state of Oregon in the United States, have permitted either or both. We will make several cross-cultural comparisons to demonstrate those differences.
The Netherlands
Physicians in the Netherlands have practiced both physician assisted suicide and euthanasia since about 1973, although theses practices remained technically illegal until 2002. Between those years, a series of court decisions and medical association guidelines led to an action of the Dutch Parliament stating that euthanasia and assisted suicide were not punishable if they have been “committed by a physician who has met the requirements of due care” described in the Termination of Life on Request and Assisted Suicide Act, and if they have informed the municipal authorities in accordance with the Burial and Cremation Act.
The events leading up to this legislation was stimulated by a 1973 district court case in which Geertruida Postma, a Dutch physician, was convicted of a crime after she ended the life of her seriously ill mother by lethal injection. Postma made her action public, hoping that it would stimulate public opinion and legal reconsideration of the laws against assisted suicide and euthanasia. Ordinarily, Postma’s crime would have resulted in a jail term of up to 12 years; nevertheless, the court imposed a one-week suspended sentence and a week’s probation following testimony by the district medical inspector who set forth certain conditions under which euthanasia should be considered “acceptable.” Other cases followed, each widening the boundaries and further liberalizing the conditions under which euthanasia and assisted suicide would not be punished.
Under this legislation that was adopted in 2002, minors between 16 and 18 years of age may request that physicians terminate their lives and, although parents and guardians may be consulted, they have no authority to prevent the requested death. However, a parent or guardian must approve of requests from children between the ages of 12 and 15 who make such an appeal. In addition, the law recognizes the right of a physician to carry out euthanasia based on a written advance request for death of a current incapacitated person who is 16 years or older. There is no requirement that the person must be at least 16 when the request is put into writing.
According to the Dutch government, physicians had been reluctant to report their death-inducing activities. According to the Dutch government, the primary reason for adopting the 2002 law was to bring matters into the open, to apply uniform criteria in assessing every case in which a physician terminates life, and to ensure that maximum care is exercised in such cases. In reality, however, many physicians objected to the many provisions of this law and it is likely that the actual number of physician induced deaths was under-reported. In the meantime, a university medical center in the Netherlands issued a report that it had been euthanizing infants, not only in the case of terminally ill newborns but also in the case of children born with spinal bifida and other severe disabilities. The medical center noted that its practice was in accord with the local cultural standards but was not necessarily transferable to other countries.
In 2005, survey results were published reporting responses of 3,614 general practitioners in the Netherlands. Of the explicit assisted suicide requests, 44% were granted by general practitioners, 13% died before the physicians could end their lives, 13% died before the physicians had made their final decisions, 12% of the requests were refused, and 13% of the patients changed their minds after the request had been granted. The total number of reported cases of legal anesthesia was 1,933 in 2005 (International Task Force on Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide, 2005).
The three most compelling reasons given by the patients whose requests were granted included “pointless suffering,” “loss of dignity,” and “constant weakness.” Among those whose requests were denied, the most common reasons given by patients were “I do not want to be a burden,” “I am tired of living,” and “I suffer from depression.” A critic of the study noted that the physicians surveyed were chosen because they did not have a negative attitude toward euthanasia; hence, the survey might not be representative of all Dutch physicians (Jan-van der Weide, et al., 2005).
Australia
In 1995, with the passage of the “Rights of the Terminally Ill Act,” Australia’s Northern Territory became the first jurisdiction in the world with both legalized assisted suicide and euthanasia. The law went into effect in 1996 but was repealed in 1997 when the national Parliament repealed the act. Under Australian law, the national government can review and repeal a Northern Territory Act if it is seen as conflicting with national interests. Groups as diverse as the Australian Medical Association and Australian aboriginal communities had opposed the legislation and supported the repeal; the latter group expressed concern that the procedure would deter aborigines from seeking prompt medical attention.
A deeper examination of the beliefs and practices of Aborigines illustrates how, for the Aborigines, birth and death were great mysteries involving supernatural beings. Therefore, if an Aborigine were taken ill and became close to death, he or she may reason that this was the will of those supernatural being. Further, the Eora/Dharawal Aborigines believed in transmigration or transmutation, e.g. warriors became dolphins in a subsequent incarnation. Animals were viewed as “their brothers” and David Collins (2007) noted one instance in which an Aborigine stood in the line of fire to protect the life of his “brother” when a European hunter wanted to kill a raven. Aborigines, as a rule, do not fear death and perceive themselves as so connected to the world of nature that they are willing to sacrifice their individual lives. However, their preference is to keep this practice under control rather than relegating it to a Western-trained physician unfamiliar with their traditions (http://www.crystalinks.com/aboriginals2.html).
During the four months which the law was in effect, four assisted deaths occurred under its provisions. The same physician facilitated all four deaths by means of a computer attached by plastic tubing to a pump-driven syringe filled with barbiturates. After the patient was attached to an intravenous line connected with the computer, three questions appeared on the computer screen:
1. Are you aware that if you go ahead to the last screen and press the “yes” button, you will be given a lethal dose of medicine and die? Yes/No.
2. Are you certain you understand that if you proceed and press the “yes” button on the next screen, you will die? Yes/No.
3. In 15 seconds, you will be given a lethal injection. Yes/No.
Checking “yes” for each of the three questions activated a syringe driver and a sequential delivery of barbiturates. The physician, therefore, did not directly administer the lethal dose. The physician noted that the procedure was inexpensive since patents paid about $100.00 (U.S.) for the drugs; the cost of the consultations was paid for under the Australian Medicare System.
Even after the repeal of the Act, an international organization, Compassion and Choices, worked with physicians to develop a “drawstring” device that people could put over their heads to commit suicide using carbon monoxide. So-called “peaceful pills” will also be available should Australian legislation change in the future.
Colombia
Colombia is the only Latin American country where euthanasia is not outlawed. The practice became permissible in 1997 when the Constitutional Court, Colombia’s highest judicial body, ruled that individuals may choose to end their lives and that physicians can not be prosecuted for their assistance. The ruling came in response to a case in which an opponent of euthanasia had tried to outlaw the practice. The court urged the Colombian Congress to codify the practice in order to prevent abuses, but legislators refused to do so, given the emotionally charged debate in a country that is predominantly Roman Catholic. Proponents of the legislation have proposed legislation that would compel physicians to obtain a second opinion, administer psychological and medical tests to patients, and have each case reviewed by a government commission. An activist group, The Right to Die with Dignity, has been formed to push for this type of legislation. A 2006 poll indicated that Colombians are equally split on the issue.
In the meantime, Gustavo Alfonso Quintana, a physician, admitted performing euthanasia on some 15 patients and requested that the practice remain a private matter with a minimum of bureaucratic processes and legal battles. Quintana often refused patients’ requests as in one case where a man requested physician assisted suicide because he was going blind. Before Quintana agreed, he would ask himself, “If I were in his position, would I want to end my life? If I find the answer to be affirmative, then I proceed to induce death. It’s never easy, but I do it out of respect and affection for my patients.”
One of Quintana’s patients was a 23-year-old student whose cancer had spread through his testicles, lungs, and brain. A huge lump had developed on his skull and the areas around his eyes were black and swollen. Quintana spent several days in anguished discussions with the student and his family. When the decision had been made, Quintana injected lethal drugs into the man’s arm while his relatives gathered around him, one of them holding his hand. In an interview with the Associated Press, Quintana recalled the student’s plea, “I don’t’ want to wait until I’ve turned into a monster.” On the death certificate, Quintana simply wrote “cardiac arrest” as the cause of death (Associated Press, 2005).
Belgium
The Belgian Parliament legalized euthanasia in 2002, limiting it to competent adults and “emancipated minors.” In 2004, a group of legislators introduced a proposal extending euthanasia to children and adults suffering from dementia and incurable illnesses, insisting that terminally ill children have as much right to choose when they want to die as anyone else. The bill did not pass, but a survey indicated that some physicians are administering lethal drugs to newborns and infants whose chances of survival are considered minimal. In the meantime, about 300 adults who opted for the law’s provisions have died each year since the bill’s passage (Knox, 2006).
In 2005, a pharmaceutical company announced that it had developed “home euthanasia kits” that would be available, with a prescription, from pharmacies. These kits include a barbiturate, an anesthetic, a paralyzing agent, and instructions for use; the reasonable cost makes the kits financially viable for the majority of Belgians. These kits are a direct outgrowth of Belgian legislation and the willingness of a sizable number of physicians to accede to the wishes of their terminally ill patients. The Association for the Right to Die with Dignity, located in Brussels, takes the position that people should be masters of their own lives, and polls show that support for this sentiment is growing among the Belgian population (Cowell, 2006).
Switzerland
Switzerland does not have laws permitting euthanasia or assisted suicide. However, there is a Swiss law that reads, “Whoever from selfish motives induces another to commit suicide or assists him therein shall be punished if the suicide was successful or attempted, by confinement in a penitentiary for not more than five years or by imprisonment.” The key words in this legislation are “from selfish motives.” Hence, in Switzerland, there is no prosecution if the person assisting a suicide successfully claims that he or she had been acting unselfishly, which results in de facto legalization. Rather than being “legal,” assisted suicide is “unpunishable,” unless a “selfish motive” is involved. Finally, there is no assumption that the person assisting the suicide was a physician, thus the enabler need not have medical credentials to escape punishment.
The Dignitas Clinic in Zurich has operated openly for years, and received international attention when Annie Turner, aged 66, arrived from England to take a barbiturate potion that ended her life. Turner reported that she was in constant pain due to progressive supranuclear palsy, a degenerative and incurable disorder. Turner successfully took her own life, and the clinic escaped prosecution. The case was controversial because Turner was not bound to a wheelchair and displayed no external symptoms of her illness. However, she told BBC television interviewer, “I may look as though I am all right, but I am not.”
John Close was another British citizen who died at the Dignitas Clinic, after years of suffering from an incurable nervous system disorder. His sister sadly remarked, “He didn’t want to get to the stage where he could do nothing for himself. That was a step beyond a dignified life for him” (Knox, 2005). On the other hand, 70% of people applying to Dignitas, and who have received preliminary approval from a physician, change their minds and do not follow up on this approval.
Great   Britain
The Dignity in Dying society in Great   Britain has been attempting to get British legislators to debate whether physician assisted suicide should be permitted. This debate would focus on such issues in bioethics as “What is life?” “Who owns it?” “Who decides when to end it?” The issue is clouded by the case of Harold Shipman, a physician who was implicated in the deaths of some 260 of his patients and who hanged himself in his prison cell in 2004. It is also influenced by memories of the Nazi initiative to kill handicapped and disabled infants, children, and adults, as well as members of targeted religious and ethnic groups. However, a poll conducted in the early 21st century indicated that 80% of British adults support implementation of a law permitting assisted suicide (Knox, 2005).
Nonetheless, Michael Irwin, a British physician, lost his medical license in 2005 when he helped a disabled friend plan his own death, and was outspoken in urging other terminally ill patients to consider making the same decision. Diane Pretty died in 2002 after waging a long and public legal battle to permit her husband to administer lethal drugs. Pretty suffered from motor neuron disease, an incurable, progressive affliction of the nervous system known, in some forms, as Lou Gehrig’s Disease or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Stephen Hawking, the renowned physicist, has the same disease and is an icon for those who oppose the premature ending of life. Lou Gehrig was a famous baseball player from the United   States who died from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and his name is frequently linked with the incurable disease.
The Dignity in Dying group points out that outsiders can not really know the anguish of terminal illness. It not only involves discomfort, but the humiliation of depending on others, the awareness of immanent death, and the sense of helplessness in the face of the inevitable outcome. However, Baroness Finlay, a member of the British House of Lords, insists “This is not the time to change the law so that killing people becomes a therapeutic option” (Cowell, 2006).
The “ Death in America” Project
Suicide is the eighth leading cause of death in the United States and occurs 2,000 times per day throughout the world, even though the topic is rarely mentioned in some societies (Tolaas, 2005). There are multiple reasons for this taboo; in some societies, suicide brings shame upon the family, and in others it is a deeply unsettling event, threatening the social fabric. In our opinion, the overarching reason for silence is that suicide reminds family members, friends, acquaintances, and even strangers of their own immanent demise. Terror Management Theory (Solomon, Greenberg & Pyszczynski, 2003) maintains that “human beings purchase psychological equanimity by collectively deluding themselves about the fragility of existence and the inevitability of its termination” (p. 301). To devote an inordinate amount of time discussing the suicide of an individual or to even discuss the topic in general terms confronts people with the terror of death. This terror can be managed through belief systems that promise a post-mortem existence; but most of these belief systems deal harshly with those who take their own lives. Hence, denial and repression serve as defense mechanisms that promote daily coping and maintain the quest for self-preservation.
In an attempt to break through this taboo in the United States, George Soros, in 1994, introduced his Death in America project to the general public. Claiming that death has replaced sex as a taboo topic, Soros provided 15 million dollars (U.S.) to establish a headquarters for his project at Columbia University’s College of Physicians and Surgeons. Soros’ project is devoted to “transform the culture of dying” by legalizing euthanasia and physician assisted suicide, and has funded over 40 programs to promulgate his ideas. For example, an Internet site titled “Health Force: Women and Men Against AIDS” helps grieving individuals write “Dear Death” letters as a means of coming to terms with the death of loved ones. Soros gave a grant to the Ellen Stephen Hospice to expand its services to South Dakota’s Pine Ridge Indian reservation to become a national model for Native Americans who are coping with terminally ill members of their families. In 1996, Soros’ project funded the first meeting on care for the terminally ill ever held by the National Institutes of Health (Ehrenfeld, 1997).
Death has not been treated nobly in the United   States where there is considerable confusion and controversy regarding “right-to-die” decisions. In 2005, a young girl by the name of Haleigh Young was hospitalized after her stepfather beat her unconscious with a baseball bat, and then burned her body. Haleigh was kept alive by means of a feeding tube and ventilator, even though physicians determined that she was “virtually brain dead” and in a “permanent vegetative state.” A few weeks after her hospitalization, the State of Massachusetts Department of Social Services decided to remove her feeding and breathing tubes, and her biological mother agreed. The only person who objected to the procedure was Haleigh’s stepfather, because he would have been charged with murder if Haleigh died. Eventually, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled in favor of removing the tubes, saying it was “unthinkable” for her stepfather to make the decision to keep Haleigh alive. Instead, they gave the power to the Department of Social Services, even though it had failed to act 17 different times when it received reports of Haleigh’s abuse or neglect. While the contention was going on, Haleigh began breathing on her own and the breathing tube was removed. Nevertheless, the medical records were sealed by the physicians as were Haleigh’s social service records. Politicians in Massachusetts vowed to make a full-scale investigation of the incompetence involved, but it is questionable whether their interest in the case focuses on Haleigh or on winning votes in forthcoming elections (Malkin, 2006).
Even more highly publicized was the case of Terri Schiavo, whose long illness divided her family, brought about protests and attempted interventions from the Pope, the United States President, the governor of Florida, and the United States Congress before a court decision allowed physicians to remove her feeding tubes in March, 2005 (Schiavo, 2006; Schneider & Schneider, 2006). A prominent U.S. Senator, Bill Frist, who was a surgeon before he entered politics, made a statement about Schiavo that, according to TIME magazine, “destroyed his reputation.” Frist stated that, based on the television footage he had seen, “she does respond” to external stimuli. TIME magazine called this statement “utter nonsense,” but it won political support for Senator Frist among religious conservatives. Even so, he decided not to run for re-election.
While the Schiavo controversy raged, Jack Kevorkian, an American physician who championed terminal patients' “right to die,” languished in jail because of his role in helping over one hundred men and women die. Kevorkian called for the establishment of “suicide clinics,” and the U.S. media referred to him as “Doctor Death” (Kevorkian, 1991). He invented a device, the “Thanaton,” that could be attached to a patient’s body; when these patients were ready to die, they pressed a button that released chemicals into their body. He also invented a device, the “Mercitron,” that employed a gas mask that was fed by a canister of carbon monoxide. The Mercitron was necessary because Kevorkian’s medical license was revoked following publicity resulting from his initial instances of physician assisted suicide, and he could not longer obtain the drugs and chemicals needed for the Thanaton. Many of the people who appealed to Kevorkian for assistance were members of the Unitarian Universalist Church, which has never issued a blanket condemnation of physician assisted suicide. In 1999, Kevorkian was found guilty of second-degree homicide by a jury in the state of Michigan and was given a 10-to-15 year sentence. He was released on probation in 2007.
“Compassion and Choices” in the United States
“Compassion and Choices” was formerly named the Hemlock Society, because of Socrates’ decision to drink a poisonous hemlock brew (instead of escaping) when he was sentenced to death by the Greek Senate. This organization purports to be dedicated to bringing “dignity, choice, and compassion” into the lives of terminally ill people. They have prepared a document for its members to sign, which states, “If a time comes when I am suffering from an incurable and terminal illness, and choose to end my suffering, I wish to have physician aid-in-dying.” Compassion and Choices urges its members to complete a “living will” and “power of attorney” for health care, both of which give its members, or those who they designate, control over the time and manner of their death. The organization makes several books available to its members including one by Barbara Roberts (2002), former governor of Oregon, who chronicled her husband’s torturous death from lung cancer.
Compassion and Choices supports the State of Oregon’s 1997 law that allowed physicians to prescribe lethal drugs to terminally ill patients who want to end their lives. This law was challenged by the Bush administration but was upheld in a 2006 decision of the United States Supreme Court. The federal objection to the law was that it violated laws concerning dangerous drugs. However, a national Harris poll conducted in 2005 found that 70% of Americans believe that “the law should allow doctors to comply with the wishes of a dying patient in severe distress who asks to have his or her life ended.” In 1982, 53% of Americans agreed with that statement. In the decade since the Oregon law was passed and the Oregon Health Division was organized to implement it, over 200 patients decided to end their lives under its provisions (Jacoby, 2005).
The Harris poll indicated that 67% of the American public would favor a similar law in their state. The Oregon law has strict conditions, requiring that:
1. Two physicians certify that the patient is 18 or older and has no more than six months to live;
2. The patient has made three requests to the physician for a lethal dose of medication, twice orally and once in writing;
3. The prescription will be filled only after a 15-day waiting period;
4. Patients will take the drug themselves.
Most of the deaths take place at home, usually with family members and a health care worker present. One of us (Krippner) had a friend who had a debilitating disease and was a member of Compassion and Choices. She lived in Oregon and followed each provision of the law whiles her family members and a health care worker sat by her side, and while a recording of her favorite music was playing.
Historical and Contrasting Values
In 2001, President Bush’s attorney general threatened to prosecute any Oregon physician who prescribed drugs to cause death, but the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit overruled him. Supporters of the Oregon law have noted that it does not use the term “physician assisted suicide,” because it does not conform to the usual definition of “suicide.” One Oregon patient remarked, “The only question I have is whether I will be able to say goodbye to my family while I’m still myself” (Jacoby, 2005).
Gilbert Meilaender, a member of President George W. Bush’s Council on Bioethics, has stated that “assisted suicide is the opening wedge in the more general argument for our culture to move on to the euthanasia of people whose lives are regarded as being of minimal value.”Although many supporters of physician assisted suicide would accuse Meilaender of making an extremist statement, Meilaender’s backers could remind them that the Nazi Holocaust provides (e.g., Wood, 2007).
In October 1939, Hitler authorized the “Aktion T 4” Nazi euthanasia program, first targeting the “mercy killing” of sick and disabled persons. This program was soon expanded to Hitler's decree of October, 1939, typed on his personal stationary, enlarging "the authority of certain physicians to be designated by name in such manner that persons who, according to human judgment, are incurable can, upon a most careful diagnosis of their condition of sickness, be accorded a mercy death" (History of Euthanasia, 2007). Within a few years, this agenda encompassed “inferior” ethnic groups (Jews, Slavs, gypsies, etc.) as well as Germans whose behavior demonstrated their “inferiority” (homosexuals, political activists, etc.). Years later, the diplomat Dennis Ross (2005) was to characterize the Holocaust as “an unimaginable evil” (p. 18).
This view of euthanasia stemming from the notion of life having minimal value stands in sharp contrast with the Australian Aboriginal motives for euthanasia. Eoral/Dharawal Aborigines’ beliefs in reincarnation, transmigration, the sacredness of life, and their fearless perception of death as a rite of passage present a paradigm in which life has so much value that its cessation on the earthly plane does not terminate it.
The motives behind the Nazi’s forced euthanasia program and the Aborigines’ indigenous euthanasia program could not be more at odds. Meilander’s “slippery slope” rationale is superficial in nature and needs to be spelled out to be convincing. Meilander and his supporters would do their cause a service if they would cite specific steps that would follow from the regulation of physician assisted suicide to the extermination of “minimal value” persons. Instead, a logical leap is made that, even if it were plausible, does not hold up under scrutiny. The Aborigines’ program is carefully thought through and regulated, reflecting a centuries-old tradition. The Nazi program was a “top-down” ordinance, not a “bottom-up” custom based on long-standing values.
We are not assuming that all similar indigenous customs are permeated with the same values even when they are intended to ease suffering. Sati (or Suttee) was a Hindu funeral practice dating back to about 400 C. E., in which a widow would throw herself in her husband’s funeral pyre in recapitulating the myth in which the goddess Dakshayani immolated herself because she was unable to bear the humiliation of her husband Shiva by her father. Reunion in the afterlife and a demonstration of devotion were seen as admirable motives. As the centuries went by, the practice varied from one area to another. In some, Sati was used for political purposes or status; in an 1806 case in Nepal the Marahai Raj Rajeshwari Devi was forced to commit Sati following her husband’s assasination; in others, the widow, especially if childless, knew she could expect little from life once her husband had died. In other parts of India Sati was forced on the widow via social pressures; as recently as the 19th century the British East India company recorded over 4,000 incidents of suttee in Bengal (Thompson, 2007). Although sati has been illegal in India since 1829, occasional reports of its practice still surface.
Voluntary Sati was not committed by the inform or the terminally ill. However, there were cases in which it was motivated by extreme depression, by the hopeless existence that was thought to follow a husband’s demise, by the absence of viable alternatives, or even by religious devotion.
The anthropology of consciousness contributes to an understanding of suicide when different cultures are compared and contrasted. A Dutch patient whose every waking moment is filled with pain, a terminally ill Australian aborigine who yearns for rebirth, and a Hindu widow whose uncontrolled depression leads her to her deceased mate’s funeral pyre have more in common than one might initially surmise. At the same time, the Nazi guard who tosses a baby in an oven and a fanatical group of religious devotees in India who immolate a young widow are acting from mythological premises that justify murder. It is not that the lives they destroy are of minimal value, it is that the dogma they espouse takes precedence over human life, individually or collectively.
The Public Debate
By 2040, one in four people in Europe will be 64 or older. In the United States, the ratio will be one in five. As members of the post-World War II generation grow older, their increasing frailty will strain health care and welfare systems, not to mention their families. As a result, governments will be under pressure to bow to demands to legalize euthanasia, according to supporters of these options. The same groups also claim that assisted suicide and euthanasia take place everywhere in the world, but usually illegally. Boris Dittrich, the Dutch legislator who was the major author of the Dutch euthanasia law, has stated, “We want to write it down and get it out in the open so that we know what is going on. We don’t want any misuse or abuse. If you don’t do it in a transparent way, the chances for abuse or misuse are larger.” In fact, in countries where euthanasia is legal, there has not been a dramatic increase in the number of reported cases (Knox, 2005). But opponents of the practices worry that euthanasia and assisted suicide will become too acceptable and will be sought by people who are not suffering from terminal illnesses or who are unable to make rational decisions (Singer, 2006).
In the meantime, the Swiss Dignitas Clinic has opened an office in Germany; its goal is to attempt to change German laws because one poll showed that 74% of the German public supported the option of euthanasia for seriously ill patients. Only 20% of Germans opposed legalizing the practice, and the rest were undecided. The debate is muted in countries with a strong Roman Catholic tradition, except for Spain where 75% of adults support the practice, and where 21% of physicians claim to know of cases of assisted suicide. Indeed, 15% of Spanish physicians admitted that they had participated in assisted suicide themselves. The Council of Europe (2003-2004) published two volumes on the topic of euthanasia, defining it as “an action or omission with the primary intent of bringing about a patient’s death in order to end his or her suffering” (van der Lugt, 2004). One volume was devoted entirely to ethical issues, dating the debate back to the Hippocratic Oath, which specifically forbids the practice (Council of Europe, 2003-2004). It can be seen that this topic has become a player as well as a pawn in the so-called “culture wars” that characterize diversity in the 21st century. As cultures come into closer contact with each other, there are opportunities for cooperation as well as for conflict.
The 2004 United Nations Human Development Report ranked 177 countries on a “Human Development Index” that measured such indicators of societal health as life expectancy, adult literacy, per-capita income, low rates of HIV infection, gender equality, and educational attainment. The leading countries on this index were Norway, Sweden, Australian, Canada, and the Netherlands – all countries whose citizens classified themselves as “atheists” more often than those countries at the bottom of the index (Zuckerman, 2006). The sole indicator of societal health in which religious countries scored higher than non-religious countries was the absence of suicide, but some would argue that the right to end one’s own life can be seen as a positive sign of a mature society. The world’s most powerful religious institutions are opposed to anything resembling euthanasia, but secular humanists, members of less powerful religious groups, and independent thinkers—including some of those who are strategically placed in the media—are calling blanket opposition to assisted suicide into question.
In the film, “The Sea Inside,” Spanish actor Javier Bardim won plaudits for his portrayal of a terminally ill author who finally persuaded someone to help him die. In the Academy Award-winning film, “Million Dollar Baby,” Clint Eastwood played a boxing trainer who facilitated the death of his protégée, played by Hilary Swank, following a debilitating boxing injury. In a journal published by the American Society of Law, Medicine, and Ethics, Coleman and Fleischman (1996) refer to the “serious public debate” raging in the United States regarding assisted suicide and euthanasia. More and more people around the world are becoming aware of the ceaseless suffering involved in Alzheimer’s and AIDS-related diseases and other terminal illnesses. This has led not only to increased interest in assisted suicide and euthanasia, but to a search for alternatives. More powerful painkilling drugs are being developed, sympathetic hospice workers are insuring “good deaths,” and training in “mindful dying” is offered by many Unitarian-Universalist churches and several Buddhist centers.
Spiritual Approaches to a “Good Death”
Pallative care for the dying in hospices and other institutions appears to be one arena where advocates and opponents of euthanasia can find a common ground (van der Lugt, 2004). If the United States can be described as a “death denying” society, most indigenous groups stand in marked contrast, conceptualizing death as part of the life cycle and providing meaningful rituals and pallative care for the terminally ill. One of us (Krippner) has visited The Sisterhood of the Good Death, a group of women in Salvador, Brazil, who are associated with both the Roman Catholic Church and Candomble’, an African-Brazilian religion. These women devote themselves to the dying, engaging in a never-ending cycle of cooking, singing, massage, and counseling to provide a “good death” for those men and women in their care.
In the Hindu tradition, to die with Gods name on one’s lips is a conscious way of returning to the “Source of Being,” in preparation for one’s next incarnation. When Mahatma Gandhi was struck by an assassin’s bullet, he uttered the name “Ram,” one of the appellations for God, as he fell, mortally wounded (Levine, 1982, p. 27). A traditional parting proclamation for Jewish people has been, “Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is One.” The last words of St. Francis of Assisi were, “Welcome, Sister Death.” St. Teresa of Avila proclaimed, “Lord, now is the time to arise and go….My soul shall enjoy the fulfillment of all her desire.” Such reverence has marked the deaths of countless Roman Catholics whose final moments found them repeating the phrase, “Sweet Mother of Heaven.” The Blackfoot Indian Chief Crowfoot stated,
A little while and I will be gone from among you, whither I cannot tell. From nowhere we came, into nowhere we go. What is life? It is a flash, a firefly in the night. It is a breath of a buffalo in the winter time. It is the little shadow that runs across the grass and loses itself in the sunset. (Schneidman, 1980)
One of the classical philosophical discussions between the human species and all other forms of life is humanity’s awareness of its own mortality, but numerous spiritual traditions and practices have emerged from that awareness. In death-denying societies, people often refuse to reveal their true age, spend large sums of money to erase their wrinkles and transplant their hair, and tell their dying relatives that they will recover soon. Ernest Becker (1973) observed that the denial of death starts in childhood and shows up in recurrent nightmares.
In their tortured interiors radiate complex symbols of many inadmissible realities – terror of the world, the horror of one’s own wishes, the feat of vengeance by parents, the disappearance of things, one’s lack of control over anything….But the child has to take it, and so he [or she] wakes up screaming. (pp. 19-20)
Rather than denying death and refusing to discuss it, most indigenous societies have conceptualized it as a part of life. The Egyptian Chapters of Coming Forth by Day is a “book of the dead” that dates back to about 1600 B.C.E. It casts no doubt regarding the reality of this world or the next, in contrast to the Tibetan “book of the dead,” Liberation by Hearing on the After-Death Plane, whichviews the entire human experience, including the after-life, as being fraught with illusion. This Tibetan tome teaches the dying to face death calmly and with a clear mind so that one will be able to transcend bodily suffering with a trained intellect that focuses on transcendence. It also teaches that denying death produces unfavorable results and that prolonging life with medicines dulls the mind and one’s ability to attain liberation. When the Tibetan yogi Milarepa was preparing to die, he welcomed death with a song about the naturalness of his passing (Krippner, 1989).
Mythological Themes
The anthropology of consciousness can provide examples of indigenous people and traditional cultures that can provide useful antidotes to the denial of death so prevalent in many Western cultures. These traditions can inspire people to imbue their time on earth with a richness of meaning that cannot be overshadowed by the certainty of their death. They can remind people that they can survive genetically, by their good works, and in the memories of those whose lives they have touched. Some people can be content to survive as part of the cosmic process, happy to have carried their banners in the universal parade of existence (Krippner, 1989). As Robert J. Lifton (1968) noted, following his study of Japanese citizens who had survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, the basic spiritual principle, with or without a concept of afterlife or immortal soul, is the ancient mythological theme of death and rebirth. Whatever the imagery, at the heart of religious mythology is a sense of spiritual power. This power may be understood in a number of ways including dedication, capacity love, and moral determination. But underlying all of them is the power one has over death. Some of the survivors he interviewed, cited an ancient proverb, “The state may collapse, but the mountains and rivers remain” (p. 22).
Carl Jung (1961) examined beliefs about life and death of various cultural mythologies and admitted that embracing a personal myth about survival of death was, for him, psychologically hopeful and enriching. The lives of Christ, Mohammed, Moses, the Buddha, and other spiritual leaders encompassed various combinations of revelation and ultimate ethical principles that could divest death of its “sting” of annihilation. Mythology (those narratives that address existential human issues, often in metaphorical ways) is still important in the contemporary world, especially in regard to the end of life. The anthropology of consciousness can examine the ways that indigenous people and traditional cultures often exemplify ways of caring for the dying that are more sophisticated and compassionate than what can be found in Western hospitals and nursing homes. The stories that they tell about the dying process and what lies beyond bring comfort and hope to the terminally ill as well as their loved ones. The debate about physician assisted suicide will not go away, especially as aging populations increase more rapidly than the funds to assist them when they become seriously ill.
The next step that anthropologists could make is to catalogue the ways that traditional cultures have dealt with (and are dealing with) elderly people as well as younger men and women who develop terminal illness. Anthropologist could ask such questions as at what point do practical and/or humanitarian considerations outweigh the “heroic interventions” needed to keep an individual alive? What role does the terminally ill person play in hard decisions that must be made and ethical concerns that need to be faced? What type of legal framework would allow for the greatest freedom of choice, and prevent religious and political pressure groups from interfering with decisions made by family members and by ill people themselves? These are life-and-death concerns that will become more salient as the 21st century progresses; anthropologists have the opportunity to play a vital role in this discourse. For example, indigenous worldviews are more likely to allow Nature to play a role make its voice heard in this discourse. Collective societies are more likely than individualistic societies to have a repository of rituals to ease transitions, such as those from life to death, for its members (Braun, Pietsch, & Blanchette, 2000; Parkes, 1997).
In Greek mythology, Aurora, goddess of the dawn, gave her human husband Tithonus eternal life, but forgot to give him perpetual youth. Tithonus grew older and weaker, until he shriveled down into a cricket. If humans learn to cure all diseases and heal any wound, but not prevent their cells from aging, they might face a similar unsatisfactory end (Jennings, 2005). Traditional cultures pay more attention to the role of ritual and ceremony during one’s final days than do modern societies (Holden, 2002), whether or not they practice euthanasia. Most indigenous spiritual traditions stress the concept that what matters is not how long a person lives but how well a person lives. Whether or not there is an afterlife, the quality of one’s existence on planet Earth deserves to be contemplated and examined, as well as the final days of that existence.

Is There a Moral Difference between Passive Euthanasia and Physician-Assisted Suicide?
General Reference (not clearly pro or con)
Gerald Dworkin, PhD, Professor of Philosophy at the University of California, wrote in his chapter “The Nature of Medicine” published in the 1998 book Euthanasia and Physician-Assisted Suicide: For and Against:
“Among physicians the most frequently heard argument against physician-assisted suicide is one about the nature of the medical profession. It is argued that the norms of medicine prohibit a physician from ever acting with the intent to kill a patient or to aid him in killing himself. For this reason it is essential, they believe, to maintain a sharp distinction between allowing patients to die [passive euthanasia], say by the refusal to initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and acts of assisted suicide.”
1998 - Gerald Dworkin, PhD

A second consequence of the common sense point concerns the acts of suicide and submission to euthanasia that would in fact occur as a result of legalization. One natural way to understand the thought that killing yourself is harder than having someone do it for you is that killing yourself requires firmer resolve. The element of passivity involved in your letting another perform the unpleasant task of putting you out of your misery means that your will is not as active as it would be if you performed the task yourself, and thus weakness or irresolution in the will is less likely to cause failure, less likely to cause an interruption in the lethal action. Conversely, then, a completed act of suicide warrants more confidence in its having issued from a will that was strong or resolute than does a completed act of submission to euthanasia. Accordingly, though any act by which a person deliberately hastens his or her death raises concerns about its voluntariness, there is less reason to worry, other things being equal, about the voluntariness of suicide than about the voluntariness of submitting to euthanasia…
One can, to be sure, imagine physician-assisted suicides that are not significantly different from submitting to euthanasia. Assisted suicides in which the amount of assistance is so great as to reduce the patient’s role to that of merely taking the very last steps, nothing more than opening a mouth, say, and intentionally swallowing a capsule placed therein by the physician are, practically speaking, equivalent to submitting voluntarily to active euthanasia. And if such suicides were typical of the suicides that resulted from legalizing the practice, then one could not seriously object to conflating it with voluntary active euthanasia when making utilitarian arguments against their legalization… But neither [Yale] Kamisar nor, as far as one can tell, any of the prominent opponents of legalization he cites offers reasons to think that such suicides would be typical. “

Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide
Pros And Cons
Perhaps the strongest argument made on behalf of legalizing euthanasia or assisted suicide is that it, like abortion, is a "choice" issue. Proponents argue that euthanasia/assisted suicide is "the ultimate civil right," and that to deprive mentally competent, terminally ill people who want to end their suffering of a peaceful "aid in dying" is to fundamentally disrespect their right to personal autonomy. Proponents also argue that legalizing euthanasia/assisted suicide is a necessary "insurance policy" that will ensure that no one dies in painful agony or unremitting suffering. Advocates contend that euthanasia/assisted suicide is little different from pain control since both use strong drugs and patients' deaths are occasionally unintentionally hastened as a side effect of the narcotics used in palliation. They also claim that doctors commonly engage in euthanasia/assisted suicide surreptitiously and promote legalization as a way to protect vulnerable patients from abuses inherent in the current "unregulated" practice. Acknowledging worries about potential abuses, advocates assure that "protective guidelines" would protect the vulnerable from wrongful death while still permitting suffering patients who are eligible for euthanasia/assisted suicide to obtain a desired, peaceful "death with dignity." Proponents also claim that opposition to euthanasia/assisted suicide is based primarily in religion and that laws prohibiting the practice are thus unconstitutional because they violate the division between church and state.
Opponents counter that legalizing euthanasia/assisted suicide would lead society down a dangerous "slippery slope" with legalized killing eventually being permitted for disabled, elderly, and depressed people, as well as for those who are not mentally competent to request to die. Protective guidelines "do not protect," opponents declare, pointing to the Dutch experience with euthanasia as "proof" of both the reality of the slippery slope and the relative meaninglessness of guidelines. Opponents also argue that the economics of modern medicine would promote euthanasia/assisted suicide as a form of health care cost containment, noting that the drugs in an assisted suicide cost only about forty dollars, while proper care for a dying patient can cost tens of thousands of dollars. They also note that forty-four million Americans do not have health insurance, and that medicine is sometimes practiced in a discriminatory manner against racial and other minorities. Thus, they argue that "the last people to receive medical treatment will be the first to receive assisted suicide." Opponents also deny that there is widespread surreptitious euthanasia practiced in clinical medicine, citing several published studies as proof, and urge that hospice care and proper medical treatment provide the morally acceptable answers to the difficulties that are sometimes associated with the process of dying.

The pros and cons of legalising euthanasia
August 10, 2018 politics
posted on Aug. 10, 2018 at 11:48 am
Euthanasia is a controversial topic for legislatures around the world. Legal and normalised in some countries while totally taboo in others, it remains one of the key ethical debates at the juncture where politics meets philosophy.
Also known as assisted suicide, euthanasia involves “administering a lethal dosage of a certain medication, or ending all life support means, and letting a person who is terminally ill pass away at their own will,” says blog Flow Psychology.
Many believe that allowing a person who is terminally ill and in pain to pass away at their own will is morally right, but those opposed to the practice on religious, moral, and ethical grounds argue that nature must be allowed to take its course.
Here are some of the main arguments for and against legalising euthanasia:
Pros:
An end to suffering
In a 1996 US Supreme Court case regarding assisted suicide, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) said that the right of a mentally competent person facing a terminal illness to choose “a timely and dignified death”, rather than suffer excuciating pain in their final days, should be seen as “implicit in the concept of ordered liberty”.
Allowing patients to end their suffering is not only morally justified but also essential to upholding the right to personal and bodily autonomy, advocates argue.
A “categorical ban on physician assistance to suicide… substantially interferes with this protected liberty interest and cannot be sustained”, the ACLU said.
Death with dignity
People in the late stage of terminal illness often end up bedridden and reliant on nurses and relatives for simple tasks such as eating, bathing and going to the toilet, which can be degrading.
Back in 2008, a woman suffering from terminal multiple sclerosis that had left her unable to take care of herself told The Daily Telegraph that such an existence was “torture”.
“If I was Spooky, my cat, I’d have been put down long ago,” she said.
Giving dying people the opportunity to choose when and how they die allows them to take control of their life and how they are remembered by their loved ones.
Eliminating fear of financial burden
A survey in the US state of Oregon, where assisted dying is legal, showed that 66% of euthanasia requests involved patients who did not want to be a financial burden, according to the New Zealand-based Life Information Website.
Inadequate funding for palliative care and pain management, and governments’ reliance on nursing homes, all contribute to the despair felt by many who reach old age, endure frustrating physical limitations, or are afflicted with debilitating conditions, the site says.
However, it adds, euthanasia opponents argue that the “ provision of adequate pain management and hospice (palliative) care could improve quality of life and eliminate the demand for euthanasia”.
Cons:
Corruption
Many believe that legalising euthanasia would put too much power in the hands of doctors, who could abuse their position.
Rita Marker, executive director of the International Task Force on Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide, says: “Laws against euthanasia and assisted suicide are in place to prevent abuse and to protect people from unscrupulous doctors and others. They are not, and never have been, intended to make anyone suffer.
“Euthanasia and assisted suicide are not about the right to die. They are about the right to kill.”
‘Slippery slope’
Opponents also argue that normalising euthanasia would be a philophical slippery slope to legalised murder.
Edmund Pelligrino, a professor emeritus of medicine and medical ethics at Washington DC-based Georgetown University, says that “in a society as obsessed with the costs of healthcare and the principle of utility, the dangers of the slippery slope are far from fantasy”.
He continues: “If terminating life is a benefit, the reasoning goes, why should euthanasia be limited only to those who can give consent? Why need we ask for consent?”
Religious concerns
Many religious people, especially Catholics, believe that life is the ultimate gift and that taking that away is usurping power that belongs to God only. The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops opposes euthanasia on the grounds that life is “a gift over which we have stewardship but not absolute dominion”.
The Catholic tradition “clearly and strongly affirms that as a responsible steward of life one must never directly intend to cause one’s own death, or the death of an innocent victim, by action or omission”, the assembly concludes.

Euthanasia vs Physician Assisted
There is a lot of debate whether a terminally ill man or woman should be allowed to die through mercy killing known as Euthanasia. There are both proponents as well as opponents of Euthanasia and physician assisted suicide. Whether or not a person should be allowed to choose death over life is a debate whose outcome can have serious repercussions on relationships in a family, the bond between a doctor and his patients and the basic human instincts. Many people do not know the subtle difference between euthanasia and physician assisted suicide though the outcome of both is the same, ending misery for the person who is terminally ill and does not want to remain hooked up to life prolonging machines. Let us find out the differences.
While Euthanasia is banned in most countries and all states in US, it is physician assisted dying or PAD that has been allowed in some states such as Oregon, Montana, Washington, etc on grounds of compassion. In Euthanasia, it is the doctor or the physician who administers the lethal medication that would end the life of the person, but in physician assisted suicide, the patient, with the help and assistance of the doctor, administers the dose himself. In physician assisted suicide, the patient decides whether and when to take this step whereas, in Euthanasia, it is the doctor who takes this decision as the patient is not in a position to be able to think about suicide or take his life in his own hands.
Religious affiliations have traditionally come in the way of euthanasia and mercy killing. Most Christians believe that ending one’s own life should not be allowed under any circumstances though liberal Protestants have been sympathetic to the cause and even supportive of the issue.
Physician assisted suicide is also labeled as voluntary active euthanasia. This is mercy killing where the patient is aware of the act and even decides the timing and means to end his life. The means such as lethal dose of medication are made available to the terminally ill patient, and he takes it with the help of the physician. PAD or physician assisted suicide is said to be emotionally easier on the doctor as he is not directly causing death of the patient and is merely fulfilling the desire of the patient by supplying him with the lethal dose of the medication that would end his life. Physician assisted suicide has the benefit of allowing the patient to change his mind even at the last minute.
What is the difference between Euthanasia and Physician Assisted Suicide?
• The objective of both Euthanasia and physician assisted suicide is the same, and that is to end the life of a terminally ill patient who does not wish to remain hooked to life prolonging machines.
• In Euthanasia, doctor administers the lethal dose of medication with to without the consent of the patient to end the life of the patient.
• Euthanasia is not legal in any state in US.
• Physician assisted suicide is a type of euthanasia where the patient decides when to have medication that would end his life and the physician helps him in taking that dose
• Physician assisted dying (PAD) is legal in some states of US such as Oregon, Washington, and Montana.
• PAD is emotionally easier for the doctor as he feels he is merely helping in fulfilling the desire of the patient by supplying the medication.

Nuclear energy comes with many benefits and drawbacks, which is what makes it such a controversial alternative energy source. Here are the main nuclear energy pros and cons:

What is nuclear energy?
Nuclear energy has been powering the United States for over 60 years. But how exactly do nuclear power plants generate electricity?
Nuclear energy is formed by splitting uranium or plutonium atoms through chain reactions in a nuclear reactor by a process called ‘nuclear fission’. The energy released from splitting the atoms is used to heat water into steam. This steam then turns a turbine, which creates usable electricity.
Experts believe that thorium is another fuel that could be used for nuclear power. It’s already being used in countries like India and Russia.
Advantages of nuclear energy
1. Low-cost energy
Although building nuclear power plants has a high initial cost, it’s relatively cheap to produce energy from them and they have low operating costs.
Also, nuclear power doesn’t experience the same kind of price fluctuations that traditional fossil fuel energy sources like coal and natural gas do. Because of that, the price of nuclear energy can be predicted well into the future.
That price is likely to remain low, or get even lower, as technologies advance.
2. Reliable
One of the biggest benefits of nuclear energy is that it is a reliable power generation source.
Unlike solar and wind energy, which need the sun to be shining or the wind to be blowing, nuclear power can be generated at any time throughout the day. This means that a nuclear power plant can produce energy nonstop, and you won’t have to experience any delays in energy production.
3. Zero carbon emissions
Nuclear power reactors do not produce any carbon emissions. This is a huge advantage over traditional sources of energy, like fossil fuels, which releases tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Excess carbon dioxide is one the leading causes of climate change. So, the less carbon and greenhouse gas emissions an energy source has, the better.
In fact, according to the Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI), nuclear electricity production prevents 528 million metric tons of carbon dioxide from being released into the atmosphere annually.
