This rattle illustrates two further principles underlying narrative in Northwest Coast art. The first principle: that animal beings are both actors in this world, and the stage upon which action takes place. The play of parts and wholes—a head emerging from a body, which then produces a head—requires the animals to take on many concurrent roles, as bases, frames, and agents. On the Peabody oystercatcher rattle, a head (perhaps a frog) emerges from the back of the bird, and from its cranium springs forth, Athena-like, a full frog (perhaps the same one, seen now as a body rather than a head); it’s this last creature, presumably at the shaman’s summoning, who fights the witch and the witch’s helper (likely a land otter, which is split in two and acts as a frame for the witch). On rattles, sentient beings interact in sentient frames or, better yet, frames are always figures, and figures must often serve as frames.
The second principle inheres in use: the rattles show us that there is always yet another frame of sentience that surrounds the one visible in the artifact. This is the human use of the rattle, in this case the shaman shaking it in the air over a suspected witch or sick person seeking a cure. A contrast with Western pictorial art may be broad, but nevertheless useful. In many Old Master paintings, beings are depicted within a series of inanimate frames. Imagine, say, a Poussin, in which figures are framed by an arbor, nestled within a temple, carefully surrounded by a landscape, and finally enclosed by a literal frame. In contrast, each representation on the Tlingit rattle is surrounded by layers of labile aliveness: the setting is as alive as the characters. The beings on top ride on a moving being (the oystercatcher), who is being moved by yet another moving being (the shaman). And if we consider that the shaman is likely being guided by a spirit animal (in Tlingit, a yéik) during his ritual, then that seemingly final moving being is actually being moved by yet another being, who may even be the very oystercatcher or land otter depicted on the rattle itself.
The paradox of emergent aliveness: G̱unakadeit
Many cultures, it is claimed, understand the world to be alive. But what, precisely, does that mean? Is the world one living being? Many living beings? Are there things that are alive and things that are not? Are things alive insofar as they are perceived to share in some form of consciousness, or are they alive only in a more biological or abstract sense? (A still more sobering question, likely answerable only long after the fact, is whether an outsider writing in English can offer a plausible translation of the ontology of animism from a given time and place into the language of a scholarly essay.)
A set of linked myths might give us a small hint as to how aliveness was conceptualized in the Northwest in the nineteenth century. These concern that underwater creature called in Tlingit G̱unakadeit, and in Haida often, though not always, wasgo. As we’ve seen, he is one of the figures associated with the bottom face of the raven rattle, and a key figure in the cosmic picture, living on the curved base of the world. He is a bringer of wealth and a monster from the deep. He may serve as an important test case for notions of aliveness because he cannot be seen in the everyday, like a raven or eagle. His aliveness is out of sight—and so the underlying metaphysics must come to the fore.
Two G̱unakadeit stories were recorded in English by John Swanton in his Tlingit Myths and Texts, published in 1909. 15 The first, told by Katishan, or Ḵaadasháan, a leader of the Kaasx̱’agweidí clan, concerns a lazy man, fond of gambling, who’s always being nagged and criticized by his mother-in-law. She thinks he wastes his days in idleness and doesn’t shy away from saying as much to the whole village. But in fact, he goes every day in secret to a deep lake and works at cutting down a tree on its shore. Eventually he fells the tree and splits it into a bifurcating trap. He stretches it over the surface of the lake and lays a line baited with salmon. A sea monster—“he saw that it had very sharp, strong teeth and that its claws looked like copper”—rises up to eat the salmon, and it’s caught and killed when the two halves of the tree snap shut. 16
The man skins this G̱unakadeit and puts on the skin, gaining the animal’s power. He swims down to the bottom of the lake, where he visits the animal’s splendid house, and discovers a tunnel leading out to sea. He swims to the ocean and starts catching fish and whales. He leaves them on the beach and arranges with his wife a scheme so that his mother-in-law will be the one to discover them lying there on the shore in front of the village. The catches grow ever more extravagant—a king salmon, a halibut, then two halibut, then a seal, and finally a whale. All the while the mother-in-law takes credit, claiming to be a powerful shaman, conspiring with spirits to bring food to the village.
Eventually the man exhausts his mortal powers, as he knows from the beginning will likely happen. He dies trying to liberate himself from the monster’s skin as it bursts onto the beach. His wife, who’s been warned of this possibility, comes down to the shore, pries his body from its sheath, and exposes her own mother as a sham before the whole village. The mother-in-law is so humiliated she drops dead. The wife (as her husband had instructed her to do) brings the dead man and his animal skin back to the lake, leaving them in the stump of the tree he had first used to make the trap. Then:
Every evening after this the dead man’s wife went to the foot of the tree which contained his body and wept. One evening, however, she perceived a ripple on the water, and looking up, saw the monster flopping around in the lake. Then the creature said to her, “Come here.” It was the voice of her husband. “Get on my back,” it said, “and hold tight.” She did so, and he swam down to the monster’s former house. This monster is the Gonaqade’t that brings good luck to those that see him. His wife also brings good luck to those who see her, and so do their children, “the Daughters of the Creek,” who live at the head of every stream. 17
Although a great deal can be said about this story and the many iterations of it that appear on the Northwest Coast, we can limit ourselves for the time being to a discussion of what Ḵaadasháan suggests to his listeners about different forms of aliveness, human and supernatural.
There are certain living beings who are always just out of sight. The beings who constitute the powerful forces of the world do not manifest in the everyday life of the village, but rather live behind screens—in the woods, under the waves, beneath the still surface of a lake. They travel through the world by unknown and inaccessible conduits. For a sea monster, the freshwater lake and the ocean are connected, but by hidden paths that human beings cannot normally see or travel along. These beings likewise act in ways that can only be seen after the fact: the monster deposits food, but it hunts and travels under cover of night. The living beings of the world map a secret geography of action, giving a countershape to the world by their movements, a second world order unlike the one perceived from the threshold of a house looking out toward the water or the forest.
Another observation about living beings to be gleaned from this story is harder to formulate, but a first pass might be: nonhuman life is intimately connected to human life, but not in the ways it might seem to be. Public claims about privileged access to the hidden beings of the world—like the mother-in-law’s—are to be treated with skepticism. But there are nevertheless secret forms of access, usually carried out beyond the social world, triggered when a person withdraws from the village with its gossip and ambitions and seeks the solitude of the forest or the ocean. Here nonhuman life can be encountered and, in complex and even dangerous ways, fused with. The man kills the sea monster, but only to become the sea monster, and then be killed in turn by the sea monster skin, and then somehow to be resurrected once more, now irreversibly the sea monster and not a human, no longer able to return to the village—and this time even his wife and children must follow him to the nonhuman world.
Here is the paradox of emergent aliveness: in the wilderness, aliveness is felt most intensely when it pops in and out of nowhere, when it jumps out from the bushes, or surges up from the water and drops back down again. 18 The most intense forms of nonhuman aliveness to permeate the world are the liminal ones—those that hide and reveal themselves in a flash before disappearing again. This jumping in and out of revealed aliveness is the source of power and wealth, and the conceit of this story of the G̱unakadeit is that a man might be able to share in this potency if only he can become an animal and live literally in its skin. 19 But again, a human cannot just annex an animal being or the power of emergent aliveness and remain as he was. He must go through a continuous process of moving between the animate and inanimate, between living and dying. Eventually, if he persists, he will no longer be a living human, but one of the beings in the nonhuman sphere of sentience, always just out of view. Among other things, this is an allusion to normal human-animal interactions, as any hunter or hiker knows. At best we see them for seconds, before they vanish into the secret world they inhabit. This story and others like it suggest something like a phenomenological ontology of nonhuman life. To become an animal is to live within the slipstream time that is the usual human perception of animal life.
A human can enter the skin of the animal and so become it; this is elegantly mirrored by another important idea from the Northwest, namely that when animals (and monsters) are out of sight, they shed their skins and become humanoid, living and walking about in villages of their own. 20 This idea is at the center of the second G̱unakadeit story recorded by Swanton among the Tlingit, this one told to him by Kasank’ from the village of Kake. The story begins with a chief who, traveling at sea with his nephews, ties up his canoe for the night “to a dead tree hanging from a cliff. At midnight he felt the canoe shaking very hard. He jumped up and was terrified to see foam breaking almost over his canoe. Then he thought of a sea monster, and climbed up to the cliff by means of the dead tree. His nephews, however, went down with the canoe. A Gonaqade’t had swallowed them.” 21
The chief returns to the village and explains what has transpired. The people immediately prepare to set out and slay the monster, but the chief stops them and instead proposes inviting the G̱unakadeit to a feast at his home, in the hopes that he’ll return the nephews if treated generously. He dispatches a brave brother-in-law and other men of the village to offer hospitality to the G̱unakadeit. They paddle to the cliff where the nephews were lost and, as they shout their invitation into the air, a huge cloud of foam envelops the sea. Then the cliff cracks open and reveals a town, presided over by the G̱unakadeit who, when in human form, is a powerful chief. The G̱unakadeit agrees to return with them as their guest. He and his men travel by canoe to the human village, and a long potlatch ensues, during which the human chief gives many of his prized possessions to the sea-monster chief. But his nephews still fail to reappear, and he begins to wonder why he bothered to give this feast if the G̱unakadeit had no intention of giving them back:
Soon after this thought had passed through the chief’s mind the Gonaqade’t called loudly to one of his men, “Bring me my box from over yonder.” This box was beautifully carved and painted, and it was from it that the Tsimshian came to know how to carve and paint boxes. Then he took out a chief’s dancing hat with sea lion bristles and a rattle, and just as soon as he had done so the chief’s eldest nephew stood beside him. … Then the Gonaqade’t went through the same actions as before. There had been twenty youths in the chief’s large canoe, and he gave each a hat, a rattle, and four songs, making them all stand on one side of the house. Now the village chief felt very happy and was glad that he had invited the Gonaqade’t to him instead of doing as the village people had planned. 22
It is important to note just how different Kasank’’s myth is from Ḵaadasháan’s. Within the Tlingit myth-world, this name and the character behind it are protean enough to be, depending on the teller, a chief who lives under the sea or a former human who lives in a lake, a bringer of wealth or a taker of nephews. Many other stories are told about this figure in all the northern languages, and in them this G̱unakadeit spirit might be described as a sea-wolf or sea-grizzly living in the lake, or as a long-eyed wealth spirit from the bottom of the sea, sometimes rising up from the deep in the shape of a giant house. 23 The mysterious aliveness to be seen in the depths of the sea and in the cosmic and numinous corners of the universe is plastic, can change form and shape even when it retains the same name across a corpus of myths. 24
The mystery of emergent aliveness is a key topos in Haida and Tlingit narrative. When beings first appear out of the forest or sea in such stories, they’re often just called “something”: then something spoke, or then something jumped out of the water.25 At first there is no name, no shape, just the presence of a being, indiscriminate, not yet woven into a web of story or kinship. This is a mimesis of surprise, the way a living being steals upon your proprioception, raising the hair on your neck before the cognitive faculties can offer a concrete explanation. Only after the initial shock of having encountered this being passes do a name and a description come into focus. And even then, the name and the description are not locked by culture into an unchanging relationship. Different descriptions and different names can attach and reattach to one another depending on who is telling the story, and for what purpose. In the case of this second story, that purpose says something about the complex mirroring of the social and natural ecology. Conflicts with sea monsters, like conflicts with humans, can be resolved by feasting and gift-giving. The protocols shared by humans and sea monsters constitute a whole political system—but the parallels cannot be seen with normal sight, for the sea-foam and dark waters of the perceptual world get in the way.
The aliveness of the world—in the case of this story, the aliveness of the sea in particular—is at first hidden, secret, emerging only sporadically and violently amid obscuring foam or dark waters. But once it can be truly looked at face-to-face, away from the village and its constraints, this aliveness turns out to be very much like human aliveness, a looking glass of all the things that make up human experience. And what is this looking glass made of? It is a razor-thin plane of matter: sea-foam, water-surface, dense thickets that are everywhere in the rainforests of the North Pacific. It is nonlife bracketed by the animate on either side, and contact between different forms of aliveness is achieved by passing through a thin membrane of nonbeing. To pass from one to the other, you must be able to go through this membrane by some form of death, which is itself conceived not as a permanent state, but as a thin boundary that can be traversed to reach other iterations of aliveness. 26 When nephews devoured by a sea monster are brought back to their home village and restored to their human status, their return is nothing less than a resurrection.
Boxes, or envelopes of being
And what is the instrument of resurrection? To use a (perhaps) anachronistic and out-of-context word: art. A beautifully painted box—in fact the ur-box, the template for all subsequent ones—contains rattles and hats that, when ritually removed, generate, in a supernatural metonymy, the nephews who wear and hold them. The pattern of emergent aliveness present in the larger architecture of the myth is reproduced in microcosm by the G̱unakadeit’s potlatch performance. From the concealed, hidden interior of the box, something is brought out, and that something then turns spectacularly into a someone. If the rattles are meant to be imagined as the raven rattles we’ve earlier discussed, then the image is also a mise en abyme. In the myth, a wealth-bringing sea creature regenerates humans by scooping rattles from the bottom of his box, and on those rattles are depicted humans riding on top of wealth-bringing sea creatures. Every element in this dizzying constellation of interactions can be understood in two ways at once: as a living being, and as the catalyst for the generation of a living being. Everything comes from the depths, but everything is also the surface across which the animate treasures of the deep world break forth. Everything is being, except when it is the envelope of being.
Nowhere is this dualism more intensely expressed than in boxes. In the great plank houses of the northern cultures, boxes had two functions that echoed these cosmic dramas in everyday life. The first, likely the older function, was as a vessel for cooking. 27 There were no implements capable of directly withstanding contact with fire, so instead, tightly sealed boxes—their sides made by kerfing, steaming, and bending a single plank of wood—were filled with water and heated rocks that made the water boil. Dead animals went into the boiling box and emerged as life-giving sustenance. This vessel was one more thin membrane between life and death, equal and opposite to the ocean surface across which a hooked halibut might burst, or the screen of reeds through which a duck could be spied.
The second function was to contain objects of splendor and pride: rattles, blankets, hats, headdresses, perhaps also preserved foodstuffs or tools. G̱unakadeit is the bridge between these two uses. He guards the living food-wealth at the bottom of the sea. Food-wealth, in turn, is what permits all other forms of wealth and power to accrue. It should come as no surprise that the box is not only associated with G̱unakadeit, but in some sense is him. An elaborate figure with an enormous face is typically depicted on the sides of the boxes, and this figure is very often said to be a wealth spirit from the bottom of the sea, often explicitly called G̱unakadeit, sometimes given other names.
Speaking about one of the masterpiece boxes of the nineteenth century, Wilson Duff told his students in an unpublished lecture, “But didn’t you find it strange … how little I could say about what it meant? ” 28 Surely a reader of this article will have found this strange, too: at every turn when talking about the art I have been careful to say that something might be a frog or supernatural snag, probably a G̱unakadeit unless some other underwater spirit. Now it’s time to address this vagueness head-on. Let me suggest that it’s not only a matter of context lost because of colonial depredation (though it is that also). I wish to claim that this indeterminacy is integral to the ideas expressed in and by the art.
A box now in the Peabody Museum, collected in the late nineteenth century on Haida Gwaii, is at once highly typical for storage boxes and also an example of considerable elegance and refinement (fig. 3 ). The box is painted on two sides in a design that shows a humanoid animal figure but flirts with abstraction. Duff draws a distinction between what he calls the “iconographic” aspect of Northwest Coast art—its representation of specific beings, say, Raven or G̱unakadeit—and the “iconic” aspect, by which he means its display of form, its exploration of style:
Iconic design cannot exist alone, except as an esoteric exercise or as empty decoration. It requires a foundation of ordinary iconography on which to root and feed and grow, just as poetry needs a foundation in ordinary speech. Yet in order to get its messages across, it has to compete with the iconography for attention. It is a competition in which the iconography has a strong advantage, for the eye and mind strain first to recognize the icons and concepts of that realm, and are then tempted to rest, feeling that to know what it represents is to know what it means. The task of the artist is to draw the attention back into the design, pique it again to a high state of vigilance, and present it with the subtle pre-gestalt images and signs which convey the iconic meanings. 29
Let us assume for a moment that (as is likely) this box is meant to represent G̱unakadeit or another wealth-hoarding creature of the submarine. We can see his face with its huge eyes, a pair of claws on either side, and in the center a face-form that may also be some kind of dorsal fin. But the essential characteristic of the work—if we are to believe Duff—is rather the exercise in emergence it engenders, the cognitive slip-and-slide triggered by looking at it, the bouncing back and forth between fixed representation and an unformed matrix of meaning, like “a flower coming into bloom.” 30 G̱unakadeit is always rising from the churning sea-foam: in this case the skein of ambiguity, the obscuring film of perceptual experience, is style itself. 31 Style is what hides content, keeps it below the surface. Yet it also embodies, once again, the paradox at the center of this system: being is constituted at the moment of its temporary emergence from occlusion. For style is both the obstacle to revealing the thing and also the constituent material of the thing itself.

“Haida art has no horizontal straight lines,” writes Duff in his notes. The classical Haida understood their world to be curved—except, speculates Duff, in the vertical dimension. “Trees grow straight up, men stand upright, everything upright (the world inclusive) has a centre straight line (is bilaterally symmetrical).” 32 The axis of the world is the meeting place of worldview and style; it is the equivalent of linear perspective in Western painting. 33 The curved, swelling world arrays itself around this line, and models itself especially on the bilateral symmetry of the face. I count four facelike arrangements displayed across the surface of this box: a pair of eyes with nostrils at the top, the large face with eyes and mouth just below, a pair of slanted eyes in the center, and a pair of perfectly round eyes with an inverted U for a mouth-form just below. 34 As almost always in Northwest Coast art, “eyes” are some manifestation of the ovoid, the rounded, calligraphic form that can vary between almost perfect circle and almost perfect rectangle. The eyes in the main face are further and conventional elaborations on the ovoid known as “salmon-trout’s-heads.” They are clearly another exploration of the face, such that smaller faces inhabit a larger face, in the way that a complex linguistic utterance might be composed of numerous figurations embedded in one another, some of them so conventionalized that their literal meaning is no longer accessible. The longer we look at the box, we see new lookers emerging to meet our gaze before receding into the labyrinth of form.
Once again, this is a being built of beings. The units of style by which the being is depicted are themselves formalized depictions of aliveness. The message is made still more complex when we look at the other side of the box, which seems to me what one might call its verso: much the same figure is depicted, but with telling differences (fig. 4 ). It is even more abstracted than the recto. The hands of the recto figure become matching pairs of sideways U ’s (perhaps evoking the shape of fins?), and the doubled and much elaborated mouth of the recto becomes just one long form. The inner ovoids (i.e., the “eyes” of the lower two “faces”) are given a much slacker shape. On the recto, one set is a tight pair of slits, the other perfect circles. On the verso, they have all released to less tense, less extreme ovoid forms. It’s as if the box encodes a complete cycle of breath, the recto a tight intake, and the verso a release.

Other metaphors are possible: the recto is hyper articulation, the verso a dissolving into abstraction. The recto is the emergence out of the foam, the verso a receding back into it. The principle should by now be familiar. Rattles are designed to be shaken. Transformation masks swing open to change one face into another. These boxes—which held within them rattles, masks, and other instruments of metamorphosis—operate on the same principle, though they are less theatrical. They are a meditation rather than a performance, offering possibilities for the static contemplation of an ontology in which nothing can be seen entirely at one glance, and in which the tension between surface and depth is paramount. Everything is always and forever arising out of its surroundings, dissolving back into them and, in the process, creating them. In the study of European art, such investigations at the cusp of perceptual recognition—for example, in the fantasias of Arcimboldo or Magritte—are often seen as frivolous and marginal. But here this suspension between the first apperception of a being and its identification is charged with the highest aesthetic value. It is a perceptual mimesis of the hunting eye, and in a hunting culture where interactions with nonhuman beings are the proving ground for life and death, such depictions might very well illustrate a society’s deepest concerns about knowing and existing.
Why Boas couldn’t see what Edenshaw was trying to show him
The ontology expressed in these oscillations is complex enough that I believe it benefits from a description (such as I’ve given here) independent of the major social institutions of Northwest Coast culture, like the potlatch and shamanism. Future work—beyond what can be done in these pages—may show that it also played a part in ceremony, healing, or the affirmation of privilege and rank. Still other work may one day investigate parallel forms of emergent aliveness in artistic traditions beyond the Northwest. For now, however, I’d like to explore one minor and speculative example of the social life of this principle, as it may have played out in a conversation between a great anthropologist and a great artist.
The example concerns one particular Northwest Coast box (sometimes called a bowl), which has haunted outsiders and insiders alike (figs. 5 – 6 ). Boas was puzzled by it but included a drawing of its surfaces in Primitive Art. It was in Primitive Art that the great Haida carver Bill Reid first saw this “masterpiece, whose outstanding qualities were apparent even in the small, inaccurate, unfinished rendering by which it is illustrated there.” 35 Reid, in turn, showed the box to Wilson Duff, and Duff was overwhelmed. The piece became the prime mover of his late thinking and writing. He named it “the final exam of Northwest Coast art.” 36

The box, which inexplicably languishes in storage at the American Museum of Natural History, is painted on all four sides with a design of staggering complexity. Each side is divided into four quadrants, and opposite sides of the box seem to be paired by stylistic similarities (“recto” relates most directly to “verso,” “left side” to “right side”). Bill Reid called its unknown creator “The Master of the Black Field” because the lower right-hand quadrant of each side is painted in such a way as to reverse the normal arrangement of colors in the Northwest: red is used for the primary forms, and they are placed on a black field. But this great painter might also be called “The Master of the Hand and the Face,” for among other things, his work is a superb exploration of these two elements of the body, the main instruments of human (and animal?) communication. Eye-forms, mouth-forms, and hands (or claws) saturate the field of representation. On the sides with convex top edges—what I call recto and verso—combinations of hands and eyes seem to form a being across two quadrants, such that a face-form in the upper left and the claw in the lower right might make up a single being. On the smaller sides, with concave top edges, a hand and face appear side by side within a single quadrant, most notably in the upper left and more vaguely in the lower right.
A full analysis of this box is beyond the scope of this essay, or the capacity of this writer. Duff spent a thousand notebook pages on it and couldn’t arrive at a conclusion. But I will hazard a few remarks in light of my earlier contentions.
Franz Boas, as I’ve said, saw this box at the end of the nineteenth century and showed a sketch of its design to Charles Edenshaw (da.a xiigang), the greatest Haida artist of the era. Edenshaw explained that its four faces represented four iterations of Raven creating the world. He interpreted the different parts of the design in detail, and Boas dutifully recorded these remarks in Primitive Art (“The upper right hand rectangle of the first side he claimed to represent the head of the raven surmounted by the ear; the large eye to the left of it, in the left hand upper corner, the shoulder and under it the wing and tail,” etc.). 37 But Boas, bizarrely, thought the interpretation was nonsense. “Although obtained from Charles Edensaw [sic ], one of the best artists among the Haida,” he writes, “I consider it entirely fanciful.” 38
Why couldn’t Boas accept Edenshaw’s interpretation? He’s surprisingly coy on the matter, but I suspect it has to do, at least on the surface, with the simple fact that Boas, though in general a man of great intellectual open-mindedness, couldn’t make out what Edenshaw was describing. No matter how precise the linguistic description became, Boas could not harmonize it with his own perceptual experience. 39 The box’s four sides with all of their geometric profuseness are meant, says Edenshaw, to be understood as one figure, a figure containing all of its narrative actions and characteristics—perhaps even the world it made—within its bodily boundaries. For Boas, such a cosmic Raven would not emerge from the sea of form.
Perhaps Boas could not understand the philosophy of representation displayed on this box and others like it. A stable perceptual relationship to an image is not the end goal of this art. Instead the painting seems meant to keep us as long as possible in the state at which a distinct shape is just about to emerge, and also always just about to disappear again. Which is not to say that Edenshaw was wrong: personally I see no reason to doubt him. But it may perhaps be said that the artistic styles of the Northwest require of viewers not only an act of recognition, but also that they linger in the process that precedes recognition, that is, in the cognitive zone where they sense someone or something before they determine exactly who or what. A figure is the whole world insofar as any part of the world could, in the blink of an eye, turn into the figure.
Such an aesthetic is fundamentally linked to hunting, to the epistemology of myth, to ceremony and rank, and to orality. The conventions of description that develop alongside it (Charles Edenshaw—carver, chief, hunter, storyteller—saying this is the Raven) are inevitably going to be different from those possible within a textual society, where a picture and its textual description (at the simplest level, its title) are supposed to march hand in hand through the ages (even if in reality the situation is almost never so straightforward). “A mythology is not a fixed body of stories,” writes Robert Bringhurst, “it is an open set. It is a narrative ecology: a watershed, a forest, a community of stories that are born and die and breed with one another and with stories from outside.” 40 We should not imagine that this metamorphic ecology was restricted to verbal artifacts. Objects also moved within a structure of meaning that was constantly reconstituting itself through oral storytelling, performance, gifting, acquisition through purchase or warfare—all of which no doubt in turn influenced the style and content and ceremonial use of future objects. Charles Edenshaw may never have seen that box before, and it may, for all we know, have merely been his intuition that gave rise to his Raven ekphrasis. But even if that’s true, we shouldn’t discount it: for even then it would represent a form of in-the-moment meaning-making, no doubt governed by its own strict and complex rules, constituting a discipline of the intellect that made possible, like during the patient watching of a hunt, the sudden apperception of an animal. Out of that first spark of perceived aliveness came the construction of a narrative, the evocation of a tradition, and the tracing of a cosmology: in fact, the making of the world into what it is.
Raven puts all things in place. He flies over the water and by blundering, goofing, stealing, losing, dropping, and gift-giving, he redistributes life and sustenance, turning an unequal world into a balanced one. His curiosity and nosiness are insatiable and key. He’s always looking under rocks, behind screens or in boxes, stealing whatever he finds there, often turning into the very beings he meets. (When, in the great Haida account given by Skaay of the Ḵ’uuna Ḵiig̱awaay, Raven goes to meet the Old Man of the Sea, this quasi-G̱unakadeit says to him, “You are me, and you are that too,” pointing at “something blue and slim” on the house screen. 41) In many Haida accounts of the creation, human beings emerge when Raven discovers them under a clamshell. Raven is the greatest uncoverer of hidden aliveness, and this is, I think, a more accurate description of his persona than the anthropological archetypes of “creator” or “culture-hero.” A being bumping into beings—like flint on a stone—is the mechanism by which time and space come into existence. Perhaps one of the deep philosophical messages encoded in Haida and Tlingit art is that beings always already stretch across the entire surface of the world, just beneath its membrane, and that the beginning is never an arrival but rather a meeting with what’s already there. This makes living in the world a difficult proposition, requiring delicate negotiations at every turn, for any claim a sentient being stakes out will necessarily overlap with another claim already in place, and the relation between the claims will have to be adjudicated when the two beings meet each other through a curtain of foliage or foam. The arrangement is by no means always harmonious: violence or cunning sometimes puts one class of being temporarily on top. But as often as not, you invite the sea monster or the bear to a feast, and you always know a priori that there is no pure space, no abstract time, no omnipotent stance in relation to the world—even among the gods and spirits. Edenshaw’s description of the box as a cosmogony (rather than, say, as a particular clan’s crest animal or a wealth spirit) may have been his attempt to help Boas understand this worldview, and all of the many flexible but nevertheless binding entailments it expressed.
Without contact between living beings, there is nothing. The point may seem obvious, yet it is pathologically occluded by a colonial ideology that imagines inert resources to be the measure of prestige and power. The first century of white-Native relations in the Northwest was a nightmare paradox of apotheosis and annihilation. There was dizzying prosperity—new sources of wealth, incredible artistic energy, potlatching reaching new heights—and also the terrible depredations of disease, in some places killing off as much as ninety percent of the indigenous population within a generation. 42 In a short time this holocaust would permit whites to take almost all the land and attempt a cultural genocide on those Natives who had survived. The staggering sum of art made during this time, its forms overspreading every surface with emergent beings, may have been an attempt to reiterate and renew a world picture that whites were actively trying to unstitch from the world one law at a time, a world picture that simultaneously found itself at the height of its powers, and on the cusp of devastation. To cover the surfaces of reality with beings who achieve their existence in the sudden, even violent, act of apperception might have been a statement that such beings are not just everywhere, but in some sense every thing. The human relationship to other beings is neither a mere allegory for intrahuman social relations nor an encounter with something completely alien and opposite. Rather, we truly encounter other living beings (including, in some cases, other humans) in tiny bursts of atavistic apperception, bursts in which all the key ethical possibilities (killing or making offerings to, occupying or withdrawing from, starving or feeding, taking or giving away, dominating or submitting to) are entertained and, in an instant, tested. The actions triggered by those pulsations are what make our world. Correct behavior in such key moments should be a central goal of education and maturation—for the integrity of the universe is at stake.
There are many people nowadays who profess an abstract respect for the sentience that surrounds us. But our understanding of that sentience is obscured by an environmentalist sentimentalism that all too often stakes out one of two extreme claims: either it maintains that there is a complete divorce between an idealized nature and a debased humanity, or it proffers a vague and utopian notion that everything is somehow interconnected. 43 In this moment of considerable environmental and political danger, there is an urgent need for everyone (and especially the inheritors of settler colonialism) to study indigenous accounts of the world’s aliveness, to learn something of their sophistication, balance, and even ambivalence. On the Northwest Coast—at least in my no doubt incomplete and preliminary reading—these accounts suggest that the world is created by an imbricated, nested, hidden, appearing-and-disappearing sentience. This sentience is best understood not as inhabiting fixed realms like “the sea” or “the village,” nor as divided into fixed categories like “human” or “animal,” but as arising from sudden flashes of contact, which only afterward produce the structures of meaning by which they can be explained and judged.

Why did Native Americans draw?
Many American Indian art objects are basically intended to perform a service—for example, to act as a container or to provide a means of worship. The particular utilitarian form that Native American arts take often reflects the social organization of the cultures involved.
What animal was most important to the Northwest Native Americans?
One of the most awesome creatures in both real life and in Pacific Northwest Native Indian art is the orca or killer whale. Feared many years ago but now loved by millions of people around the world, the killer whale is one of the most prominent subjects for Northwest Native artists.
What animals did the Northwest hunt?

What animal was important to West Coast tribes?
Hunting, both on land and sea, was also an important source of food. At sea this involved hunting whales, sea lion, porpoise, seal and sea otter, while deer, moose and elk were pursued on land. The plentiful supply of all these animals meant that the tribes became prosperous.
What is Pacific Northwest art called?
Northwest Coast art is the term commonly applied to a style of art created primarily by artists from Tlingit, Haida, Heiltsuk, Nuxalk, Tsimshian, Kwakwaka’wakw, Nuu-chah-nulth and other First Nations and Native American tribes of the Northwest Coast of North America, from pre-European-contact times up to the present.
What is the name of the Northwest Coast cultures specific art style?
Northwest Coast Native art is very well known globally, primarily for the monumental totem poles and spectacular masked performances of the First Peoples of the northwestern British Columbia and Alaska.

How did the Northwest tribes use their natural resources?

What did the Northwest tribe eat?

What are a few of the distinctive features of Northwest Coast Aboriginal art?
Wood sculpture and painting, notably totem poles, are the most renowned features of Northwest Coast Indigenous culture. Culture
Culture
The Northwest's abundance of resources allowed indigenous people to develop a rich culture of artistic, religious and ceremonial traditions.

The region's exclusively male artists specialized in distinctive carvings that depicted animal, monster and human forms.  The figures represented supernatural beings whose spirits gave the artist permission to render their likeness.  An animal species was distinguished by one or two prominent
features.  For example, the bear was characterized by a stubby snout, large teeth and a protruding tongue, while the beaver was portrayed with protruding teeth, a cross-hatched tail and a stick between its forepaws.  By borrowing the features of more than one species, a monster could be depicted.  Carvings were painted in red and black and sometimes incorporated into elaborate masks.  When white people introduced iron tools, totem poles were created.  These tall, cylindrical objects were carved from a tree trunk and indicated their owners' prestige.

The religion of the Northwest Native Americans was closely tied to nature.  They believed that animal and human lives were inextricably intertwined.  Animals were intelligent, willful beings and should be treated with respect.  Other beliefs involved an afterlife, which was a continuation of earthly life, a sense of the natural order as slippery and fluid, and various myths that explained creation.  Shamans were important to the religion and cured disease by realigning spiritual elements.  Shamans honed their skills by going on frequent retreats and practicing sexual and dietary abstinence.

Much ritual activity focused on food.  For example, an elaborate salmon festival was held to honor the first catch of the year.  The fish were treated as chiefs of high rank in the hope that their souls would spread the news of their good fortune and attract other fish to be harvested.  Another key ceremony was the hamatsa dance.  Performed by the Kwakiutl tribe in the winter, the ritual dealt with the hamatsa, a human who had been carried off by spiritual beings.  After learning the ways of the spirits, the hamatsa escaped and returned to the human realm, only to find that human expression was too weak for his new divine energy.  The dance depicted the hamatsa going berserk, requiring a dozen tribe members to restrain him.  Though Potlatches were more secular by nature, they were also important rituals that dealt with wealth and social organization.

The Art of the Northwest Coast American Indians

The Art of the Northwest Coast American Indians
November is Native American Heritage Month, so this month, I will be dedicating the whole month of posts to Native American artworks!
I’m going to start the series with some of my favorite art objects from the native cultures from the Northwest Coast of North America.
More than 16 nations make up this grouping including Tlingit, Haida, Heiltsuk, Nuxalk, Tsimshian, and Kwakwaka’wakw. Although each group has it’s own unique culture and art, they do share some commonalities, and I am highlighting some of the art forms that cross between many of the groups.
The Northwest coast has rich forests, rivers, and rocky coastlines. Their art reflected this environment. Much of their art was created with the abundant trees from the area and featured animals found in the forests, rivers, and oceans such as eagles, beavers, whales, wolves, ravens, frogs, and bears.
These animals had special meanings and symbols and individual clans had animals associated with their clan. For example, whales symbolize ancient wisdom and awareness, beavers stand for creative and artistic ability, and frogs symbolize spring and new life.
Some of the Northwest Coast groups incorporated these animals onto totem poles, which are super tall sculptures made from the trunk of a tree, usually cedar. The designs usually include stacks of stylized animals done in an abstract and bold way.
** Read more … See my post about Tlingit totem poles.
Photo Credit: Ryan Bushby
The totem poles were often in front of long, narrow houses where up to 50 people from the same clan lived all together. These houses were also decorated in bold abstract animal designs as well. Totems represent the history of the clan/family. In addition to the special symbolism of the animals, the colors have special meanings as well.
On my trip to NYC in the summer of 2014, I discovered Kwakiutl transformation masks at the American Museum of Natural History. I found them to be so intriguing and like nothing I had seen before. The masks are interactive: beaks would be attached to strings to make it open and close making a loud clacking noise, masks could open up to then display a different character, or mouths could be removed and replaced with mouths with additional expressions. So. Very. Cool.
These masks were used in different types of ceremonies, and each Native American group might use them in a different way.
Met Museum
Another interesting art form from this area is a Haida button blanket. The Haida artists sewed stylized animal designs and pieces of shell to simple wool blankets brought by European traders. These were worn during ceremonies and other special events. Often, the wearer would have a blanket design that represented his or her clan’s signature animal.
Of course, that is not all of the art from the Northwest coast! I have chosen a few art forms to highlight, but there is also basketry, pottery, boats, carved objects, and more.

Northwest Coast Indian - Technology and the visual arts | Britannica
Technology and the visual arts
The indigenous peoples of the Northwest Coast drew from the heavily wooded environment for much of their technology. Woodworking was facilitated by the abundance of easily worked species of trees, especially the giant arborvitae (Thuja plicata, also known as red cedar) and the redwood (Sequoia sempervirens ). The trunks of these trees could be split into planks or hollowed out into canoes, containers, and other useful objects.
Discover wood-carving traditions handed down from past generations of the Northwest Coast Indian peoples
Traditional wood carving of the Northwest Coast Indians.
Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc. See all videos for this article
The peoples of this region were noted for their artistic skill, and many everyday items were decorated in some way. More than most other groups in North America, Northwest Coast visual arts emphasized symmetry, neatness of finish, and embellishment through carving and painting. Traditional carving implements included adzes, mauls, wedges, chisels, drills, and curved knives, all made of stone; sharkskin was used for sanding or polishing wooden items.

Native American: The Northwest Coast
This culture area is bounded on the west by the Pacific Ocean and on the east by the Coast Range, the Sierra Nevada, and the Rocky Mountains;...
As far south as the Columbia River, wooden boxes were made of red cedar boards that were kerfed—cut nearly through transversely. The wood was steamed at these points until it was flexible enough to shape into the form of a box. Dishes often were hollowed out of pieces of wood, sometimes plain, sometimes in the form of animals or monsters. Other items made of wood included spoons and ladles, canoe bailers, trinket boxes, chamber pots, masks and rattles used in ceremonies, magnificent memorial or totem poles and interior house posts, housefronts and screens, halibut hooks, and even the triggers of animal traps. Sometimes items were made from the horns of mountain goats, bighorn sheep, or elk, which were carved by essentially the same methods as wood. Occasionally sculptures were carved from stone.
Haida headdress
Haida headdress, painted wood, swan's down, and abalone, c. 1870; in the Denver Art Museum.
Courtesy of the Denver Art Museum, Colorado
Artists in the northern province emphasized low-relief carving accented by painting; their motifs were the hereditary crests of the clans or parts of the crests. Different groups in the northern province expressed themselves in somewhat different styles. Haida art, for instance, tended to be massive and to comprise highly conventionalized balanced elements. In Tsimshian carving and painting, there was an effort to leave no open space in or between the conventionalized motifs; filler elements such as eye designs and miniature figures were used intensively. Tlingit art was slightly less conventionalized, with relatively little use of filler elements.
Haida argillite carving
Haida argillite carving, c. 1890, depicting a folktale in which the Bear Mother endures a cesarean birth; in the National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Haye Centre, Smithsonian Institution, New York City.
Courtesy of the Museum of the American Indian, Heye Foundation, New York
In the Wakashan province, representative art was frankly sculptural, impressionistic, and bold. There was a limited amount of simple geometric design on such things as whalebone clubs and whaling harpoon barbs. Their Coast Salish neighbours used some, but less, representative art, similar if looser in style. On Puget Sound there was little representative art; the abstract painted designs on the canoe boards were unlike anything else in the region. Most traditional Chinook art is represented by just a few angular figures incised on mountain sheephorn bowls. In the southernmost part of the culture area, in northwestern California, art generally focused on geometric patterns incised on elkhorn objects and shells. (See also arts, Native American .)
totem poles
Memorial (totem) poles from different tribes stand in Stanley Park, Vancouver.
© Alan Kearney/FPG International
Weaving was also highly developed. The inner bark of red cedar was stripped, and the long ribbonlike strands were woven into mats and baskets, using a checkerwork technique. The same material could be shredded into finely divided flexible hanks, which were twined together to make a slip-on rain cape shaped like a truncated cone. The softer inner bark of yellow cedar was made into robes. Persons of high status wore robes made of or edged with strips of sea otter fur and yarn made of the wool of mountain goats. Salish groups near the Georgia Strait wove robes of mountain goat wool and also of wool from a special breed of shaggy dog. The Chilkat, a Tlingit group, wove robes and basketry, applying various twilling techniques to fabric and basketry alike. Their blankets bore representations of crests in blue, yellow, black, and white.
Karok twined basket
Karok twined basket, c. 1890; in the Denver Art Museum.
Courtesy of the Denver Art Museum, Colorado
Twined basketry made from long flexible splints split from spruce roots illustrated great technical skill. Baskets so tightly woven as to be waterproof were made for cooking in northern and northwestern California; their contents were boiled by placing hot stones into the soup or potage within the basket. Storage containers, receptacles for valuables large and small, and rain hats were also woven. The Coast Salish specialty was coiled baskets.
Dress patterns of the area were fairly simple, and, although ceremonial garments and some hats could be highly embellished, most clothing was worn for protection from the environment rather than for ostentatious display. Both women and men customarily wore some combination of necklaces, earrings, nose rings, bracelets, and anklets; these were made of various materials, mostly shells, copper, wood, and fur. Some individuals rubbed grease and ochre onto their skin to produce a red colour, often accented with black; tattooing was also practiced. Throughout the region women wore skirts or gowns of buckskin, soft leather, or woven wool or plant fibres. Men’s dress varied from tribe to tribe but was in general quite minimal—most men wore nothing but ornaments on warm days. Men of the northernmost Tlingit and the Kitksan of the upper Skeena wore tailored buckskin breechcloths, leggings, and shirts in cold weather; elsewhere they wore robes of yellow cedar bark or pelts in cold weather and rain capes in downpours.
Northwest Coast Indian woman
Tlahleelis, a Northwest Coast Indian woman, probably Kwakiutl, wearing a fringed cloak, c. 1914.
Edward S. Curtis—Edward S. Curtis Collection/Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. (digital. id. cph cph 3b00207)
Kinship and family life
While groups in the northern province tended to be matrilineal—passing status, property, and education through the maternal line—those in the other three provinces were generally patrilineal. Marriages were usually arranged by parents, who openly wished to see their children rise (or at least not fall) in status. As with up-marrying slaves, members of the middle classes of a group could marry up if they had distinguished themselves in some way; the children of these marriages would inherit the status of the higher-ranking spouse. If the spouse of lower rank was not distinguished in some way, the children would accrue the lower status; as this was generally seen as an undesirable outcome, such matches occurred relatively rarely.
An interesting aspect of Northwest Coast culture was the emphasis on teaching children etiquette, moral standards, and other traditions of social import. Every society has processes by which children are taught the behaviour proper to their future roles, but often such teaching is not an overt or deliberate process. On the Northwest Coast, however, particularly northward of the Columbia River, children were instructed formally. This instruction began at an age when children were still in their cradles or toddling, and all elder relatives, particularly grandparents, participated in it. Lessons were often delivered gently and humorously through the telling and retelling of folktales; trickster tales recounting Raven’s exploits were especially entertaining, as his troubles were so obviously the result of his dissolute, lazy, gluttonous, and lecherous personality (see Raven cycle ). Children born to high status were given formal instruction throughout childhood and adolescence. They had to learn not only routine etiquette but also the lengthy traditions by which the rank and privileges of their particular group were validated, including rituals, songs, and formulaic prayers.
Changes in status were generally marked by public ceremonies. Formal rituals were considered necessary at each of two or three critical stages in a person’s lifetime—birth, a girl’s attainment of puberty (there were no boys’ puberty rites in the area), and death—because at those times the participants in these events might be especially vulnerable or so filled with power that they could inadvertently harm others. A newborn infant was believed to be in danger of harm by supernatural beings; the infant’s parents were simultaneously in danger and potentially dangerous. Mystic forms of vulnerability and volatility also accrued to girls at puberty, to the close kin of a deceased person, and to those who prepared and disposed of the dead. Such perils were avoided by isolating the persons involved—either within a boarded-off cubicle in the house or in a simple structure out in the woods—and by limiting their diet to old dried fish and water. At the conclusion of the isolation period, a formal purification ritual was performed. The intensity of the restrictions varied considerably, not only in different parts of the coast but even within individual houses. Often the pubescent daughter of a chief, for example, was secluded for many months, whereas her low-ranking house sister might have to observe only a few days of confinement.
Over most of the coast there was a very great fear of the dead. A body was usually removed from the house through some makeshift aperture other than the door and disposed of as rapidly as possible. An exception occurred in the northern province, where bodies of chiefs were placed in state for several days while clan dirges were sung. Disposal of the dead varied. In the northern province, cremation was practiced. In the Wakashan and part of the Coast Salish areas, large wooden coffins were suspended from the branches of tall trees or placed in rock shelters. Other Coast Salish deposited their dead in canoes set up on stakes. In southwestern Oregon and northwest California, interment in the ground was preferred.
Religion and the performing arts
The religions of the Northwest Coast shared several concepts that provided the widespread bases for various kinds of religious activity.
One concept was that salmon were supernatural beings who voluntarily assumed piscine form each year in order to sacrifice themselves for the benefit of humankind. On being caught, these spirit-beings returned to their home beneath the sea, where they were reincarnated if their bones or offal were returned to the water. If offended, however, they would refuse to return to the river. Hence, there were numerous specific prohibitions on acts believed to offend them and a number of observances designed to propitiate them, chief of which was the first-salmon ceremony. This rite varied in detail but invariably involved honouring the first salmon of the main fishing season by sprinkling them with eagle down, red ochre, or some other sacred substance, welcoming them in a formal speech, cooking them, and distributing their flesh, or morsels of it, communion-fashion, to all the members of the local group and any guests. The maximal elaboration of this rite occurred in northwestern California in what have been called world-renewal ceremonies; these combined first-salmon rituals, first-fruits observances, and dances in which lineage wealth was displayed. Elsewhere the first-salmon rituals were less elaborate but still important, except among the Tlingit, who did not perform them.
Another religious concept was the acquisition of personal power by seeking individual contact with a spirit -being, usually through prayer and a vision. Among Coast Salish all success in life—whether in hunting, woodworking, accumulating wealth, military ventures, or magic—was bestowed by spirit-beings encountered in the vision quest. From these entities each person acquired songs, special regalia, and dances. Collectively, the dances constituted the major ceremonials of the Northwest Coast peoples; known as the spirit dances, they were performed during the winter months.
In the Wakashan and northern provinces, it was believed that remote ancestors who had undertaken vision quests had been rewarded with totemic symbols or crests. Displaying these hereditary crests and recounting the traditions of their acquisition formed an important part of potlatches. In the Wakashan area certain ceremonial cycles called for the dramatization of the whole tale of the supernatural encounter, which in some cases included the spirit-being’s possession of and its eventual exorcism from the seeker; such dramas were performed by dancing societies.
Shamanism differed from other acquisitions of supernatural power only in the nature of the power obtained—that is, power to heal the sick through extraction of disease objects or recovery of a strayed soul (see soul loss ). It was commonly believed that some shamans, or medicine men and women, had the power to cause infirmities as well as to cure them. Witchcraft was used to kill others or to make them ill and was believed to be carried out by malicious persons who knew secret rituals for that purpose (see witchcraft: Witchcraft in Africa and the world ).

Daily Life - Northwest Coast
Daily Life
The Northwest Coast People caught many fish to store for food in the winter.
The fishing nets are a quite common source to go fishing on the bay.
The canoes were generally close to the longhouses.
Their clothing was highly decorated with beautiful designs.
Many people could fit into a single canoe.
Food & Water
The Northwest Coast Peoples' main source of food was fish that includes salmon, halibut, herring, and cod. Other seafood was; crabs, oysters, clams, mussels, seaweed, fish eggs, and occasionally whale. They also ate berries, cranberries, huckleberries, and salal berries that were dried and stored in oil to keep preserved for the winter. Their water were held in "bent boxes" or "property boxes". Those boxes were also used for cooking. Another cooking method would be to roast over a fire or in a large pot in the ground that they added very hot rocks to boil the water. The food would then be wrapped in leaves.
Hunting/Fishing
As you can tell, the Northwest Coast People had a lot of fishing experience. You may wonder, "how did they actually catch the fish?" They used nets and underwater traps as well as bone and wood hooks and harpoons. The fish lines were made from cedar. The People also hunted many things including; black-tailed deer, elk, mountain goat, and bear. They used bows and arrows, snares, and harpoons to kill these wild animals.
Shelter
The Northwest Coast People don't live by themselves. There were several families that could add up to 40-60 people in one longhouse that were build from cedar. To decide what room you had, the more power you had, the bigger room you got. The roof was supported by four sturdy interior posts at the four corners. To keep warmth there were no windows and only one small entrance. Inside there were cedar or bulrush mats and a fire in the middle of a room used for heat, light and cooking. The smoke from the fire would exit to the outside from a hole in the center of the roof.
Clothing
Their clothing was made from
bark of cedar tree. No, not the hard gnarled bark on the outside. It’s the soft thin bark underneath of that. The process isn’t the same for yellow and red cedar. For yellow cedar they soak it in cold water and then hot water until soft, then beaten it with a “Bark Beater” which is made from whale bone and had
a handle. After that step they roll the soft cedar between the palms of their hands and their upper leg until it is the right thickness for weaving. On the other hand, red cedar is not soaked. It is just split when dry, then twisted or shredded until soft. All of this hard work turns out in the end to make beautiful cedar bark capes, skirts, rainproof hats, a “Chilkat Blanket, which is worn by a high ranked person. They also wear robes of sea otter and other furs to show power.
Transportation
There was only one main source of transportation. Canoes. They were made from cedar trees and some of them could hold 30 or more people!
Trade/Economy
There was a lot of trade in the Northwest Coast. In fact, trading happened for 10000 years. That was long before the arrival of the Europeans.

Target employees say store doesnt stop all shoplifters, – Business Insider
A viral TikTok video is calling Target’s approach to shoplifters into question.
Seven former and current Target employees across the US confirmed that it is common for the retailer to not immediately apprehend certain shoplifters and wait for the total value of the stolen items to reach a certain amount.
Some said that this policy helps Target monitor and catch its high volume shoplifters on larger charges. A loss prevention expert said that retailers might not report every minor theft incident in order to maintain a good relationship with local police.
“We don’t have any policies in place to hold or bundle shoplifting charges until they reach a felony level,” a Target spokesperson said in a statement.
Visit Business Insider’s homepage for more stories.
At a Target in Las Vegas, the store’s approach to shoplifting has caused one former employee to speak out.
Isaiah Arellano, a former Target employee who worked at a North Dakota Target location in 2016, and transferred to a Las Vegas location in 2018, recently went viral on TikTok for his video explaining how Target addresses its shoplifters.
“They will continue letting you steal, all the while they’re documenting the value amount of every single item that you are stealing,” said Arellano in the video. “They will wait until it reaches or exceeds the amount that makes it grand theft larceny, which is an actual felony.”
The parameters that classify the degree of a theft charge vary across different states. For example, in Nevada, the stolen property must exceed $1,200 in value for the charge to go from misdemeanor to felony. In general, to be charged with grand theft or larceny, a person must be suspected of stealing more than what would constitute a charge of petty theft, a more minor theft charge with less serious repercussions.
Arellano’s video was a response to another TikTok from influencer Dessy Joseph. In her original video, Joseph described Target’s policy of monitoring repeat shoplifters and waiting for them to accumulate a higher value of stolen merchandise before taking action against them. In Arellano’s video, he says, “She is 100% telling the truth.”  His TikTok has racked up more than 8 million views since it was posted on November 27. Arellano has over 28,000 followers.
Arrellano told Business Insider he felt confident speaking out about this after working in two different Target locations and seeing how they operated.
“If we saw somebody acting suspicious, it wasn’t up to us to confront them,” he said.
In a statement to Business Insider, a Target spokesperson said the company does not “bundle” charges until they reach a felony-level and would not provide details about the company’s procedures for handling theft.
“We don’t have any policies in place to hold or bundle shoplifting charges until they reach a felony level,” a Target spokesperson said in a statement.
“At Target, we prioritize the safety and well-being of our guests, team members and the communities we serve,” the statement continued. “Like most retailers, we have security practices, training, and technology in place to address shoplifting in our stores.”
However, according to at the six other former and current Target employees Business Insider spoke to across Minnesota, Michigan, Virginia, New York, and California, the claims in the video are based on actual store policies.
Target headquarters monitors crime
Target’s “asset protection team members,” or the retailer’s in-store security team, are responsible for monitoring and preventing theft in stores. According to a former employee who worked in asset protection in a Minnesota store until July, shoplifting is usually addressed right away in the store unless the situation is deemed too dangerous.
However, this employee added that there are instances where Target might decline to apprehend a shoplifter because of a general strategy the retailer has when it comes to tracking theft.
“Headquarters tracks the people who are impacting the stores the most,” this former Minnesota Target employee told Business Insider in an email interview. “Sometimes we are told to only collect information but do not apprehend. This is because a Target Investigator is working with law enforcement to press charges and get these people arrested for a long time.”
The reason for this, this former employee said, is to put a stop to the high-volume shoplifters who are a serious threat to the store. If such individuals are only arrested on minor charges, they’ll likely return and continue to steal.
“The people that Target waits to build a case on are not your run of the mill shoplifter; these are professional thieves,” the former Minnosota employee said, relating his own experience of seeing the same person sent to jail for minor thefts multiple times, only to see him continue to steal.
“Most of the people get cited and released,”  he said. “These high impact people do not care if they get arrested.”
A current employee in a New York Target said the asset protection employees often track Target’s “career shoplifters” and “have a binder full of people” with evidence of theft.
These employees, like most that were interviewed for this story, were granted anonymity in order to speak more frankly about the policies at Target.
Maintaining a relationship with police
With online marketplaces allowing criminals to surreptitiously unload a high volume of stolen goods online, organized theft has lately become more common in a retail setting, explained Jason Brewer, the executive vice president of communications for the Retail Industry Leaders Association (RILA).
“This trend has accelerated during COVID, and stores are often dealing with more brazen, and sometimes violent attempts at stealing mass quantities of merchandise,” Brewer said. “Loss prevention tactics and strategies are designed to mitigate this alarming trend, and protect employees and customers.”
General practices in loss prevention suggest that documenting theft and waiting to apprehend may have something to do with maintaining a positive relationship with local police.
When operating a big-box store, building a relationship with local police is essential, explained retail loss prevention and security expert John Hassard. While some police departments might be happy to prosecute every instance of theft across the spectrum, many police departments are often swamped with heavier crimes. According to Hassard, it is up to a retailer to determine which crimes are worthy of a call to the police to ensure that justice is able to be maintained in the most efficient way.
“It’s not typical to call the police in retail when you’ve suffered a loss and you don’t have a person,” said Hassard, explaining why a retailer might undergo a process of documenting and tracking multiple thefts from one individual.
Hassard, who has close to 30 years of experience in loss prevention, said it is up to the retailer to determine how they will go about prosecuting criminal activity in its stores — and if and when it is the right time to call the police.
“There are retailers that say, ‘We won’t call a police if we catch a shoplifter who has below X amount of dollars,'” he explained. This can change depending on the retailer and location of the store.
AP
Tracking employees
According to at least three former and current Target employees, Target also tracks shoplifting among its employees and will often wait to apprehend employees who are stealing.
“Target watches employees for theft more than they do customers,” said a former Target employee who left his job in April of 2018 after 17 years at Target. “They’re easier targets and a lot less risk.”
A former Target employee in Virginia who left his job in early 2018 said he witnessed management track an employee who was stealing in 2017. In this case, he said, the store manager was aware of a co-worker who was pilfering items from the storeroom for about six months.
“Seemingly out of nowhere he was arrested at work under the accusation of grand larceny,” the former Target employee said. The asset protection leader later told this employee the store had been documenting every stolen item and collecting security footage for months, he said.
In the Las Vegas Target where Arrellano worked he experienced the same thing, he said.
‘Let them build their own case up’
As a cashier, Arrellano was instructed not to intervene in suspected thefts and instead notify asset protection over the radio, he said. As an employee at the in-store Starbucks, Arrellano was privy to the stories and “work gossip” from the asset protection workers who stopped by the coffee shop.
In his conversations with asset protection employees, Arrellano learned that the philosophy was to “Let them build their own case up,” and wait for multiple documented cases against a shoplifter.
“It was a lot more worth their time if they could prosecute for thousands versus a hundred dollars,” he said.
The policy felt “strange,” to Arellano, but he felt that he couldn’t say anything while working at Target. “I didn’t think it was right. Luckily they didn’t make me sign an NDA,” he said.

Why Target Is the Worst Store to Shoplift From
Dan  Kahan
January 29 | 2020
Target
Despite the fact that late-stage capitalism is an amoral hellhole driven by a borderline religious belief in the sanctity of brands, we would never, ever suggest that anyone should shoplift from big-box stores, or even imply that doing so is a victimless crime and morally fine.
But hypothetically, if we were to give any tidbit of advice to any would-be shoplifters (aside from the Golden Rule that you never, ever steal from mom-and-pop shops or individuals just trying to make a living), it would be this: Avoid shoplifting from Target.
While loss prevention technology has certainly ramped up over the past decade, the truth is that the vast majority of one-off shoplifters don't get caught. The majority of shoplifters who eventually get apprehended are "the clunky ones who get just good enough to evade detection for a while until they get too greedy and too braggy," as Target manager Dan Holliday explains.
By nature, working as a loss prevention officer (LP) is one of the most dangerous retail-related jobs a person can have. Every customer apprehension poses the potential risk of the situation turning violent, which is why the vast majority of stores implement "No Touch" policies for their LPs, whereby LPs are not allowed to get physical with, and sometimes even not allowed to pursue, suspects. Moreover, even if an LP suspects a person of shoplifting, stopping a customer without solid proof can open the store up to a lawsuit (especially if the customer is innocent).
But unlike Walmart and Best Buy, whose loss prevention officers (LPs) barely get paid enough to care––let alone risk their own safety––Target takes loss prevention very seriously. In fact, Target runs one of country's top-rated forensic laboratories, which specializes in solving "organized retail crimes committed at Target stores through video and image analysis, latent fingerprint and computer forensics."
Retail Stores Sales, Newport, USA - 23 Nov 2018 John Minchillo/AP/REX/Shuttersto
Scarier, though, is the methodical way in which Target goes about building cases against repeat shoplifters. In a 2016 Reddit post, a user named StiggyPop recounted his experience of being a drug-addict who made money by stealing and flipping Blu-Rays from Target. After four months, he was apprehended by a team of high-level LPs who knew everything about him, from where his apartment was located to the specific store he used as a fence (a middleman for stolen goods who acts as a "fence" between thieves and unknowing buyers).
Other Reddit users shared similar stories. As it turns out, alongside their forensic team and top-of-the-line, in-store facial recognition technology, Target is known for actually letting shoplifters get away with their bounty...up until they reach the monetary threshold for a felony shoplifting charge. This means that while a Walmart LP will stop a shoplifter regardless of whether they're stealing a $5 DVD or a $500 dollar TV, Target might allow a shoplifter to steal 100 $5 DVDs over time, all while building up a massive, fool-proof felony case against them. And here's the craziest part––they organize these efforts across stores and even state-lines. Essentially, if you steal at any Target, anywhere in the country, they're quite possibly building up a case against you.
So if by chance you have the urge to shoplift, keep yourself safe and avoid Target at all costs. There are plenty of other big-box chains out there that don't deserve your business.

Arrested for Retail Fraud from Target
by Hilf & Hilf, PLC
Target stores take an aggressive approach to apprehending suspected shoplifters.  The reason for this is to deter shoplifting, reduce losses, and to protect the merchandise.  What specifically does Target do to address retail fraud:
First, Target prosecutes for shoplifting.  There are no warnings.  There is no mercy.   The employees involved with the theft investigation testify in courtrooms, when necessary. Target actively bans people from their stores with no trespassing orders who it suspects of  shoplifting.  Target has a civil law firm seek civil law settlements and judgments for damages.
Second, the store employs asset protection/loss prevention personnel that are well trained.  Technology is used to help the loss prevention team, such as closed circuit television, theft detection devices, and store designs to eliminate blind spots.  The loss prevention personnel have specialized training to identify behaviors of shoppers that suggest that they may commit some form of theft.  Target tries to identify known shoplifters so that loss prevention is alerted whenever such a suspect enters the store so that they can be watched closely.
Third, the sales personnel are also well trained.  They alert loss prevention or management when they see something suspicious.  Dressing rooms are frequently checked.
Fourth, when a person is apprehended on suspicion of retail theft, they are questioned about the incident in an attempt to gain a confession.  Loss prevention, unlike police officers, are not required to provide Miranda rights.  The recovered merchandise is documented.  Videos are preserved.  All of the evidence – the loss prevention reports; the suspect’s statements, store video, photographs of merchandise, etc., are given to the police officers once they respond to the scene.   Target makes it easy for a police officer to file a report.  Target makes it easy for a prosecutor to go forward with a prosecution.
Even though Target attempts to do a thorough investigation, mistakes sometimes occur.  The fact that the desk for customer service is so close to the exit sometimes is a source for confusion and error.  Not everyone detained or arrested for retail fraud is guilty.
Experience matters when it comes to the defense of retail fraud cases.  Not every criminal defense lawyer has the knowledge and ability to properly defend retail fraud accusations.
Even in cases where guilt is apparent, an experienced criminal defense lawyer that specializes in retail fraud cases is a necessity.  The quality of legal representation is often the difference between jail and no jail.  It makes a difference when trying to obtain a charge reduction or a status in the law to keep the offense off your record.
Retail fraud convictions can have life altering consequences: it can affect your reputation; it can prevent you from obtaining certain jobs and pursuing certain careers; it can effect your ability to obtain loans/grants/assistance.  It can effect your ability to travel.  To individuals that are not United States citizens, it can affect your ability to remain in the United States, or return if you ever leave the country.
Make the smart decision and hire the right lawyer.  For all retail fraud cases I recommend the services of Attorney Daniel Hilf of the law firm Hilf & Hilf, PLC.
