When It Comes to Taylor Swift’s Outlook on Love, Everything Has Changed
It makes sense that as Swift matures, so would her attitude toward of love. But is her cynicism really the mark of that evolution?
By Molly Flynn, University of North Carolina at Charlotte
I’ve always identified with music and songwriting. When I was a young and hyperemotional tweenaged girl, I would look to the pen and paper to express my feelings of heartache over silly little twelve-year-old boys who liked my sister better than me. I still, to this day, have notebooks piled high of documented embarrassing crushes—yikes. So, being a self-proclaimed songwriter, I idolized Taylor Swift, who seemed to understand exactly what I was experiencing as I navigated my way through discovering what love meant.
Image via Pop Crush
I related so intimately to Taylor’s music that I had a boy that came to mind when listening to “Teardrops on My Guitar,” and the only thing that was different about my crush and the boy in “Hey Stephen” was the name. When I went through my first break up, “White Horse” was my anthem, and when my best friend got pregnant at 14, I ached with the song “Fifteen” and could feel the lyrics pressing into my soul. It’s encouraging to have someone understand you when you’re growing up and speak to the struggles you’re facing. For me, Taylor Swift was that encourager.
And like me, Taylor Swift grew up. In many ways, this is a very good thing. I left those old silly crushes behind, learned to be much more independent and—praise the lord—I no longer own corduroy pants. Taylor has also gone through some important changes, too. Her style has matured, her lyrics have become deeper and she totally rocks the bob! However, her portrayal of love has also drastically changed. With her most recent album, “1989,” the public and media were concerned with her transition from the traditional “country” genre and into an era of pop, but my concern was less with stylistic choices and more with the ideology behind her music.
Taylor pioneered through different albums like “Speak Now” and “Fearless,” but as she approached her album “Red,” a change began in the way she spoke about love. In her earlier childish music, Swift romanticized love and break-ups. Heartache was a beautiful melody that connected her to her listeners. I remember when I was a freshman in high school, and my first boyfriend broke up with me at my house while my family had a huge group of friends over. I snuck up to the flat roof of my country home and looked at the vast sky speckled with stars.
You might also like:
Why You Shouldn’t Judge an Album by Its Cover
While I was sad, I was also existentially connected to Taylor Swift. She knew this feeling and was able to help me savor the emotion of heartache, because when your heart is broken, you know that the vulnerability you exchanged in the relationship had the potential of turning into love. However, as “Red” was released, vulnerability transformed from a quality Taylor cherished into one that she rejected. She became more of a realist in her lyrics, proclaiming that “We are never ever ever getting back together” and exposing her foolishness in the anthem “I Knew you Were Trouble.” Love, to Taylor, became synonymous with recklessness and treachery.
Another important change that began to reveal itself in “Red” was Taylor’s changing ideology around the concept of forever. In the past, she believed in the permanence of love, but with her coming-of-age album, she lost the belief in love’s longevity.
In her song “Never Getting Back Together,” Taylor proclaimed this worldview with her lyric, “I used to think that we were forever and ever.” No longer did Taylor believe in forever and ever.
While we started seeing the change in the “Red” album, Taylor’s cynical worldview really came to fruition in the “1989” album. No longer did she write songs about the cute boy driving her around the small town in his truck. Her lyrics became darker, dirtier, more sensual. She became less concerned about love and more concerned with lust and temporality. When I first heard her new album, I was going through a break up, just as I was four years before on my star-spangled rooftop. But her songs this time, rather than encourage me that love would find me again, promised me that love was overrated and eternally painful. Heartache was no longer a necessary part of love, but rather a foolish part of ignorance.
While “Red” began to question the idea of forever, “1989” completely threw it away. In “ Wildest Dreams ,” Taylor didn’t think the relationship in question was going to last—in fact, there was never an intention of the relationship lasting. In her first verse she proclaimed, “Nothing lasts forever.” In the bridge, she continued with the theme, saying, “Someday when you leave me.” It makes sense in this particular song that forever is not an option, because in the music video, it is revealed that this man who she is tangled up with all night is married. Not only has Taylor entered into a world of love being temporary, but also of marriage being moot.
You might also like:
Taylor Swift and the Songs That Led Her to Her ‘Lover,’ Joe Alwyn
Image via CBS News
However, “Wildest Dreams” is not the most cynical of her newer songs. In her song “Blank Space,” Taylor revealed her newfound ideology of love. There is a stark contrast between her earlier lyrics and some of the lyrics in this song like, “You look like my next mistake. Love’s a game. Wanna play?” Rather than embracing heartbreak, love and true emotion, Taylor rejected these feelings and traded them for a shallow replacement. She continued her cynical rant in this song through positing, “Boys only want love if its torture,” and “I’m dying to see how this one ends.” No more teardrops for Taylor, only making bad boys good for a weekend.
Let me clarify: This is not written out of animosity towards T. I love her, and I secretly know all the words to all of her songs—even the not-so-great ones about love. And this is not to caution you against listening to her music—seriously, who doesn’t like to shake it off every now and then? But, as she has grown up, she has compromised her innocent understanding of and giddiness toward love.
Some people might argue that this is inevitable as we age. That cute boy who wrote love notes in your seventh grade science class is now a lot taller and also a lot less inclined to write us a sappy note. He might swipe right on Tinder and buy us a drink, but let’s be honest, he probably won’t be asking us to the dance any time soon.
You might also like:
How Pizza Points to a Collab Between Taylor Swift and the Jonas Brothers
How do we then transition from a time in which we over-romanticized love to a time in which we condemn it outright? Should we follow in Taylor’s footsteps and stop believing in forever? I don’t think the answer is that simple. I do believe, however, that Taylor might not be on the right track—not the platinum-award-winning track, but the track to truly finding love.
Why should we care about Taylor’s evolution from romantic to cynic? I am not claiming to believe in indoctrination theory or the idea of the hypodermic needle, because I don’t think it’s that linear. Watching one aggressive television show won’t make you an aggressive individual, just like listening to one T Swift tune from her newer albums won’t make you a cynic about love; but, I do believe it is important to critically engage with the messages we expose ourselves to—especially messages around fundamental things like love.
While Taylor Swift might be great to jam to every now and then, I will no longer be using her music for relationship education. I do still believe in forever and I do still believe in marriage and while I wish Taylor and I could be “Forever & Always.”

Abstract
With rapid population growth, especially in low-income and middle-income countries, the generation of waste is increasing at an unprecedented rate. For example, annual global waste arising from waste electrical and electronic equipment alone will have increased from 33.8 to 49.8 million tonnes between 2010 and 2018. Despite incineration and other waste treatment techniques, landfill still dominates waste disposal in low-income and middle-income countries. There is usually insufficient funding for adequate waste management in these countries and uptake of more advanced waste treatment technologies is poor. Without proper management, many landfills represent serious hazards as typified by the landslide in Shenzhen, China on 20 December 2015. In addition to formal waste recycling systems, approximately 15million people around the world are involved in informal waste recycling, mainly for plastics, metals, glass and paper. This review examines emerging public health challenges, in particular within low-income and middle-income countries, associated with the informal sector. While informal recyclers contribute to waste recycling and reuse, the relatively primitive techniques they employ, combined with improper management of secondary pollutants, exacerbate environmental pollution of air, soil and water. Even worse, insufficient occupational health measures expose informal waste workers to a range of pollutants, injuries, respiratory and dermatological problems, infections and other serious health issues that contribute to low life expectancy. Integration of the informal sector with its formal counterparts could improve waste management while addressing these serious health and livelihood issues. Introduction
With rapidly increasing populations and unprecedented urbanisation rates, waste generation is growing rapidly, particularly in cities and especially in low-income and middle-income countries. Effective waste management, especially of toxic material, is a major challenge for global sustainable development. 1 A range of methods are available for the disposal or treatment of waste including landfill, incineration, composting and recycling. Landfill remains the most widely used approach in the low-income and middle-income world due to its low cost. However, improper management can result in major health and environmental problems. Particular emerging hazards are dangerous and poorly managed landfill slides. 2 For example, management failures led to the collapse of a landfill in Shenzhen, China on 20 December 2015 that killed 73 people. 3 4 A similar collapse in Bandung, Java, Indonesia, in February 2005 was responsible for 140 deaths. 5
The formal, government-funded, sector is responsible for most waste collection and treatment services in high-income countries. However, in many low-income and middle-income nations limited resources means that the formal sector cannot keep pace with rapid expansion of waste production. The informal sector (the so-called waste pickers and scavengers in some countries) has grown as a result. Informal waste recyclers collect, transport and trade waste in almost all low-income and middle-income countries. 6 It is estimated that the informal waste sector supports around 15 million people, particularly within large and relatively wealthy cities. 7
Informal waste recyclers are subsistence workers using relatively primitive technologies to process and recycle a wide variety of waste material from food waste to heavy metals. They can play a key role in recycling material but poor regulation often results in increased environmental pollution through release of an array of secondary pollutants. 8 Insufficient occupational health exposes informal waste recyclers to a host of health damaging factors. 4 With rapid urbanisation and the diversification of waste, especially waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE), health risks facing informal waste recyclers from toxins is increasing. These concerns are exemplified by growing health-related problems facing waste workers in Guiyu, South China, the so-called ‘electronics graveyard of the world’. 9
Some studies of informal waste recyclers 10–12 and WEEE 13–15 have been undertaken while plastic waste pollution, particularly microplastics, have received more attention recently. 16 17 The current study focuses on important emerging public health challenges facing informal recyclers, particularly in low-income and middle-income countries. It also outlines the future challenges for the informal waste sector.
Increasing waste production with growing populations and expanding urbanisation
Waste is continuously generated by human activities. Sources of solid waste include industry, construction, commerce, the services and domestic sectors and individual households. The nature of the waste generated will vary from location to location and through time in response to the dominant human activities taking place. It is estimated that globally approximately 11 billion tonnes of solid waste were produced in 2011. 18 Increasing populations, rapid urbanisation and economic development in low-income and middle-income countries mean that waste production is increasing at an unparalleled rate. China and India are the most populous low-income and middle-income countries and waste problems in their urban and periurban areas are among the most acute. Municipal solid waste frequently exceeds society’s capacity for safe management. 19 Expanding urban infrastructure, for example, roads, bridges and rapid transport systems are generating increasing volumes of construction and demolish wastes (CDW). For example, 87 000 m 3 of CDW was produced during construction of Futian station, Asia’s largest underground station, in Shenzhen, China, the city where the calamitous landfill slide occurred in 2015. 3
Rapid development of information and communications technology 17 means that, globally, WEEE is one of the fastest growing wastes. 20 In 2014, around 42 million tonnes of WEEE was generated worldwide. 21 Despite low average per capita WEEE generation of only 3.7 kg/year, Asia was the largest continental contributor, accounting for nearly 38% of global WEEE (16 million tonnes in 2014). While between 2010 and 2018 the global population is projected to have increased by around 8%, total and per capita WEEE generation are set to grow by approximately 47% and 34%, respectively (figure 1 ). 21 The severity of problems associated with WEEE disposal is creating both governmental and the public concern around the world.

Worldwide plastics and polymer consumption has grown at an average rate of 10% per year since the 1990s. 17 Rates of increase are particularly large in low-income and middle-income economies. Lack of funding within rapidly expanding cities of many low-income and middle-income countries results in extensive informal waste recycling. In contrast to the formal sector, informal waste recycling is undertaken without government financial support and may not be recognised by the public as providing a valuable service. 23
In common with formal waste management, the informal sector comprises players at the different stages of waste recycling (figure 2 ). 17 For example, waste pickers choose and collect valuable items from locally sourced household, commercial and industrial waste or from waste imported from overseas. Although informal waste recycling is not usually recognised as a legal occupation in many countries, it provides large societal benefits in terms of waste management and lessening pressure on resources used in the production of material goods. 24

Of the estimated that >15 million people involved in informal waste recycling, mostly are in low-income and middle-income countries. 7 China has the largest number 11 25 and between 0.6% and 0.9% of the urban population, or 3.3–5.6 million people, are involved in informal waste collection and recycling activities in Chinese cities. 11 In Shanghai alone, the informal recycling sector involves nearly 2 00 000 people and accounts for 17%–38% of municipal recycling activities.
Materials recycled by informal waste recyclers
Although there are variations between regions and countries, materials most frequently recycled by the informal sector are paper and cardboard, scrap metal (especially aluminium, steel, tin), glass, plastic (polyethylene terephthalate (PET)) bottles, rubber, wood, textiles and food waste. 6 Metal, paper and PET are usually preferred due to their large recycling potential and long life spans.
WEEE makes up a growing proportion of waste recycled by the informal sector due to the potentially high value of materials that can be recovered. However, recycling methods and poor occupational health means that WEEE poses some of the largest health risks to informal recyclers. 13 Informal WEEE recycling activities are widespread and are undertaken in many places around the world, although toxic exposure patterns vary according to recycling methods and processes. A notorious example of informal WEEE recycling is Guiyu, an agglomerate of four villages in Guangdong, South China (figure 3A ). Since 1995, nearly 6000 family workshops have processed approximately 1.6 million tonnes of WEEE annually. 9 26 Guiyu has become the world’s largest WEEE dismantling and recycling site. Workers manually break open electronics and strip away parts for reuse including chips and valuable metals (figure 3B, C ). Workers ‘cook’ circuit boards to remove chips and burn wires and other plastics to liberate metals such as copper. Highly dangerous acid baths are used along the riverbanks to extract gold from microchips (figure 3D ).

Plastic, especially bottles, is easily collected and sold by informal recyclers. In many cities, for example, Delhi and Beijing, waste plastic trading is well established with many processing units. 17 However, most of this plastic is recycled in a crude manner by informal setups. Elements such as heavy metals, bromine and antimony are added to polymers as pigments, fillers, UV stabilisers and flame retardants. 17 Inappropriate recycling of plastic waste risks contamination by such additives.
Environmental pollution
Crude methods with insufficient environmental protection can generate secondary pollutants. Environmental pollution from informal waste recycling is diverse in toxicants and levels of exposure, contaminating air, water and soil. 27–29 Contamination is widespread and can reach extremely high levels near to informal recycling sites. Toxic heavy metals, for example, lead (Pb) and chromium (Cr), and persistent organic pollutants including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and brominated flame retardants are common contaminants. 13
In Agbogbloshie, a WEEE processing site in Accra, Ghana, the average soil concentrations of Pb (953.21 mg/kg), Cr (296.60 mg/kg), barium (Ba) (627.66 mg/kg) and copper (Cu) (1387.96 mg/kg) far exceed regulatory limits, for example, the worldwide accepted Dutch and Canadian standards. 30 Similarly, in Mandoli, Delhi, India, concentrations of heavy metals, particularly Cu (115.50 mg/kg), Pb (2645.31 mg/kg) and zinc (Zn) (776.84 mg/kg), in surface soil of WEEE recycling sites were much higher than those in reference sites. 31 Concentrations of total monobrominated to heptabrominated diphenyl ether homologues in soils near WEEE dumping sites in Guiyu, China, were 1140 and 1169 µg/kg dry wt, approximately 10–60 times higher than in any other contaminated sites. 14 Cu, Pb and Zn were the most abundant metals and their concentrations exceeded the new Dutch list action values of 190 mg/kg at most sites (table 1 ). 14 This environmental pollution has drawn wide attention and Guiyu has been selected as one of China’s first pilot circular-economy sites to mitigate contamination and improve WEEE recycling. 32

Health issues
A wide range of health issues confronts those involved in the informal waste sector (table 2 ). Working on waste dumps and landfill sites is inherently dangerous and there are frequent accidents including fires, explosions and, as at Shenzhen, debris slides. 4 Most informal waste recyclers do not wear protective equipment such as gloves and boots because of their relatively high costs and lack of risk awareness. Recyclers often prefer to work barehanded for greater tactility but risk sharp trauma 7 especially from glass and hospital waste containing syringes (table 3 ). 24 33 Pickers are often in direct contact with toxic materials as well as human/animal wastes.

Health risks to informal waste workers and their families associated with heavy metals have drawn particular attention. High blood concentrations of lead have been found in recyclers working in landfills. 34 35 Lead and dioxin-related compounds have been discovered in higher concentrations within the breast milk of female waste recyclers. 36 Children and developing fetuses are particularly susceptible to heavy metal effects (figure 3E ). For example, the stillbirth rate in Guiyu was 4.6 times that of control sites, while blood lead concentrations in neonates were 4.8 times the control. 9 Exposure to hazardous plastic additives including brominated flame retardants (BFRs) and heavy metals are all implicated in nervous and reproductive system problems, behavioural changes and cancer. 37
Informal waste workers are also prone to inhaling gaseous emissions, bioaerosols and microorganisms (ie, automobile fumes, dust, and fungal spores). Waste pickers in landfills can be exposed to gas emissions including methane (CH 4) and hydrogen sulfate (H 2 S), as well as vehicular emissions, 38 causing respiratory, dermatological and eye problems. 24 They are also more prone to common illnesses (influenza, bronchitis, ulcers and others), musculoskeletal difficulties and vermin transmitted disease. 33 39
Insanitary working conditions and lack of washing facilities mean that informal waste recyclers can transport toxic materials to their homes and families. 33 40 Waste dumps and landfills are breeding grounds for pathogenic organisms responsible for dengue, leishmaniasis, diarrhoea, typhoid, anthrax, cholera, malaria and a variety of skin disorders (table 2 ).
In addition, most informal waste workers and their families are marginalised and suffer social exclusion. 7 Coupled with financial insecurity, perceived shame and humiliation, this can lead to severe psychological damage 7 which in turn has wide-ranging implications for the local communities.
Measures to improve the well-being of informal waste recyclers
There is a range of policy, economic and industrial hygiene measures that can improve the well-being of informal recyclers. Green chemistry, improved recyclability of products and the removal of toxicants before recycling are fundamentally important. 41 Poverty alleviation through adequate funding of the services provided by informal recyclers is a necessity. Hence, modernising waste management systems will need to increasingly consider informal waste systems. 11
Proper landfill management is important to prevent scavengers accessing toxic waste sites. In addition, new low-cost technologies developed to minimise health risks during waste recycling need to be adopted by the informal sector. An example is salt water floatation for separating plastics containing toxic BFRs. 42 Governmental or NGO funding can provide equipment such as battery-driven handcarts, hand tools, safety wear and uniforms. 43 Uniforms and ID cards formalise the appearance of informal workers and thereby foster a better relationship with the public that can build self-confidence and self-esteem among informal workers. 33
Government training of informal sector workers can provide more professional recycling knowledge, such as standardised classification and processing methods for different waste, the laws and regulations concerning recycling and development plans for recycling systems. In China, relevant new regulations and laws have been implemented. For example, the Law on Circular Economy Promotion (effective from 1 January 2009) includes a legal framework for waste reduction, reuse and recycling while China’s new Environmental Protection Law also highlights waste management. 44 In July 2017, China released regulations to gradually stop importing soild wastes, especially WEEE. Strict enforcement of such laws and regulations by both formal and informal recyclers will be indispensable in improving waste recycling and protecting workers. 45
The creation of cooperatives and associations by informal recyclers has proven to be effective. The strengthening of these cooperatives and group networks can facilitate transfer of knowledge regarding proper waste handling and processing, related regulations and laws, environmental protection, sanitation, hygiene and health. 7 Such cooperatives also legitimise the work as a public service, allowing social programmes, such as extended healthcare and childcare, to be funded. In some countries, these cooperatives have combined into larger regional or national movements. 46 In Pune, India, Solid Waste Collection and Handling (SWaCH), a cooperative of approximately 1500 waste pickers, serves 2 00 000 households. 43 In Brazil, Coopamare is one of the most successful cooperatives 47 and the country has one of the largest and best established national movements of waste pickers. 6 46
There are characteristically more women than men working in the informal recycling sector. Support for the sector should, therefore, reflect this gender imbalance. For example, Women in Informal Employment: Globalising and Organising (WIEGO), is a global action research-policy network and waste picker support organisation focused on women in the informal waste sector. 46 WIEGO has been actively involved in the First World Conference of Waste Pickers (2008), the Third Latin American Conference of Waste Pickers (2008) and the National Day of the Waste Picker in Colombia (since 2008).
Collaboration between informal and formal sectors
Efforts have been made to integrate the formal and informal waste sectors. Effective integration can increase recycling rates, improve livelihoods and occupational and environmental health as well as reducing waste management costs. Research in Brazil, Egypt and India has demonstrated that integration can increase informal sector revenues and reduce total waste system costs for the formal sector. 43 A study of the state-of-the-art ‘InteRa’ model for integrating the informal sector within waste management systems in low-income and middle-income countries found similar win-win outcomes. 48 Successful development of integrated systems requires involvement of a wide variety of stakeholders beyond the formal and informal waste management sectors including federal, state and local governments, environment/development agencies and NGOs, academics and financial institutions. 47 49
Challenges and future research
Improving the health of those involved in the informal waste sector is a major challenge. International collaboration, for example, through the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), will be vital for improving waste management, including addressing environmental pollution problems, and for enhancing well-being of informal waste recyclers. While there are promising schemes for integrating the informal sector with formal waste management, especially in Latin America, 43 these are still in their infancy in many countries. Probably, the biggest challenges are to raise awareness of the issues facing the informal sector and to change attitudes to waste pickers in many traditional cultures. Governments and the media need to acknowledge the often vital contribution the informal sector can make to waste recycling. Changed attitudes would contribute to establishing support schemes for workers, better integration of informal workers in waste management and establishing professional informal sector recycling enterprises. 43
Current regulatory trends and capital investments pave the way for large recycling firms to operate. One result is that small players become excluded from the industry. Increasing pressure for automation and updated sorting techniques make it much more difficult for small enterprises to compete and informal workers are excluded from waste sites. There are clear health and safety benefits but displaced informal workers need to be either incorporated into new business schemes or be compensated to help alleviate poverty. Waste management decisions should also take into account who would most benefit from the revenues from recyclables and how to improve disposal of non-recyclable, often toxic, material. 11 High market prices can boost incentives for informal recycling and increase collection rates of recyclable material, while also benefiting the livelihoods of many individuals through employment. Conversely, low prices are challenging for informal waste recyclers.
Conclusions
With increasing populations and economic development, the quantity of waste being generated is rapidly increasing, creating an array of management and environmental issues. In many low-income and middle-income nations, insufficient funding for the formal waste sector means that globally around 15 million informal waste workers sort, collect, transport and trade waste. This informal sector makes major contributions to waste recycling and reuse. Heavy metals, plastic and paper are the main targets for informal waste recyclers. Unfortunately, relatively primitive recycling methods are responsible for major environmental pollution and human health problems. Some efforts have been made to integrate the informal waste sector with the formal sector, especially in Latin America. However, in many countries, the informal sector is still regarded as undesirable and often a nuisance despite the services it provides. Raising awareness of the valuable contributions made by the informal sector and changing public attitudes to those involved is needed. International collaboration, for example, through the SDGs, will be indispensable for improving waste management and the well-being of those participating in informal waste recycling.
What is already known on this subject
With expanding population and urbanisation, global waste generation is increasingly rapidly.
Despite limited support from many governments in developing countries, informal waste recyclers make great contributions to urban waste collection and recycling.
Without proper environmental protection, informal waste recycling, for example of toxic WEEE, pollutes water, soil and the atmosphere.
With little occupational protection, informal waste recyclers are impacted by many serious health hazards.
What this study adds
Rates of WEEE and plastic waste generation are increasing very rapidly so urgent measures are needed to reduce usage of plastic and promote safe recycling of WEEE.
Green chemistry and low-cost technologies can increase recycling efficiency and reduce the health risks to informal recyclers.
Effective integration of the informal sector within waste management systems can optimise waste recycling and improve the health and welfare of informal recyclers.
Collaborations between the private, public, government and NGO sectors is essential for minimising the environmental and health risks of informal recycling.

Abstract
Crude or primitive recycling practices are often adopted in material resource recovery from E-waste in developing nations. Significant human health and environmental impacts may occur because of such practices. Literature on metal(loid)s pollution during E-waste processing is fragmented. Here, I review the health and environmental impacts of E-waste recycling operations and transport pathways of metal(loid)s, dispersed during operations. This paper is organised into five sections. Section 1 relates to the background of global E-waste generation and legal/illegal trade, citing specific cases from Ghana and other developing nations. Section 2 provides a brief information on sources of metal(loid)s in E-waste. Section 3 describes characteristics of informal E-waste recycling operations in developing nations. Section 4 examines the health and environmental impacts in E-waste recycling while section 5 evaluates major transport pathways of metal(loid)s contaminants.
Introduction
E-waste is the generic name for electronic wastes, which includes discarded electronic devices or broken electronic or electrical items (Widmer et al. 2005 ). Sources of E-waste include appliances such as televisions, personal computers, telephones, mobile phones, fax machines and photocopiers. While E-waste contains hazardous elements such as chromium, cadmium, mercury and lead, it is also considered a rich secondary source of metals including aluminum, iron, copper, zinc, palladium, platinum and gold. E-waste generation is staggering worldwide. For example, in 2006, global E-waste generation was estimated to be around 20–25 million tonnes per year in 2006 with most E-waste production regions in Europe, the USA and Australasia (Petranikova 2008; Robinson 2009 ). In Europe, about 8 million tonnes are generated annually, with annual increases of 3–5% (Drechse 2006 ). In the USA alone, 11.7 million tonnes of E-waste was generated in 2014 (Baldé et al. 2015 ). In Australasia, E-waste generation was estimated to be around 106,000 tonnes in 2007–2008, and is projected to reach 181,000 tonnes by 2027–2028 (Khaliq et al. 2014 ). China, Japan and India lead in absolute E-waste generation in Asia with 6, 2.2 and 1.7 Mt, respectively, in 2014 (Baldé et al. 2015 ). Advances in technology, rapid economic growth, urbanization and innovative marketing strategies have contributed to growing demand for consumer goods resulting in high production and consumption of electrical and electronic goods (Babu et al. 2007 ). High costs of labour, lack of recycling facilities and strict environmental laws have facilitated the export of E-waste from rich and developed nations to poor and developing countries (Iqbal et al. 2015 ). Consequently, old waste electrical and electronic goods are exported to developing countries to “bridge the digital divide” and satisfy demand for cheap second-hand electrical and electronic equipment (Prakash et al. 2010 ). Emerging economies and developing countries plagued by large volumes of legal and illegal imports of E-waste include China, India, Brazil, Ghana and Nigeria (Wu et al. 2015; Jun-Hui and Hang 2009; Otsuka et al. 2012 ). For example, it is estimated that about 25–75% of second-hand goods exported to Africa are broken and cannot be reused (Herten 2008 ). Significant increases in E-waste generation have not led to improved collection, recycling or reuse (Kahhat et al. 2008 ). For example, in the USA, it is estimated in 2002 that 20–24 million obsolete computers and TVs were added to storage rather than being disposed and recycled (Ongondo et al. 2011 ), while about 50–80% of total outputs of E-waste collected for recycling were exported rather than treated locally (Puckett and Smith 2002; Lepawsky 2015 ). The Basel Convention is the key international legislation regulating the trade of E-waste between Annex VII countries (made up of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), European Commission (EC), Lichtenstein) and non-annex VII countries (all other signatories) (Lepawsky 2015 ). Under the Basel Convention, E-waste labelled as reusable is allowed for export. The USA for instance has neither signed the Basel Convention nor ratified the Basel Ban Amendment which prohibits all forms of export of hazardous waste from rich countries to poor countries including for recycling. Under the USA’s own laws, it is legal to export all forms of E-waste including cathode ray tubes (CRTs) which the USEPA has listed as hazardous waste (Man et al. 2013 ). A “loophole” thus exists in the Basel Convention, which is often exploited by some developed countries. Inadequate national regulations and/or lax enforcement of existing laws on disposal and recycling in developing countries has also contributed to the growth of semi-formal and informal industries around trading, repairing and recovering materials from redundant electronic devices (Widmer et al. 2005 ). Some developed countries including Switzerland are one of the first countries to promulgate WEEE legislation (Sinha-Khetriwal et al. 2005 ). They have organized systems for E-waste collection, recycling, disposal and monitoring (Wath et al. 2010; Ongondo et al. 2011 ). The E-waste system of most developing countries including Ghana is dominated by the informal sector who struggle to cope with the negative environmental impacts of informal E-waste recycling (Sinha-Khetriwal et al. 2005 ). Recovering metals from E-waste uses considerably less materials and energy with relatively less environmental damage as compared to mining, manufacturing, transport and energy use (Cui and Forssberg 2003; Bains et al. 2006; Bohr 2007 ). E-waste is one of the most complex waste streams because of the wide variety of components and their compositions, and rapidly changing product designs. For example, electric and electronic components are being increasingly added into other product categories such as tools, toys, kitchen utensils and machinery (Lauridsen and Jørgensen 2010 ). Challenges faced in E-waste management in Ghana is therefore not only because of consequence of the growing quantities of waste, but also of complexity of E-waste. Complexity in the design and composition of electrical and electronic devices renders them technically and economically undesirable for reuse or recycling (Berkhout and Hertin 2004; Realff et al. 2004; Toffel and Horvath 2004 ). Most E-waste ends in emerging economies and developing countries: 70% of all exported E-waste ends in China (Liu et al. 2006 ), with significant quantities ending in India, Pakistan, Vietnam, Philippines, Malaysia, Nigeria and Ghana (Puckett et al. 2005) and possibly Mexico and Brazil (Robinson 2009 ).
Ghana is a signatory to the 1989 Basel Convention on the control of transboundary movement of hazardous waste and disposal; however, loopholes such as export of E-waste as second-hand goods have ensured large imports of E-waste into Ghana (Orisakwe and Frazzoli 2010 ). Ghana recently approved its own specific legislation to deal with E-waste menace (Daum et al. 2017 ). Ghana’s legislation seeks to domesticate the Basel Convention into its own national laws and establish an electrical and electronic waste management fund to support establishment of treatment facilities, research and public education. The generation of domestic E-waste in Ghana has become significant in recent years with domestic E-waste generation estimated to be about 150,000 tonnes in 2009 while imported electrical and electronic devices reached 215,000 tonnes (Amoyaw-Osei et al. 2011 ). Thirty percent of imports were new and unused items, with the remaining 70% consisting of second-hand goods. These tonnages may likely increase with the current and projected annual population growth rate of 7% (Akormedi 2012 ). The use of information technology such as mobile phones and computers has increased significantly because of increasing affordability. Unlike most developed countries, who have formalized and efficient collection and recycling programs and established policies and legislations governing E-waste, most developing countries are lagging and grappling with serious challenges on E-waste. Our study has the following objectives; we aim to review metal(loids) pollution, pathways and impacts from E-waste recycling operations focusing on the global E-waste problem, E-waste processing and dismantling, possible transport pathways for contaminants at E-waste recycling sites and environmental and biological receptors for contaminants.
Sources of metal(loid)s in E-waste
Electronic products especially personal computers have grown exponentially in the last decade (Realff et al. 2004 ). This presents disposal challenges at the end-of-life for many of these products. However, 1000 or more substances are embedded in E-waste many of which are toxic such as Cr (VI), As, Se, Cd and Hg (Widmer et al. 2005 ). E-waste also contains several valuable substances including precious metals such as Pd, Pt and Au. The material composition of E-waste, made up of both valuable and toxic substances is the primary factor which drives material recycling of E-waste. For example, first generation computers, which contains 1 g of Au today used to contain about 4 g of Au (Agarwal et al. 2003 ). Over half of the material composition in E-waste is metals (APME 1995; EMPA 2005 ). Precious metals have been used in E-waste as contact materials because of desirable physical and chemical characteristics such as high electrical conductivity and chemical stability (Cui and Zhang 2008 ). Informal E-waste recycling operations
E-waste recycling in many developing countries is largely operated by the informal sector, who is involved in collection, recycling, refurbishment, reuse and disposal of residuals. The informal sector, mostly large and of low-wage workers possess an impressive ability to repair and refurbish the used electronic equipment for local resale (BAN 2005 ). Scavengers usually move about from households and businesses purchasing old electrical and electronic goods and selling them to recyclers. Components are then processed to directly useable components or secondary raw materials in a variety of refining and conditioning processes (Oteng-Ababio 2012 ). Rudimentary methods such as manual disassembly, open burning and sometimes acid leaching are used to strip the most valuable and easily extractable components in open yards with no emission control. Uncontrolled acid leaching and open burning could induce severe environmental contamination through the release of many toxic substances such as brominated flame retardants (BFRs), a component of many plastic components used in E-waste, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), dioxins and furans and other volatile and toxic metals and metalloids (EMPA 2009 ). E-waste dumping in surface waters or on land adjacent to waterbodies could result in run-off and dispersion of various toxic contaminants to estuaries and agricultural fields. In Ghana, the Korle Lagoon, which used to support a thriving fishery industry (Biney 1998) has been polluted by organic and inorganic contaminants (Huang et al. 2014; Hosoda et al. 2014 ). Furthermore, hazardous metal(loids) may leach through the soil and contaminate drinking water sources including groundwater. Metal(loid)s and organic contamination present a health hazard particularly when recyclers use bare hands to strip components of E-waste and do not wear protective clothing. Humans living in vicinal suburbs risk contamination from pollutants dispersed via particulate matter through environmental pathways such as air, food, water, dust, smoke and or fumes. Metals, unlike organic contaminants, do not undergo microbial or chemical degradation, are persistent, and may be bioaccumulative and toxic (Adriano et al. 2004 ). There is limited information on the impacts of E-waste on terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems (Kiddee et al. 2013 ).
Health and environmental impacts
E-waste impacts on the health outcomes of human populations in developing countries have been reviewed by several workers (Frazzoli et al. 2010; Grant et al. 2013 ). However, less evidence has been collected to evaluate direct harm to individuals exposed to E-waste, with many reasons such as long-term exposure to E-waste, unstable condition of the subject population and other underlying unhealthy conditions (Sthiannopkao and Wong 2013 ). The main environmental impacts from E-waste recycling sites depend on the type of processing activity. For example, non-thermal processes (hydrometallurgy) generate wastewater in large quantities because of greater volumes of water used. In contrast, thermal processes (pyrometallurgy) generate abundant gaseous pollutants including lead fumes and dioxins (Bizzo et al. 2014 ). Some of the media through which toxicants are released from E-waste recycling sites is discussed in Section 4.1.
Metal(loid)s in airborne particulates
Many pretreatment processes used in informal E-waste recycling including grinding, melting, roasting and open burning releases large amounts of fumes, dust and smoke into the atmosphere, with potential carcinogens including chromium and manganese (Zheng et al. 2013, 2016 ). Total concentrations of PM 2.5 in an E-waste recycling area showed higher concentrations in a reference area and exceeded WHO 24-h PM 2.5 ambient air quality guidelines set at 25 μg m −3 (Zheng et al. 2016 ). The total suspended samples form a printed circuit boards recycling area contained water-soluble inorganic ions in a decreasing order (SO 4 2−, NH 4+, K+, Na+, Cl − and NO 3 −) (Bi et al. 2010 ). Significant concentrations of Pb (6.1%), Zn (4.6%), Sn (2.9%) and lesser concentrations (< 1%) of Cu, Sb, Mn, Ni, Ba and Cd were observed in the workshop of the recycling area. Analysis of printed circuit board fly ash in a simulated open burn facility indicated high concentrations of bromine (21%), lead (8%), copper (5%), tin (1%) and lesser concentrations (< 1%) of zinc and antimony (Gullet et al. 2007 ). Flue gas from incineration of personal computer motherboards and keyboards contained significant quantities of Cu, Sb and Pb and trace metal(loid)s including Be, Cr, Mn, Co, As, Ag, Cd and Ba. Mercury, selenium and thallium were not detected in the flue gas (Stewart and Lemieux 2003 ). Suspended air particulates in a dismantling area of an E-waste recycling workshop in Hong Kong contained highest concentrations of Cr, Ni, Cd and Pb with high metal concentrations attributable to dust generated from manual dismantling of electrical and electronic equipment using hand-held tools (Lau et al. 2014 ). Copper and zinc concentrations were however highest in the cable shredding areas, due to their abundance in cables (Lau et al. 2014 ).
Wastewater from dismantling and shredding activities
E-waste is a concentrated source of rare earth metals and plastics. Recycling metals from E-waste can generate less wastewater as compared to mining metals from mineral ores. Large amounts of land and energy are used mining, releasing large amounts of wastewater, sulfur dioxide and carbon dioxide (Zhang et al. 2012 ). Water resources can be severely polluted by the improper disposal of wastewater (Shinkuma and Huong 2009 ). E-waste processing employing hydrometallurgy using toxic acids (nitric acid) and cyanide produces large amounts of wastewater containing acids and various metallic ions such as cyanide, which can damage people and the environment if not treated efficiently. Wastewater from hydrometallurgical processes are usually not treated and disposed efficiently because of lack of wastewater treatment facilities (Xiang et al. 2007 ).
Fly and bottom ash from E-waste burning
Fly ash refers to airborne fine grained material with high specific surface area (Ferreira et al. 2003 ). Fly ash particulates laden with metal(loid)s and other toxic materials are usually emitted in the open burning of materials resulting in increased exposure through contamination of food, soil and surface water (Zheng et al. 2008 ). During E-waste incineration, volatile metals are enriched into fly ash while lithophilic metals are deposited into bottom ash (Jung et al. 2004 ).
Leachates from dumping of E-waste
E-waste contributes approximately 70% by mass of metals (Grossman 2006 ). Leachates extracted from river sediments and paddy soils for toxicity testing by undergoing a 6-h extraction on a horizontal oscillator with bubbling nitrogen and subsequent filtration with 0.45-μm pore filter and 0.22-μm membrane filter showed higher concentrations in river sediments than in paddy soils (Nie et al. 2015 ). The concentrations of Pb in leached extracts of 36 cathode ray tubes (CRTs) had been assessed using Toxicity Characteristic Leaching Procedure (TCLP), and 21 of colour CRTs exceeded 5 mg/L, the regulatory limit for characterization as hazardous waste (Townsend et al. 1999 ). Metals were concentrated in the funnel component which recorded average lead concentration of 75.3 mg/L (Townsend et al. 1999 ).
E-waste solid materials
Studies on assessment of E-waste impacts have focused on solid materials components of E-waste such as printed wiring boards of personal computers (Li et al. 2006; Bizzo et al. 2014) that of mobile phones (Nnorom and Osibanjo 2011 ), combination of mobile phones’ and personal computers’ printed wiring boards (Yamane et al. 2011 ), simulated landfill columns (Li et al. 2009 ), CRT monitors (Musson et al. 2000; Nnorom et al. 2010) and mobile phone plastic housing units (Nnorom and Osibanjo 2009 ). Leachate analysis showed non-detectable concentrations of Pb and other toxic metals, significant concentrations of Pb ranging from 1590 to 2930 mg/kg in solid samples (Li et al. 2009 ). Material recovery benefits of E-waste recycling and concentrations of metals after undergoing mechanical separation have been evaluated and the data compared with 13 similar studies (Bizzo et al. 2014 ). Smaller particle sized printed wiring board (particle size of < 1.18 mm) contained higher inorganic material than larger particle sizes (> 1.18 mm). Lighter printed wiring boards (density of < 2.89 g cm −3) had higher average volatile content and gross calorific value (GCV), despite having a higher ash content (Bizzo et al. 2014 ).
Major transport pathways in E-waste recycling environment
Contaminants released from E-waste recycling environments are dispersed among and/or can accumulate in various environmental compartments (e.g. soil, vegetation, indoor dust, animals and humans). While some contaminants contribute to local pollution (i.e. within 10 km), other substances remain persistent for a long time and can be distributed over much greater distances, contributing to regional pollution (i.e. over hundreds of kilometres) (NAP 2000 ).
Dust
Dust as environmental media could provide useful information on concentrations, distributions and fate of contaminants present in the surface environment (Leung et al. 2008 ). Dust dispersion is dependent on physical and micro-environmental factors, including topography, wind direction and urban run-off (Wong et al. 2006 ). Air currents may influence wind speed and direction, and this in addition to the topography and positioning of buildings control deposition and dispersion of metal-laden dusts and particulates (Wong et al. 2006 ). The metals in settled dust from various receiving surfaces such as roads, top soils, buildings and plants can be easily re-suspended and dispersed among different environmental media including air and water (Kong et al. 2011 ). Metals in dust have a direct influence on public safety since they can easily enter human bodies by dust ingestion, dermal contact and inhalation (Abrahams 2002 ). Settled dust is similar in composition to atmospheric metal particulates and can be used as an indicator of atmospheric pollution (Akhter and Madany 1993 ). House dust is an important exposure medium for many environmental contaminants deposited on indoor surfaces from outdoor and internal sources (Adgate et al. 1995 ). In countries with moderate climate, the time spent indoors could vary between 70 and 90% depending on age, occupation and season. Children inadvertently has higher health risks than adults because of low tolerance to metal toxicity and ingestion of dusts (soils) through hand-to-mouth (Ljung et al. 2005; Acosta et al. 2009 ). Metal concentrations may be evaluated in dust deposited on unit area (Krolak 2000 ). Dust in E-waste recycling sites in developing countries have recorded elevated concentrations of some toxic metal(loid)s. For example, As and Sb concentrations in surface dusts from 13 E-waste recycling villages in Guiyu, southeastern China showed higher concentrations (about 13–147 times) of Sb (Bi et al. 2011 ). However, in Bi et al. 2011 study, arsenic concentrations in dust samples reflected mainly background concentrations. In a study to assess diffusion of metal(loid)s from E-waste recycling area, soils and road dust samples were collected from 11 sampling points in residential areas, garden/park, and school/kindergarten in Guiyu and a reference area, about 31.6 km east of Guiyu, during four seasons (Yekeen et al. 2016 ). Results from the study showed significantly higher concentrations for soil Pb than road dust Pb (Yekeen et al. 2016 ). On the other hand, average concentrations for Pb in road dust for all seasons were significantly higher compared to Pb concentrations in the reference area (Yekeen et al. 2016 ). Metal(loid)s dispersion in agricultural surface soils and soils (dusts) from an E-waste recycling workshop in Longtang, northern Guangzhou was studied (Liu et al. 2013 ). Dust sampled from one workshop yard where E-waste recycling activities such as dismantling of electric motors, air conditioner compressors and water metres, contained the highest concentrations of all eight metals measured. Copper, cadmium, mercury, zinc, lead and Ni exceeded the maximum level of metal allowances per the Chinese Soil Standard Grade II by 326, 203, 192, 27.7, 19.2 and 14-fold, respectively (Liu et al. 2013 ). Fujimori et al. (2012) study on surface matrices (soil and dust) from formal E-waste recycling sites in northern and southern Metro Manila, Philippines indicated that dust from formal recycling sites contained the highest concentration of metal(loid)s including Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Ag, In and Pb. Ofudje et al. (2014) investigated metals (Pb, Cr, Ni, Cd and Zn) content in dusts in four E-waste dismantling sites in Lagos, Nigeria during the dry season and recorded significant higher lead concentrations than were recorded by Adaramodu et al. (2012) who investigated metals in dust from surfaces of E-waste components as well as floor of a E-waste recycling yard in Lagos, Nigeria. In Ghana, most of the literature on metal(loid)s in dust are focussed on road dust (Atiemo et al. 2011; Atiemo et al. 2012; Addo et al. 2012 ), surface dust at E-waste recycling site (Atiemo et al. 2012 ), rain water contaminated by suspended dust during road construction (Pelig-Ba et al. 2001 ), dust deposited by traffic (Essumang et al. 2006) and surface soil in gold mining areas (Golow et al. 1996 ). Kyere et al. (2016) work revealed that metal(loid) contaminants had dispersed beyond Agbogbloshie E-waste processing areas onto residential, recreational, commercial and farms circumjacent to the main E-waste processing area.
Air
Metal concentrations in ambient air and exposure biomarkers had been assessed in both formal and informal E-waste recycling environments in several countries including Ghana (Asante et al. 2012; Caravanos et al. 2011 ), Sweden (Julander et al. 2014 ), China (Deng et al. 2006) and in India (Ha et al. 2009 ). Cr, Zn, As and Pb concentrations were enhanced in the fine particulate fraction (78–108%) of total suspended particles in air at Guiyu, a popular E-waste recycling centre in China (Wong et al. 2007 ).
Surface water
E-waste recycling sites, especially where E-waste are combusted are usually located near sources of water including streams and ponds to conveniently take advantage of potential water sources for metal extraction processes (Luo et al. 2011 ). E-waste contaminants can enter aquatic systems via leaching from dumped processed or unprocessed E-wastes (Robinson 2009 ). Acid disposal following hydrometallurgical recycling of E-waste and dissolution of airborne particulates from E-waste can result in the contamination of aquatic systems (Robinson 2009 ). Guo et al. (2009) determined the effects of E-waste recycling activities on the surrounding waterway system in Guiyu and found that concentrations of metal(loid)s including Ni, Cu, As, Cd, Hg and Pb decreased downstream from Guiyu E-waste processing village through Lanjiang River to Haimen Bay estuary. Wang and Guo (2006) earlier on investigated the effects of E-waste recycling on surface water, groundwater and sediments from three locations to establish whether E-waste recycling activities were impacting on the surrounding environment or not. It was established that Ni, Cu, Zn, As and Hg concentrations were generally below the Chinese environmental guidelines for surface water quality. In Ghana, threats to waterbodies by metal(loid)s in E-waste has been emphasized strongly (Brigden et al. 2008; Chama et al. 2014; Huang et al. 2014 ). Chama et al. (2014) work showed that sediments of Odaw River were more contaminated with Ni, Cu, Cd and Pb near E-waste burning site than other sites further away such as vegetable cultivation area and an area where there wasn’t any E-waste recycling activity. Cr, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Cd, Hg and Pb concentrations in surface sediments in an E-waste disassembly area and an industrial park in Nanguan River, Taizhou in East China were studied (Chen et al. 2010 ). Although, metal(loid)s concentrations were much higher than control sediments samples taken from an upstream area and the Netherlands Quality Criteria for dredged material, the concentrations were generally lower than a Basel Action Network (BAN) study conducted in Guiyu (BAN 2002 ). Metals generally tend to bind to sediment particles when entering a river system, with a greater probability of being re-suspended into the river during acidic conditions (Wong et al. 2007 ).
Soil
Soils are prone to contamination from hydrological and atmospheric sources (Candeias et al. 2014 ). Soils are sinks for various gaseous and particulate atmospheric pollutants emitted from E-waste recycling (Liu et al. 2013 ). Metals could be released into the soil environment through natural processes, such as volcanic activity, erosion and bioaccumulation; intentional anthropogenic processes, such as mining, smelting, industrial uses and unintentional anthropogenic processes such as incineration and burning of fossil fuels (Caussy et al. 2003 ). Elements could be introduced into distance environments through immobilization by sorption, complexation with iron and manganese oxides and organic or humic substances (Arhin and Boansi 2016 ). Many metals, persistent and non-degradable can enter human bodies through dust inhalation, direct soil ingestion and the consumption of food crops (Li et al. 2012 ). Several plants absorb metals from soils and accumulate them in their tissues depending on varying accumulating potential (Liu et al. 2006; Herat and Agamuthu 2012; Yao et al. 2013 ). Bioavailability of metals varies with the soil types and soil pH. Sandy soils allow for the greater bioavailability than clay-rich soils and low soil pH generally increases plant bioavailability (Chaney and Hornick 1978 ). Studies conducted on soils of E-waste recycling sites in both India and China over the years has showed high concentrations of metals and metalloids. For example, in Bangalore and Chennai, India, ten surface soils samples from a licensed E-waste recycling facility, backyard recycling sites and reference sites showed high concentrations of V, Cr, Mn, Co, Cu, Zn, Mo, Ag, Cd, In, Sn, Sb, Pb, TI and Bi (Ha et al. 2009 ). Crude methods of recycling had probably added higher concentrations of metal contaminants into soils sampled in backyard recycling workshops in slum areas. A similar trend was also reported in Guiyu, where concentrations of 11 metal(loid)s including Be, Cr, Mn, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Sb, Cd, Hg and Pb in an E-waste dismantling area, showed high correlations between metal concentrations in surface soils and E-waste dismantling activities (Li et al. 2011 ). Metal concentrations generally decreased with depths along a depth gradient with elevated pH and reduced total organic matter (TOM) in both burning site and paddy field (Wu et al. 2015 ). The concentration and source apportionment of metals in urban soils, apart from spatial variation also vary with depth because of temporal inputs characteristics and leaching transport of pollutants (Zhang et al. 2007 ). Fujimori and Takigami (2014) measured the concentrations of Zn, Cu and Pb in small spot areas using a field-portable X-ray spectrometer within a small informal E-waste recycling area in Metro Manila. The distance from the entrance of the study site influenced the surficial metal concentration gradient at distances away from the entrance on the y -axis (perpendicular) direction, rather than on the x -axis (horizontal) direction, and that metal concentrations were discretely distributed in surface soils, showing heterogenous distribution of soil metal(loid)s.
Biota
Various plant species including trees, vegetable crops, grasses and weeds are known to accumulate a wide range of metals (Kabata-Pendias and Pendias 1992 ). There are public health implications if plant foods accumulate high concentrations of metals; furthermore, leaf fall and dispersal may pose a hazard. The metal species is an important factor in various transfer routes of metals into various food chain compartments (Notten et al. 2005 ). Metal speciation is also dependent on variable soil properties including pH, organic matter, clay content (Salomons and Förstner 1984 ). Metal distribution across soil profile and rooting depth are other contributing factors (Martin and Coughtrey 1982 ). Total metal concentrations were twice higher in plants (S. viridis and peanut) in E-waste recycling areas than in similar plants from farmland areas (Wang et al. 2015 ). Sun et al. (2014) sampled 18 plant species from 16 families near an industrial area in Chenzhou city, Hunan Province, China and found that order of metal concentration in plant samples followed a similar pattern to soils from which the plants were taken. Metal uptake via roots from contaminated soils and surface water, and direct deposition of contaminants from the atmosphere onto plant surfaces can lead to plant contamination by metals (Zhuang et al. 2009 ). Continuous E-waste exposure through contaminated water and soil elevate chemical loadings of pastures (Frazzoli et al. 2010 ); long-term intake by diary ruminants may occur which could result in bioaccumulation in tissues and excretion in edible products such as eggs and milk (Kierkegaard et al. 2007 ). In Ghana, concentrations of Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Mo, Hg and Pb in two common plants (Eleusine indica (L.) Gaertn. and Sida acuta Burm. f. ), growing around four refuse dumps had higher concentrations than in a reference site, 1 km apart (Agyarko et al. 2010 ).
Conclusion
From this review work, literature on E-waste pollution has been synthesized to emphasize E-waste recycling impacts on major environmental media. Sound management of metal(loid)s emitted from E-waste recycling operations is a priority. In already contaminated environments, there is the need for management of these sites since they present major risks to human health and the environment. Remediation of already contaminated E-waste recycling environments in developing countries and emerging economies is also a greatest need.
